SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right elbow pain
- History of present illness: Pain in the outside part of the right elbow for about three weeks following increased tennis activity, described as shooting, stabbing, very sharp; pain rated 8/10 with use and 3/10 at rest; worsened by movement, mild relief with Tylenol and ibuprofen but returns once they wear off, minimal relief with ice; no trauma, no radiation of pain; no fever reported
- Past medical history: Type 2 diabetes, mild intermittent asthma
- Surgical history: Gallbladder removal approximately 10 years ago
- Allergies: Penicillin
- Social history: Increased recent physical activity playing tennis
- Medication adherence: Taking metformin 500 mg twice daily, fluticasone (Flovent) twice daily, albuterol as needed

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur unchanged from prior, otherwise normal cardiovascular exam; moderate lateral epicondylar tenderness of right elbow; moderate pain with passive range of motion of right elbow; mild pain with resisted wrist extension; no palpable joint effusion; otherwise unremarkable musculoskeletal exam
- Test results: Right elbow X-ray shows no acute fracture, malalignment, or joint effusion; hemoglobin A1c, CBC, and Chem-12 ordered (results pending)

A (Assessment):

- Acute lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow) of the right elbow
- Type 2 diabetes with blood sugar out of control
- Mild intermittent asthma, well controlled

P (Plan):

- For right elbow pain: Advise rest of right arm, discontinue tennis for 4-6 weeks, avoid repetitive stress activities, ice right elbow 20 minutes three times daily, provide right forearm brace, prescribe Ultram (tramadol) 50 mg once daily for pain, follow-up in 4 weeks with possible further imaging or physical therapy referral if needed
- For type 2 diabetes: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily, check blood sugar twice daily for 2 weeks, order hemoglobin A1c, CBC, and Chem-12 blood tests, monitor and adjust treatment based on results
- For asthma: Continue fluticasone (Flovent) twice daily and albuterol as needed, prescribe albuterol refill

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Possible kidney stone, history of hypertension and diabetes  
- History of present illness: Intermittent kidney pain improving after ER visit last week, believes recent kidney stone passed about 3 days ago, no current pain or blood in urine, recurrent kidney stones (7th or 8th episode)  
- Past medical history: Hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, recurrent kidney stones  
- Medications: Norvasc 2.5 mg, Metformin 500 mg daily, pain medication (Percocet) given at ER for kidney stone  
- Social history: Difficulty controlling diet due to fast food consumption, limited time to prepare meals  
- Patient reports occasional insomnia related to worrying, uses meditation apps, prefers sleeping with TV and phone nearby, reluctant to use sleeping pills  

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 150/90 mmHg at visit, home readings around 130-140/60-70 mmHg  
- Physical exam: Lungs clear bilaterally, grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur unchanged, no abdominal or costovertebral angle tenderness  
- Test results: Last HbA1c 6.7% (from previous visit) indicating slight improvement in diabetes control  

A (Assessment):

- Passed kidney stone  
- Hypertension, stable on current medication  
- Type 2 diabetes mellitus, stable with current treatment  
- Insomnia, mild  

P (Plan):

- Order urinalysis and urine culture to confirm clearance of kidney stone-related infection  
- Referral to urology (preferably Dr. Harris) for evaluation of recurrent kidney stones  
- Continue Norvasc 2.5 mg without changes, refills as needed  
- Refer to nutrition/dietitian to assist with dietary modifications, especially sodium restriction (~2300 mg/day) and fast food reduction  
- Continue Metformin 500 mg daily  
- Encourage blood glucose monitoring before meals to better manage diabetes  
- Prescribe melatonin 10 mg as needed for insomnia, emphasize sleep hygiene practices including limiting electronics use at bedtime and using sleep mode features on devices  
- Follow-up appointment in 3 months for reassessment

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Persistent asthma symptoms with frequent coughing and wheezing
- History of present illness: Asthma flares occur approximately every 1-2 months over the past six months, often triggered by colds or cat exposure; frequent need for urgent care or primary care visits, occasional antibiotic and steroid treatments, one emergency department visit for severe flare; uses albuterol inhaler (Ventolin) almost daily, including nighttime use 2-3 times per week; other inhaler not helpful; no seasonal allergy history; no tobacco, marijuana, or vaping use; occasional exposure to secondhand smoke in bars causing irritation; enjoys hiking and outdoor activities but cautious due to symptoms
- Past medical history: Hospitalization for asthma once around age 8
- Social history: No smoking or vaping, occasional bar visits with secondhand smoke exposure
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 128/82 mmHg, respiratory rate 16/min, oxygen saturation 99% on room air
- Physical exam: Heart regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs or gallops; lungs with diminished breath sounds bilaterally and occasional slight expiratory wheezes; neck supple, trachea midline, no lymphadenopathy; no carotid bruits; strong bilateral hand pulses, no clubbing, brisk capillary refill
- Test results: Pulmonary function test consistent with asthma diagnosis

A (Assessment):

- Moderate intermittent asthma

P (Plan):

- Start Flovent 110 mcg, one puff twice daily (inhaled steroid) to reduce daily symptoms and rescue inhaler use
- Continue Ventolin (albuterol) inhaler, two puffs every 4-6 hours as needed for acute exacerbations; use one to two puffs, wait to assess breathing before additional puffs
- Develop asthma action plan to monitor symptoms and manage triggers such as cat exposure and respiratory infections
- Follow-up appointment in 30 days or sooner if symptoms worsen

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Chronic back pain for a couple of years
* History of present illness: Back pain started after moving furniture on a weekend, described as sharp stabbing pain radiating down the right leg to the big toe, worsens with sitting, associated numbness and tingling in the right leg and foot, no numbness or loss of sensation in genital or rectal area, no weakness, no loss of bladder or bowel control
* Past medical history: Tried physical therapy and strong pain medications previously, surgery was mentioned but patient wants to avoid it
* Social history: Former smoker, quit about twenty years ago
* Family history: No known family members with spine conditions
* Impact on daily life: Difficulty staying active due to back pain, weight gain over the past years, limitation in playing golf

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Overall look pretty good (specific values not provided)
* Physical exam: No erythema or ecchymosis on back, midline tenderness at L4-L5 disk space, right-sided lumbar paravertebral tenderness, pain with lumbar flexion, positive supine straight leg raise test, decreased sensation to light touch at right lateral thigh at L4 dermatome, symmetrical patellar and Achilles reflexes
* Test results: MRI shows disk herniation with nerve impingement at L4-L5

A (Assessment):

* L4-L5 herniated disk with radiculopathy

P (Plan):

* Recommend spinal injection of corticosteroid into lumbar spine under fluoroscopy
* Monitor patient response to injection, with usually no more than four injections per year
* Proceed with first corticosteroid injection today if patient agrees

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right knee pain after water skiing accident
- History of present illness: Twisted right knee landing from a jump while water skiing about 5 days ago, no popping sound felt, sensation of stretching followed by swelling, pain worsens with squatting and bending, no numbness or tingling in foot, took over-the-counter Aleve twice daily and used cold packs with some pain relief
- Past medical history: Hypertension, tonsillectomy
- Medications: Lisinopril 20 mg daily for blood pressure
- Social history: Frequent water skier, goes most weekends, non-baseball fan, engages in outdoor activities
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 120/77 mmHg in office
- Physical exam: No lymphadenopathy on neck exam, heart regular rate and rhythm with no murmurs, lungs clear bilaterally, right knee shows ecchymosis, edema, effusion, pain on palpation particularly on medial side, decreased range of motion, negative varus and valgus stress tests, negative Lachman test, palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, no lower extremity edema
- Test results: No imaging performed yet, x-ray of right knee ordered
- Other: No prior surgeries besides tonsillectomy

A (Assessment):

- Medial collateral ligament strain of the right knee
- Hypertension, controlled on lisinopril

P (Plan):

- Order right knee x-ray to rule out fracture
- Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily for inflammation and pain
- Refer to physical therapy for muscle strengthening around the knee
- Advise rest and avoidance of skiing until evaluation and x-ray results
- Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for blood pressure management
- Order lipid panel for cardiovascular risk assessment
- Administer tetanus booster vaccine for health maintenance
- Follow-up after imaging and therapy initiation or as needed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Incidental lung nodule found after evaluation for cough
* History of present illness: Off and on cough for about three months, initially noticed after loading hay for horses; cough worsened after a cold but has since resolved; exercises regularly including frequent biking
* Past medical history: Rheumatoid arthritis managed with methotrexate 7.5 mg weekly; no recent flares, mostly hand joint involvement
* Social history: Former smoker, quit approximately seven years ago
* Family history: Mother with breast cancer currently doing well; no family history of lung cancer or other malignancies
* Patient concerns: Nervousness and fear related to lung nodule and upcoming procedures

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 124/76 mmHg, heart rate 70/min, respiratory rate 16/min, oxygen saturation 98% on room air, afebrile
* Physical exam: Lungs clear and equal bilaterally on auscultation; heart regular rate and rhythm without murmurs, clicks, or rubs; skin pink, warm, dry; no lower extremity edema; mild swelling over third digit knuckles bilaterally consistent with rheumatoid arthritis; peripheral pulses intact; brisk capillary refill
* Test results: Chest CT showing a solitary 2 cm smooth nodule in the lateral aspect of the right upper lobe without emphysematous changes

A (Assessment):

* Incidentally found right upper lobe lung nodule

P (Plan):

* Order pulmonary function tests for baseline lung function assessment
* Schedule PET CT scan to evaluate metabolic activity of the lung nodule
* Plan video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) for removal of the lung nodule with a small portion of lung tissue under general anesthesia; expected hospital stay one night with chest tube removal next day
* Continue follow-up with rheumatologist and maintain methotrexate therapy for rheumatoid arthritis
* Provide patient education and emotional support regarding diagnosis and planned procedures

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Difficulty swallowing for 4-5 weeks, feeling like food is stuck in throat, occasional mild pain, mostly with solid foods requiring washing down
* History of present illness: No coughing, no symptoms with liquids, no vomiting, no blood in vomit or stools, no weight loss, no chest pain, no shortness of breath
* Past medical history: Diabetes mellitus, hypertension
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided
* Current medication adherence: Taking metformin 500 mg twice daily and Norvasc, adherent to medications about 80% of the time for blood sugar checks
* Diabetes control: Reports blood sugar readings within target range, no nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea from metformin
* Blood pressure control: Reports mostly controlled blood pressure at home, occasional variations

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Office blood pressure 120/50 mmHg
* Physical exam: Neck without swelling or masses, thyroid normal, no lymphadenopathy, throat normal without masses, swelling, or redness, no carotid bruit, clear lung exam, normal heart exam without murmurs, epigastric tenderness on abdominal exam without masses or swelling, normal back exam, normal extremity and neurological exams
* Test results: Last hemoglobin A1c 7.4%, repeat hemoglobin A1c and blood work including kidney function ordered

A (Assessment):

* Esophageal narrowing or stricture causing dysphagia, suspected
* Diabetes mellitus, stable control
* Hypertension, stable control

P (Plan):

* Referral to gastroenterology for esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) to evaluate swallowing difficulty
* Start Prilosec (omeprazole) 20 mg once daily for possible reflux contributing to symptoms
* Advise thorough chewing of solid foods, especially meats, to prevent choking or food impaction
* Educate patient on emergency signs requiring urgent care if choking occurs
* Continue metformin 500 mg twice daily
* Order repeat hemoglobin A1c and additional blood tests including kidney function
* Provide referral to ophthalmology for diabetic eye screening
* Continue Norvasc (amlodipine) for hypertension; send prescription refill to pharmacy
* Schedule follow-up visit in 1 month for test result review and management adjustment if needed
* Instruct patient to contact office with worsening symptoms or concerns, or seek emergency care if choking occurs

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right ankle injury with pain and swelling on the outside
* History of present illness: Twisted and rolled right ankle landing awkwardly while playing basketball with son, difficulty walking, feeling unstable on the ankle, bruising and swelling noted laterally, recent good exercise routine disrupted
* Social history: Works from home, volunteers as a basketball coach starting in April
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Swelling on the lateral side of right ankle, exquisite tenderness laterally, some tenderness over medial deltoid region, skin intact without epidermolysis, brisk capillary refill, no malalignment, unable to walk on ankle due to pain and instability, able to stand on it
* Test results: Right ankle X-ray (AP, lateral, oblique views) showing displaced lateral malleolus fracture at Weber C level, no medial or posterior malleolar fractures

A (Assessment):

* Lateral malleolar fracture of the right ankle
* Fracture considered unstable based on displacement and location

P (Plan):

* Surgery recommended with open reduction and internal fixation using plate and screws due to instability
* Prescribe meloxicam for swelling and pain management
* Advise icing and elevating the ankle regularly; patient able to elevate ankle at home due to working from home
* Provide crutches for non-weight bearing mobility
* Anticipated recovery and activity restriction period approximately three months
* Encourage continuation of coaching role during recovery
* Discussed limitations on physical activity including walking dogs; patient to arrange assistance from family or others

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Stabbing, shooting, excruciating pain in the right cheek bone area of the face
* History of present illness: Pain present for 2-3 months, comes on slowly, occurs in episodes lasting a few minutes up to an hour, triggered by certain temperatures (hot or cold) and wind, no associated numbness or tingling noticed, no facial weakness or visual changes, occasional non-migraine headaches not related to this pain
* Past medical history: No history of multiple sclerosis or brain tumors
* Medications tried: Ibuprofen, Motrin, tiger balm with no relief
* Pain severity: 10/10 during episodes

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Normal symmetric smile and eye movement, hearing intact bilaterally, decreased sensation to cotton touch and dull needle sensation on the right side of the face compared to left
* Test results: MRI shows small blood vessel abutting and possibly compressing the trigeminal nerve

A (Assessment):

* Trigeminal neuralgia, suspected due to nerve compression from vascular contact

P (Plan):

* Start carbamazepine (Tegretol) with genetic testing to assess risk for adverse skin reactions especially in patients of East Asian descent
* Monitor for side effects including memory loss, tingling, imbalance, and dermatologic reactions
* Follow-up appointment in 1 month to assess treatment response
* Discuss surgical options if medication is ineffective

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right knee injury with pain and instability
- History of present illness: Fell while skiing in Vermont last weekend after catching ski coming off the lift, heard a pop in right knee, immediate pain, unable to bear weight, required ski patrol assistance; pain primarily on the outside (lateral) of the knee, feelings of the knee not holding weight and buckling, decreased ability to bend and straighten the knee due to pain, no numbness or tingling in toes
- Past medical history: Generally healthy, no hypertension or diabetes
- Social history: Active lifestyle involving chasing twins aged four years, currently using crutches, husband provides some but limited support due to work schedule
- Medications: Taking ibuprofen for pain with some relief

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Right knee shows edema and effusion, tenderness on palpation of right lateral knee, decreased flexion and extension, positive Lachman sign, palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, no ankle edema; heart exam with regular rate and rhythm, no murmur; lungs clear to auscultation
- Test results: Right knee X-ray shows no bony abnormality

A (Assessment):

- Suspected right anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) rupture
- Need to rule out associated structural damage in the right knee

P (Plan):

- Order right knee MRI to confirm ACL status and evaluate for other injuries
- Continue ibuprofen 600-800 mg orally every 8 hours as needed for pain
- Apply knee brace for support
- Plan follow-up visit after MRI results to discuss further management
- Patient education provided about injury and plans

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Neck pain following multiple car crashes
* History of present illness: Patient involved in multiple car crashes; after the most recent crash in February of this year, started experiencing sharp, incapacitating neck pain rated 12/10 on pain scale; associated symptoms include occasional dizziness, headaches, numbness in left arm and right leg, body spasms, stiffness, and fatigue since the accident; unable to work due to pain
* Past medical history: Previous therapy for neck and back pain, surgery after third crash, prior fentanyl prescription which has not been refilled for several weeks
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Tenderness on palpation over midline bony processes and lateral neck muscles, moderate limited range of neck motion especially with flexion and extension due to pain, no visible bruising or swelling noted on exam today
* Test results: Recent neck x-ray showed no fractures

A (Assessment):

* Neck sprain
* Need for MRI to evaluate for possible fractures or soft tissue injury as per physician’s assessment

P (Plan):

* Order cervical spine MRI for thorough imaging evaluation
* Advise icing of neck if bruising or swelling occurs
* Provide prescribed Robaxin (methocarbamol) 1500 mg every 6 to 8 hours to relieve muscle tension and pain
* Provide neck exercises sheet to perform daily for gentle movement restoration
* Recommend use of heat pad or topical analgesics (e.g., Biofreeze, IcyHot) if muscle pain persists
* Refer to physical therapy following MRI results
* Consider referral to pain specialist for possible local injections if pain persists or worsens
* Patient advised time off work until further evaluation based on MRI findings and symptom improvement

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Annual exam visit
* History of present illness: Doing well overall, traveling and hiking actively; no chest pain, shortness of breath, or leg swelling noticed; nasal congestion due to fall pollen and allergies; no nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain
* Past medical history: Congestive heart failure, depression, hypertension
* Social history: Engages in hiking and travel; work involves long hours and stress, especially during fiscal year-end data responsibilities
* Depression status: Enrolled in weekly therapy for one year, reports improvement, no suicidal or homicidal ideation
* Medication adherence: Good compliance with congestive heart failure medications, still forgetting to take blood pressure medication

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure elevated today and persistently high in recent past readings
* Physical exam: Heart exam reveals a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur (previously noted); one-plus pitting edema in lower extremities; remainder of exam normal
* Test results: Echocardiogram (from last year) shows left ventricular ejection fraction approximately 45%, presence of mitral regurgitation; lipid panel (from last year) with slightly elevated cholesterol

A (Assessment):

* Congestive heart failure
* Depression, stable on therapy without medication
* Hypertension, uncontrolled

P (Plan):

* Increase lisinopril dose to 40 mg daily
* Start furosemide (Lasix) 20 mg daily
* Continue low sodium diet
* Repeat echocardiogram
* Monitor daily blood pressure at home and record readings for one week to assess need for additional antihypertensive therapy
* Schedule mammogram for annual screening
* Patient education: Allowed to take all medications at the same time daily with an alarm to improve adherence
* Continue current depression treatment without medication change

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Joint pain in both knees
* History of present illness: Onset over the weekend after moving boxes up and down basement stairs; knees equally painful; no specific injury but history of knee problems; pain severe enough to cause difficulty sleeping on Saturday night; mild intermittent elbow pain; no fever, chills, muscle aches, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea
* Past medical history: Kidney transplant for polycystic kidneys, hypothyroidism, arthritis
* Medications: Taking immunosuppressive medications and Synthroid regularly
* Review of systems: No additional symptoms including no headaches or other joint pain beyond knees and occasional elbow pain
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Within normal limits, afebrile
* Physical exam: Heart exam reveals 2/6 systolic ejection murmur stable from previous; right knee shows edema, erythema, tenderness to palpation, and decreased range of motion; left knee appears normal
* Test results: Right knee X-ray shows good bony alignment, no acute fracture; laboratory results show normal white blood cell count, good kidney function

A (Assessment):

* Acute exacerbation of arthritis causing bilateral knee pain
* Hypothyroidism, stable on treatment

P (Plan):

* Prescribe Ultram 50 mg every six hours as needed for knee pain
* Order autoimmune panel
* Order thyroid panel
* Advise patient to rest and limit activity for now
* If symptoms persist, consider further imaging and referral to physical therapy
* Continue Synthroid as currently prescribed
* Monitor arthritis symptoms given limitation on anti-inflammatory medications due to kidney transplant status

* Chief complaint: Back pain similar to pain experienced during kidney stones two years ago

* Medication adherence: Diligent use of Imitrex for migraines, currently on Protonix 40 mg daily for reflux but needs a refill
* Social history: Increased take-out and fast food consumption due to pain limiting ability to go out; reports adequate hydration
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Elevated blood pressure (exact value not provided)
* Physical exam: Right costovertebral angle tenderness; right lower quadrant abdominal tenderness; heart and lungs clear on auscultation
* Test results: Slightly elevated creatinine suggesting possible obstruction; abdominal x-ray indicates possible kidney stone in lower abdomen (official read pending)

A (Assessment):

* Recurrence of kidney stones, suspected
* Migraines, stable on current treatment
* Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), stable on Protonix

P (Plan):

* Order CT scan without contrast of abdomen and pelvis
* Prescribe Ultram 50 mg every six hours as needed for pain
* Encourage increased fluid intake and straining of urine
* Continue Imitrex for migraines
* Refill Protonix 40 mg daily for reflux
* Nurse to assist with scheduling CT scan
* Follow-up planned in 1-2 days with instructions to call if symptoms worsen

S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Back pain after golfing injury
- History of present illness: Sustained back injury during backswing while golfing 4 days ago with immediate popping sensation and severe pain requiring to lie down; pain loosened somewhat by Monday but remains sore; experienced right foot drop and right leg weakness that has slightly improved this morning; able to walk slowly with some limitation; tried acetaminophen, ibuprofen, ice, and heat without significant relief
- Past medical history: Congestive heart failure, type 2 diabetes, lumbar spine surgery approximately 10 years ago
- Social history: No specific information provided regarding tobacco, alcohol, or drug use
- Family history: No information provided
- Other symptoms: No leg numbness or tingling besides described weakness; no problems with lying flat at night; no new symptoms reported

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Normal, stable
- Physical exam: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur stable from previous exam; lumbar spine pain on palpation at L5 level; decreased lumbar flexion and extension range of motion; positive straight leg raise test; right lower extremity strength 4/5, left 5/5
- Test results: Lumbar spine x-ray normal with good bony alignment and no abnormalities; recent hemoglobin A1c elevated at 8%

A (Assessment):

- Acute lumbar strain
- Congestive heart failure, status stable
- Type 2 diabetes mellitus with suboptimal glycemic control (HbA1c 8%)

P (Plan):

- Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg orally once daily for back pain
- Refer to physical therapy for lumbar strengthening
- Order MRI of lumbar spine if symptoms persist to evaluate for disc herniation
- Increase metformin dosage to 1,000 mg twice daily
- Order repeat hemoglobin A1c in 2 months
- Continue current medications for congestive heart failure (lisinopril and furosemide)
- Refill lisinopril 20 mg once daily
- Schedule follow-up visit in 2 weeks

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Fatigue and dizziness over the past couple of months  
- History of present illness: Increasing tiredness even with mild activity such as walking a mile or going to work, no blood in stools currently, no black or tarry stools, no heavy menstrual bleeding, no passing out episodes, no weight loss or loss of appetite, mild nasal congestion attributed to seasonal allergies  
- Past medical history: Congestive heart failure, kidney stones, prior colonoscopy 3 years ago with findings of mild diverticulosis  
- Social history: Recent travel with increased sodium intake, difficulty managing salt intake  
- Review of systems: No fever, chills, sore throat, cough, or other symptoms reported  

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Normal blood pressure and heart rate  
- Physical exam: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur on heart exam, trace to 1+ pitting edema in ankles  
- Test results: Echocardiogram (6 months ago) showing left ventricular ejection fraction about 45%, moderate mitral regurgitation; Hemoglobin 8.2 g/dL (low)  

A (Assessment):

- Anemia, new onset  
- Congestive heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and moderate mitral regurgitation  
- Kidney stones, stable, no recent flare-ups  

P (Plan):

- Order anemia profile labs to characterize anemia  
- Refer to gastroenterology for evaluation including likely endoscopy and repeat colonoscopy  
- Start Lasix (furosemide) 40 mg once daily  
- Continue Toprol (metoprolol) 50 mg daily and Lisinopril 10 mg daily  
- Counsel on strict salt restriction, daily weight monitoring, and instruction to call if weight increases  
- Advise continued hydration and dietary monitoring for kidney stones with instructions to report any symptoms  
- Follow-up as needed with physician and gastroenterology

S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Blood sugar not under control  
* History of present illness: Patient has been monitoring blood sugar at home and noticed levels creeping up, running in the 300's; diet unchanged, mainly sugar intake from fruit; no fever or chills; right knee joint pain without known injury; nausea a couple of days ago related to motion sickness; no urinary burning; history of reflux improved with Protonix; no recent weight gain or fluid retention; prefers to sleep on side but sleeps flat; right rotator cuff pain improved

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Enlarged thyroid; heart regular rhythm; lungs clear; abdomen soft; right knee with erythema, insect bite, fluctuance; right lower extremity edema

P (Plan):

* Prescribe amoxicillin 500 mg orally three times daily for 10 days, complete full course

* Monitor symptoms and follow-up as needed  
* Patient education about infections possibly contributing to elevated blood sugar

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Routine follow-up for chronic problems including depression, asthma, and diabetes
* History of present illness: Managing depression with intermittent symptoms, asthma worsened during recent bad pollen season causing shortness of breath especially when temperature exceeds 85 degrees, diabetes generally controlled but diet recently disrupted due to travel and eating on the go with junk food, occasional lightheadedness and dizziness attributed to heat and fatigue, mild knee pain from activity, exercises by biking 45 minutes in the morning
* Past medical history: Depression, asthma, diabetes
* Medications reported: Previously on Prozac 20 mg daily for depression, self-weaned off recently
* Social history: No specific details provided about tobacco, alcohol, or drug use
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: No apparent distress, no cervical lymphadenopathy, thyroid not enlarged, faint bilateral expiratory wheezing on lung auscultation, regular heart rate and rhythm, soft abdomen, no lower extremity edema
* Test results: Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) described as good, Hemoglobin A1c elevated indicating suboptimal blood sugar control, chest x-ray normal with no evidence of pneumonia

A (Assessment):

* Asthma, stable with summer exacerbations
* Diabetes mellitus with recent poor glycemic control
* Depression, ongoing with recent medication discontinuation, willing to try alternative medication

P (Plan):

* Increase metformin to 1,000 mg twice daily for diabetes management
* Repeat Hemoglobin A1c testing in 3 months
* Continue home blood sugar monitoring
* Asthma management: continue albuterol inhaler 2 puffs every 4-6 hours as needed, add Symbicort 2 puffs twice daily during summer months to prevent exacerbations
* Depression treatment: start sertraline (Zoloft) 25 mg once daily and monitor tolerance
* Arrange nursing support for medication initiation and patient education
* Follow-up as per routine care schedule

[patient] yes . yes , i have eczema .

[doctor] okay . well , my impression is that you- you probably have a contusion , but let's take a look at your x-ray first . hey , dragon . show me the x-ray . yeah , so if you look at this , this is a normal femur . um , really do n't see any evidence of a fracture or any swelling , so it's essentially , a normal x-ray . so , what we're going to do is , i'm going to start you on um an anti-inflammatory . it's going to be mobic 15 milligrams uh , once a day . i want you to use some ice for the pain , um , and it should , honestly , just being a contusion , get better in the next week or so . if it's not getting better , of course , come on back and- and see me .

S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Pain in the top part of the right leg
- History of present illness: Injured right upper leg while bowling by accidentally hitting the leg with the bowling ball, followed by a fall; mild bruising on the back side of the leg, no significant swelling noted; pain severe enough to limit walking, able to walk only carefully; avoids stairs due to pain
- Past medical history: Atopic eczema

- Vital signs: No information provided

A (Assessment):

- Contusion of the right upper leg, suspected

P (Plan):

- Advise use of ice for pain management
- Patient education: Expected improvement within approximately one week; return if symptoms do not improve

* Family history: No information provided

* Proximal humerus fracture

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Weight gain, acne, foot swelling, constipation
* History of present illness: Patient reports no new issues since last visit, unable to start prescribed thyroid medication due to cost, currently taking old thyroid medicine; concerns about weight gain possibly related to previous birth control use; sensitive skin prone to rashes from various products; feet swell frequently; experiences constipation; interested in weight loss options including study participation; inquires about supplements such as CLA, chromium, and amino acids for metabolism and weight loss; has started vitamin D supplementation but missed today's dose; plans to resume gym in July after contract hold; no medication allergies

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Lungs and heart auscultation normal; feet and ankles examined with no acute swelling or abnormal findings observed at this time
* Test results: 
  - Dexamethasone suppression test normal (rules out Cushing’s syndrome)
  - Salivary cortisol tests 2 normal, 1 abnormal; may require retesting
  - Cholesterol panel: Total cholesterol 222 mg/dL (high), HDL 44 mg/dL (low), LDL 153 mg/dL (high), non-HDL cholesterol 178 mg/dL (high)
  - Diabetes screening normal
  - Vitamin D deficiency confirmed; vitamin D supplementation started
  - Liver enzymes markedly improved: ALT decreased from 254 (Oct) to 128 (Jan) to 30 (current)
  - Pituitary hormones and iron levels within normal ranges
  - Androgen levels normal, no hyperandrogenism detected

A (Assessment):

* Abnormal liver enzymes, improved after discontinuation of birth control medication
* Weight gain, no endocrine cause identified; Cushing’s syndrome ruled out
* Hirsutism, androgen levels normal
* Acne vulgaris
* Hyperthyroidism, receiving thyroid hormone therapy (Unithroid)

P (Plan):

* Prescriptions printed for thyroid medication (Unithroid) with discount card to reduce cost; patient advised to shop around at pharmacies
* Started topical antibiotic clindamycin plus benzoyl peroxide gel for acne; patient advised to apply at night to avoid sun reaction and bleaching of fabrics
* Encouraged low-carb, low-cholesterol diet; advised to avoid alcohol and fatty foods
* Continue vitamin D supplementation at 2000 IU daily after completion of current dose to maintain levels
* Monitor liver enzymes and thyroid levels with repeat labs before next visit
* Advised weight loss; patient informed about upcoming weight loss medication study involving weekly injections and potential side effects; patient opted to wait before participating
* Advised to inform doctor if foot swelling worsens or recurs
* Recommended MiraLAX for constipation; patient already has prescription
* Discussed alternative birth control (Phexxi) after discontinuation of prior contraceptive; available upon request
* Will provide discount samples and order labs for follow-up visit

[doctor] this is philip gutierrez , date of birth 1/12/71 . he is a 50-year-old male here for a second opinion regarding the index finger on the right hand . he had a hyperextension injury of that index finger during a motor vehicle accident in march of this year . he was offered an injection of the a1 polyregion , but did not want any steroid because of the reaction to dexamethasone , which causes his heart to race . he was scheduled to see dr. alice davis , which it does n't appear he did . he had an mri of that finger , because there was concern about a capsular strain plus or minus rupture of , quote , " fds tendon , " end quote . he has been seen at point may orthopedics largely by the physical therapy staff and a pr , pa at that institution .
[doctor] at that practice , an mri was obtained on 4/24/2021 , which showed just focal soft tissue swelling over the right index mcp joint , partial-thickness tear of the right fds , and fluid consistent with tenosynovitis around the fdp and fds tendons . radial and ulnar collateral ligaments of the index mcp joint were intact , as the mcp joint capsule . extensor tendons also deemed intact .
[doctor] his x-rays , four views of the right hand today , show no bony abnormalities , joint congruency throughout all lesser digits on the right hand , no soft tissue shadows of concern , no arthritis . hi , how are you , mr . gutierrez ?
[patient] i'm good , how about you ?
[doctor] well , how can i help you today ?
[patient] so i was a passenger in , uh , a car that was rear-ended , and we were hit multiple times . i felt two bumps , which slung me forward and caused me to stretch out my right index finger .
[doctor] so hitting the car in front of you all made that finger go backwards ?
[patient] um , i do n't really know . i just felt , like , it felt like i laid on my finger , and so , i felt like it went back , and it's been hurting since about march . and it's been like that ever , ever since the wreck happened . so i , and i ca n't make a fist , but sometimes the pain's unbearable . and , like , even driving hurts .
[doctor] okay , so this was march of this year , so maybe about three months ago ?
[patient] yeah , and it's still swollen . so i was seeing , uh , an orthopedist , and they sent me to an occupational therapist . and i've been doing therapy with them , and then they sent me to go back and get an mri . so i went and got the mri . uh , then they told me that the mri came back , and it said i had a tear in my finger , but he was n't gon na give me an injection , because the injection was going to make the tear worse .
[doctor] mm-hmm .
[patient] and then , after he got the mri , he said that i have , uh , a tear in my finger , and that he did n't wan na do surgery , but he would do an injection . then i'm thinking that you told me you would n't do an injection in there , and then the oper- , occupational therapy says it's because of the tear . and then , they do n't want me to keep rubbing the thing , and doing things with my hand . so i feel like i'm not getting medical care , really .
[doctor] yeah , i see that .
[patient] so i came to see if you could do anything for this hand , because i am right-handed , and i kinda need that hand .
[doctor] what do you do for a living ?
[patient] uh , i'm an x-ray tech .
[doctor] well , um , so do you have any diabetes or rheumatoid arthritis ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] uh , do you take any chronic medications of su- , significance ?
[patient] uh , i do take a blood pressure pill , and that's it .
[doctor] okay , and it looks like you suffer from itching with the methylprednisolone ?
[patient] uh , that's correct .
[doctor] all right , well , i'm gon na scoot up closer and just take a quick look at your hand . all right , so , lean over here . all right , so on this exam today , we have a very pleasant , cooperative , healthy male , no distress . his heart rate is regular rate , rhythm , 2+ radial pulse , no swelling or bruise , bruising in the palm over the volar surface of his index finger , normal creases , slightly diminished over the pip of the index finger compared to the middle finger .
[doctor] his index finger rests in a 10-degree pip-flexed , uh , position . all right , is that uncomfortable to correct that , and is it uncomfortable now here ?
[patient] yeah , uh , when you push on it , yeah .
[doctor] all right , how about here ?
[patient] um , there , it's not .
[doctor] okay , not as bad ?
[patient] yeah , it feels , uh , a little numb .
[doctor] gotcha , all right . bend , bend the tip of this finger . bend it as hard as you can . keep bending . keep bending . all right , straighten it out . all right , and now , bend it for me as best you can .
[patient] my goodness . it feels like it's , it's tearing in there .
[doctor] okay , okay . well , bend the tip of this finger , and bend it as hard as you can . keep bending . all right , straighten that out , and now , bend it for me as best you can . all right , good . now , bend that finger , and i'm going to pull , put it down like this . and then bend that finger for me . okay , sorry , can you bend it for me ? all right . now , make a fist . great , so relax the finger . all right , so just keep it , keep , when i bend the finger , we're just going to bend that finger where it meets the hand . is that okay there ?
[patient] ow , .
[doctor] okay , okay . so all the hurt , it seems , is stretching , because you have n't been doing this for so long . so , you know what i mean ? so , um , you're going to have to start really doing that .
[patient] well , i've tried . i even bought myself a splint .
[doctor] well , but a splint does n't help move you . it actually immobilizes you .
[patient] okay . i thought it would straighten it out .
[doctor] no , no . so , so you really need to start bending the finger right here for me , as hard as you can , and keep going , going . all right , so , so you're okay . all right , so i would say the following , that there is a partial tear in one of the two flexor tendons . there is the fdp and the fds , and the fds is the least important of the two . so the mri shows that it's the fds , the flexor digitorum superficialis , which is the least important of the two .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] uh , now , there's two halves of it . so it's a partial tear of one half of a whole tendon . that's not that important , and the other one is just fine .
[patient] so the good one is good ?
[doctor] yes , correct . so the one that goes all the way to the tip is good .
[patient] okay , good .
[doctor] yeah , so you know , i think what you have got so much scar tissue and inflammation around the fds tendon blocking excursion of these other tendons , that they ca n't get through to the pulley .
[patient] okay , all right .
[doctor] so what i would recommend what we try is a cortisone injection , and i would avoid the dexamethasone , because i saw you have a little reaction to that . but we could use the betamethasone , which is a celestone .
[patient] i've gotten another , uh , methylprednisolone , and that itched me like crazy .
[doctor] did it ? yeah , this one is water-soluble , and i think it's fairly low toxicity , but high benefit , and i think decreasing the pain will encourage you to move that finger .
[patient] all right , we'll give it a try .
[doctor] good . so , you do the shot , and it's going to take about three to five days before it starts feeling better . and then probably over the next couple of weeks , it'll start feeling even better .
[patient] perfect .
[doctor] all right , so take advantage of that . you've got ta start moving the finger . you're not going to tear anything or break a bone , uh , because your intensors , extensors are intact . but your collateral ligaments are intact , so you've got a stiff , sore finger . i'm going to try to help as much as i can with this soreness part , and then you have to do all the stiff part .
[patient] the lady in occupational therapy tried some maneuvers to straighten the finger out , but it even hurt after i left . the whole thing just swelled up .
[doctor] hmm . okay , so it was injured , and you had scar tissue . and then , you had post-traumatic inflammation . and so , this will help some with all of that . it's not going to make it to where your finger is like , , my finger does n't hurt at all , but it will make it to where at least tolerable , to where you can make some gains . and we actually might need to repeat this as well .
[patient] will i be able to drive ? i drove myself here today , so ...
[doctor] yeah , it may feel a little weird , but it's totally safe for you to drive .
[patient] okay , good .
[doctor] so for mr . gutierrez , just put that he has a post-traumatic rather severe stenosing tenosynovitis of his right index finger , and the plan is steroid injection today , do a trigger injection , but i'm using a cc of betamethasone . so , mr . gutierrez , do you have , um , therapy scheduled or set up ?
[patient] uh , not at the moment .
[doctor] all right , well , i mean , you know that you need to move that finger , and i think to the degree that they can help you do that . so i want you to move that finger , finger , but i think it would be , uh , beneficial for you to have an accountability , um , so at least you know to check in with them once a week with somebody .
[patient] um , okay . that's kinda why i'm here , for you to tell me what needs to be done , you know ?
[doctor] yeah , so i'll write you out , um , an outpatient prescription . i think if you go back to the same people where you were before , i'm hoping that after this injection , you're going to be able to do a whole lot more with them . so let's do outpatient once a week for six weeks , um , and then full active and passive range of motion is the goal with no restrictions .
[patient] all right , sounds like a plan .
[doctor] all right , well , i will have the nurse set up the injection procedure , and we'll , and i'll be back shortly .
[patient] thanks , doc .
[doctor] right trigger finger injection template . attempted to inject one cc of celestone with f- , a half a cc of lidocaine . however , the patient had a dramatic and violent painful reaction to the introduction of the needle , with contortions of the hand , and with dangerously withdrawing the hand with concerns for secondary needle stick . needle was withdrawn . the patient was counseled as to the importance of attempting to get some therapeutic steroid in the flexor tendon sheath . we attempted a second time for a similar injection using the same technique with one cc of celestone and half a cc of lidocaine . a small parma- , uh , palmar vein bled a scant amount , which was cleaned up and band-aid applied . reassured on multiple occasions that no harm was done to his finger . recommended icing in it this evening , and taking ibuprofen .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Pain and inability to make a fist with the right index finger after a hyperextension injury in a motor vehicle accident about three months ago
- History of present illness: Injury occurred in March due to hyperextension during a car accident; persistent swelling and pain since then; unable to make a fist; pain sometimes unbearable, worsens with finger movement and driving; previous occupational therapy and MRI performed; patient hesitant about steroid injection due to prior reaction to dexamethasone; tried splint without improvement; complains of numbness and swelling post-therapy
- Past medical history: Hypertension treated with blood pressure medication, no diabetes or rheumatoid arthritis
- Allergies/adverse reactions: Itching reaction to methylprednisolone, heart racing with dexamethasone
- Social history: Works as an x-ray technician; drives
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No specific data provided
- Physical exam: Pleasant, cooperative man, no distress; heart rate regular; 2+ radial pulse; no swelling or bruising except bruising over volar surface of right index finger; normal creases but slightly diminished over PIP joint of index finger; index finger resting in 10-degree PIP flexion; tenderness upon pressure over PIP joint area; numbness reported at one location; limited bending of finger tip with pain described as tearing sensation; extensor tendons intact; collateral ligaments intact; no deformity or bony abnormalities
- Test results: MRI (4/24/2021) showed focal soft tissue swelling over right index MCP joint, partial-thickness tear of the right flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS) tendon, fluid consistent with tenosynovitis around flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) and FDS tendons; radial and ulnar collateral ligaments and MCP joint capsule intact; extensor tendons intact; X-rays of right hand showed no bony abnormalities, preserved joint congruency, no soft tissue shadows of concern, no arthritis
- Procedure notes: Attempted trigger finger injection twice with 1 cc betamethasone (Celestone) and 0.5 cc lidocaine; first attempt aborted due to violent painful reaction and hand withdrawal; second attempt successful with minor palmar vein bleeding; patient reassured; recommended icing and ibuprofen

A (Assessment):

- Post-traumatic rather severe stenosing tenosynovitis of the right index finger
- Partial-thickness tear of the right flexor digitorum superficialis tendon
- Previous corticosteroid reaction with methylprednisolone (itching) and dexamethasone (tachycardia)

P (Plan):

- Administer corticosteroid injection with betamethasone (Celestone) avoiding dexamethasone due to prior reaction
- Recommend starting active and passive range of motion exercises for right index finger as tolerated to improve mobility and reduce stiffness
- Outpatient occupational therapy once weekly for six weeks with focus on range of motion goals and accountability support
- Advise icing after injection and use of ibuprofen for pain and inflammation control
- Counsel patient that the injection effect will begin in 3–5 days with improvement over following weeks; possibility of repeat injection if needed
- Reinforce safety of driving post-injection despite possible discomfort
- Follow-up appointment after therapy course or as needed based on progress

[patient] stable .

[doctor] yeah , i've heard of it but i have n't had anybody consistently use it . i mean , your levels are fine and we checked your estra- estradiol and it was not elevated , so .
[patient] okay .

[doctor] well , your levels are high .

[doctor] okay .
[patient] so i'm due to dose on thursday or friday .
[doctor] all right .
[patient] i have a little med calendar and i put checks and ts on it . that helps me .
[doctor] that's a great idea . so look , the biggest issue i've seen , even if your levels today are around 700 , is that your peaks are getting greater than 1,500 , putting you at a higher chance of needing to come off due to blood thickness . and your risk will only astronomically go up the higher the dose that we go on .

[doctor] you look well , your levels are good and you're feeling well .

[patient] yeah , they have to be taking a lot .

[patient] and they are taking stuff for a long time .
[doctor] true . but right now i would not change your dose .
[patient] okay .

[doctor] okay .

[doctor] for all of them ?
[patient] sure .
[doctor] all right , will do . i'm gon na get your prescriptions .
[patient] okay , thank you .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Hypogonadism, gynecomastia concern
- History of present illness: HIV positive male on testosterone therapy (1 milliliter every 10 days), initial testosterone levels less than 300, currently reports feeling good, more vigorous, sleeping well, no notable change in muscle mass or weight, adherent to medications (finasteride half a pill 5 mg, daily Cialis 2.5 to 5 mg depending on workout days), interested in adjusting testosterone dose to 175 mg from 140 mg; patient notes significant improvement in cholesterol and triglycerides since starting testosterone 5 months ago
- Past medical history: HIV positive
- Social history: No specific information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Heart and lung auscultation normal with no concerns
- Test results: Last PSA 0.66 ng/mL (current 0.6), last testosterone >1500 ng/dL at peak, current testosterone levels around 700 ng/dL on eighth day post-injection, triglycerides decreased from 265 mg/dL to 145 mg/dL after testosterone therapy, estradiol levels normal (not elevated), red blood cell count increased but stable

A (Assessment):

- Hypogonadism
- Gynecomastia, discussed with patient
- No suspicion or diagnosis explicitly stated regarding cholesterol or estrogen abnormalities

P (Plan):

- Continue testosterone replacement therapy at current dose without increase due to risk of elevated peak levels causing blood thickness and cardiovascular complications
- Continue finasteride 2.5 mg daily (half a 5 mg pill)
- Continue Cialis 2.5 mg to 5 mg daily depending on activity
- Annual monitoring of PSA and testosterone levels
- No current indication for estradiol re-testing until fall unless clinically indicated
- Prescriptions for finasteride and Cialis to be provided via paper script at patient’s preferred pharmacy (Walmart)
- Continue patient education on medication adherence and risks of high-dose testosterone use

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Post bilateral reduction mammoplasty follow-up, concerns about scar irritation  
- History of present illness: Underwent bilateral reduction mammoplasty on 10-10 20-20; previously noted lump under left breast in March (felt by PA but not felt since, improved with massage); scar widening on left breast causing irritation; no chills, fever, nausea, vomiting; back pain resolved  
- Social history: No new issues, enjoying summertime  
- Family history: No information provided  
- Past medical history: No additional information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Incisions well healed on both breasts, no signs of infection or redness, scars on left breast slightly widened and under high tension, no palpable lumps noted during current exam  
- Test results: No lab or imaging results provided  

A (Assessment):

- Post bilateral reduction mammoplasty healing well  
- Scar widening on left breast, mild irritation  
- Palpable lump under left breast previously noted, likely scar tissue  

P (Plan):

- Continue Mederma scar gel twice daily on scars  
- Continue massage of scar tissue  
- Re-evaluate scars and consider revision surgery to excise and reclose area if irritation persists after six months  
- Obtain photographs today for documentation and monitoring  
- Schedule follow-up visit in six months to reassess  
- No revision surgery before one year post-operation

transcription:
[doctor] next patient is nicole miller . date of birth is 09/18/1949 . patient was called for a follow-up with me for chronic congestive heart failure with diastolic dysfunction . bmp's been , uh , 3,000 in march , and is about six- was up to 6,000 in april . she was increasingly dyspneic . we changed her furosemide and torsemide 20 milligrams by mouth daily . uh to note , the patient is not currently on potassium supplement . her lisinopril had- has also been increased up to 10 milligrams daily in march . also did when i saw her last april . she reported being interested in having her right knee replaced this summer at east metro . it was recommended that we work to control her cardiovascular status before surgery .
[doctor] hey , miss miller , how are you today ?
[patient] i'm doing okay , thank you .
[doctor] i asked you to come in today because we want to keep- we want you to have this knee surgery this summer but we want to keep a close eye on you to make sure a week before your surgery you do n't suddenly go into congestive heart failure and it gets postponed .
[patient] yeah , that would not be good .
[doctor] i see you're scheduled on the 24th for surgery .
[patient] yeah , that's right .
[doctor] okay , good . well it looks like you have lost about 3 , 3 and a half pounds since i saw you last in april . some of that might be water weight , but still , this is positive .
[patient] yeah , i noticed that too . i think the oxyglutinine is helping as well . my urgency to use the bathroom is much better .
[doctor] well that's great .
[patient] yeah , i , i'm pleased about it too .
[doctor] you ever get leg or finger cramps or anything like that ?
[patient] yeah , i had leg cramps the other day , but i thought it might , was maybe just because i was cold as i had my ceiling fan on and fell asleep . i had cramps when i woke up in both legs right here . um i drank pickle juice and it went right away .
[doctor] well do n't , do n't get crazy with the pickle juice because all of the salt in it .
[patient] haha , i know , i only drink about 4 ounces or so .
[doctor] okay good .
[patient] um it went away so i did n't drink anymore . i find it works a lot better than trying to put some cream on my leg .
[doctor] sure just , just keep it in moderation .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] and then are you still on an iron supplement ? and are you using the bathroom okay ?
[patient] uh yes , everything is good .
[doctor] good . how is your heart burn doing ? any problems with that ?
[patient] no , it did get bad for a while so i tried to take some prilosec and then stopped that other one .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] um i did that for like , gosh , i think it was two weeks back in january and have n't had any problems since .
[doctor] great .
[patient] um and after i stopped taking that um i went back to the stomach one , so i'm doing good now .
[doctor] okay and you're still due for a colonoscopy , correct ?
[patient] uh yeah , that's right .
[doctor] all right , let's review your blood work real quick . i checked your hemoglobin level because you have had some anemia in the past but that is still doing great .
[patient] good , that's a relief to hear .
[doctor] your potassium is 3.9 so it's holding steady on the torsemide . your creatinine was .7 not .8 so you're doing well with kidney numbers . your bun may be a tiny bit elevated at 23 which is the number we look for for dehydration sometimes the kidneys , but it's not terrible . um so when i look at your numbers as a whole i think you're tolerating the torsemide okay at the current dose . i also sent out to look at the heart failure number- i sent to look at your heart failure number . there is a test called a bmp that i was monitoring and in march it was up to 3,000 and then went up to 6,000 in april before i made the change . i'm still waiting for those results .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] all in all i think you're doing good on paper though .
[patient] what about , um what's it called , a1c ? does that show up ?
[doctor] um i do n't think i ordered it but i could . your last a1c was 5.5 in march .
[patient] all righty .
[doctor] so your blood sugar is a little bit high , it was 169 today but that kind of depends on what you ate and you were n't fasting for the blood check so i might have to repeat that test for pre-op , but i do n't think we need to do it today .
[patient] all righty that sounds good .
[doctor] i checked your magnesium level because sometimes you uh urinate out magnesium with the water pills but it was normal at 1.7 and your blood pressure is also looking good .
[patient] okay great . that all sounds awesome .
[doctor] all right let's take a quick listen .
[doctor] use my general physical exam template .
[doctor] and take a couple of deep breaths for me .
[doctor] your lungs sound pretty good to me so keep doing what you're doing . um uh , like i said , i think you're doing good overall but let's just talk about a few things .
[patient] all righty .
[doctor] so we often like to keep people with heart problems on magnesium and get their levels up to around the 2-ish range . yours is a little bit less than 2 and we want that 2-ish range because it can help stabilize the heart muscle . so i might recommend putting you on magnesium supplement . it's supposed to be twice a day so that's kind of annoying , but i know you're on other medicines twice a day too , so i think you'll do fine .
[patient] yeah , that'll be okay .
[doctor] great . now before surgery we'll have to get you off your clopidogrel for a week beforehand .
[patient] yes , okay , i have everything written down on my phone , and i have a letter taped to the side of my bed to remind me .
[doctor] perfect ! we will give you a reminder as well . we will also need to complete a pre-op check within two weeks of your surgery during the first or second week of june .

[doctor] you might also have to repeat an ekg before surgery which we could do today . i know i'm sure it feels like you're doing , you're always doing ekgs . um we do n't need to any x-rays of your chest because you had one recently , and we do n't need any more blood work because we did that today .

[patient] yeah , i have both .

[patient] okay , well my husband's insurance may be running out . might we be able to get the procedure done sooner ? maybe in the next 30 days ? is that okay ?
[doctor] um i can put it in right now for , uh , for county for the next 30 days , and they might be able to get you in within the next few weeks . it should not take , it should not make you ineligible for the surgery . in other words completing a colonoscopy would not delay your surgery .
[patient] okay , good .
[doctor] so let me see . i've been doing one of two things at every one , and everyone is great so it depends more on timing availability of their or for the colonoscopy . we can send you to dr. martin for the surgery who is at county surgical services down here or the other option is valley medical , and they do it at springfield .
[patient] okay , that sounds good .
[doctor] i think either direction they're good technicians of the colon .
[patient] okay , yeah whatever you can get me in , that works great .
[doctor] so i'll call around . now if you get that done and they tell you 10 years then you'll be good to go .
[patient] great , thank you .
[doctor] you're welcome . have a great day . let us know if you need anything else , okay ?
[patient] sounds good .
[doctor] all right , assessment and plan .
[doctor] chronic chf . mixed presentation . had a exacerbation of cf , chf earlier in the spring . we switched her from a furosemide to torsemide and symptomatically she is doing a lot better . she's about 3 , 3 and a half pounds down in weight . breathing is non-labored . going to repeat ekg today but otherwise continue with her current regimen . labs checked and creatinine is appropriate .
[doctor] uh number 2 , pre-op examination . she is , she's having a right knee replacement end of june . also , she would like to have a colonoscopy performed which we'll try to have done at uh bartley regional , rightley regional hospital in the next month , uh , prior to a change in her insurance . this is just a screening colonoscopy that she is overdue for . no family history of colon cancer .
[doctor] uh the next one is diabetes . a1c is 5.1 on the last check so no need for further a1c today . she may need another one prior to her surgery next month though . thanks .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up for chronic congestive heart failure (CHF) with diastolic dysfunction, and planning right knee replacement surgery this summer
* History of present illness: Increasing dyspnea prior to April, improved symptoms after switching from furosemide to torsemide; lost about 3 to 3.5 pounds since last visit in April, feeling better with less urinary urgency; recent leg cramps relieved by pickle juice; no current heartburn symptoms after short trial of Prilosec in January; no problems with iron supplementation or urination
* Past medical history: Chronic CHF with diastolic dysfunction, anemia, heartburn history, iron supplementation use
* Social history: No alcohol or tobacco use mentioned
* Family history: No family history of colon cancer
* Other reported information: Interested in right knee replacement in late June; overdue for screening colonoscopy; has both Medicare and private insurance

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure stable (exact values not provided)
* Physical exam: Lungs clear on auscultation, breathing non-labored
* Test results: Hemoglobin stable, potassium 3.9 mEq/L, creatinine 0.7 mg/dL, BUN 23 mg/dL (slightly elevated), magnesium 1.7 mg/dL (normal, but below target 2.0 range), A1c 5.5 (last checked in March), non-fasting blood glucose 169 mg/dL today, BMP heart failure biomarker 3,000 in March rising to 6,000 in April, currently awaiting new result
* Imaging: Recent chest X-ray done recently, no new imaging ordered
* Other diagnostics: EKG to be repeated today prior to surgery

A (Assessment):

* Chronic congestive heart failure with mixed presentation, recent exacerbation earlier in spring
* Preoperative evaluation for right knee replacement
* Overdue screening colonoscopy, no family history of colon cancer
* Diabetes mellitus, A1c stable at 5.5, no current indication for repeat A1c today

P (Plan):

* Continue torsemide 20 mg orally daily and lisinopril 10 mg daily
* Recommend starting magnesium supplement twice daily to raise magnesium levels toward 2.0 range to support heart muscle stability
* Repeat EKG today as part of preoperative evaluation
* Obtain preoperative check within 2 weeks before surgery (early to mid-June)
* Instruct patient to stop clopidogrel one week prior to surgery; reminders to be provided
* Schedule right knee replacement surgery on June 24
* Arrange screening colonoscopy within next 30 days at local facility (Bartley Regional or other) prior to insurance changes; colonoscopy will not delay surgery
* Monitor renal function and electrolytes periodically; current creatinine and potassium stable
* No new A1c ordered today; may repeat prior to surgery based on preoperative assessment
* Educate patient on moderation of pickle juice intake due to salt content
* Follow-up as needed and ensure patient contacts clinic if any new symptoms arise or for additional instructions pre-surgery

[patient] well , right now the hand is .

[patient] and the thing started about two weeks ago . i woke up about two o'clock in the morning and it was just hurting something awful .
[doctor] uh- .
[patient] and then i laid some ice on it and it finally did ease up .
[doctor] okay , that's good .
[patient] so i got up , i sat on the side of the bed and held my arm down , thinking it would , like , help the circulation , but it did n't .
[doctor] okay , i see .
[patient] and so , after a while , when it eased off , maybe about four , five am , i laid back down and it did n't start up again .
[doctor] mm-hmm , okay .
[patient] um . i went back to sleep but for several nights this happened , like , over and over . so , i finally went to see the doctor , and i do n't really recall her name .

[patient] um , she's the one who sent me to you , so , i , i would , i would think so . but when i went to her after the third time it happened and she checked me out , she said it was most likely coming from a pinched nerve .

[doctor] and do you notice it at other times besides during the night ?

[patient] yeah .

[patient] uh , this finger , i hurt it some time ago as well .

[patient] yeah . it does n't work properly . or , it works very rarely .
[doctor] gotcha . and did i hear that she gave you some prednisone and some oral steroids , or ?

[doctor] okay . is it neuropathy ?
[patient] uh , yep .
[doctor] gotcha . that is good to know . all right , well , let's go ahead and take a look .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] all right . so , to start , i'm gon na have you do something for me . uh , just go ahead and tilt your chin as far as you can down to your chest . okay , good . and now , go the other way , tilting your chin up as far as you can . now , does that seem to bother you at all ? okay . and now , come back to normal , just look and turn your head as far as you can that way . great . and now , as far as you can towards that wall . uh , does that seem to bother you at all ?

[doctor] okay . uh , now squeeze my fingers as hard as you can with both hands . great . now , hold your arms like this .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] and i'm going to try to strain your arms and try to keep them as stiff as you can . do n't let me strain it . okay , good . good . now , when i , i'm just touching your hands like this . does it seem to feel about the same in both hands ?
[patient] uh , yes .
[doctor] okay . all right . so , i do agree with betty . uh , more than likely , this seems like it would be coming from your neck . that's the most common reason that causes what , what you're experiencing . and i looked at an x-ray of your neck , and you do seem to have a lot of arthritis there , and there does seem to be potential for a disc to be pushing on a nerve . and now , what i do n't have is an mri , which would show me , uh , kind of exactly where the nerve roots are getting pinched off .

[doctor] so , gabapentin can help a little bit with the nerve pain , and what i would like to do is potentially set you up for an epidural . and what that is is it , it's a focused anti-inflammatory medicine , excuse me , that works behind the nerve roops that , nerve roots that we are thinking might be getting squished off . it can often help alleviate your symptoms , and i do need to get an mri of your neck . um , i know we have had one of your lower back , but i need one of your neck to see exactly where the roots are getting pinched off . so , what i can do is tentatively set you up for an epidural , but before you do that , we do need to get that mri so i can see right where i need to put the medicine for your epidural . uh , what do you think of that ?

[doctor] okay .

[doctor] okay . um , so whatever you are doing you can just keep doing it , and i'm going to set you up for the epidural and imaging study , um , just so i know right where to put the medicine . and i will follow up with you after s- um , that's in . we can do the shot , just to make sure your arm is feeling better . sound good ?

[doctor] okay . s- um , so , presumably what's happening , then , is when you're sleeping your neck is kind of gets off-tilt , uh , kilter , and it compresses the nerve roots there . now , if you think you're doing fine , we could hold off , but at the very la- least , i'd like to update that mri of yours and see what's going on , because probably this is something that will likely flare up again .
[patient] yeah , it , it has been for the last week , so , i understand .
[doctor] okay . all right . well , do you want to do that work-up and do the epidural , or do you think you're doing fine and you want to wait ?
