SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Knee pain for about six months
* History of present illness: Bilateral deep, achy pain behind the kneecaps, worse with standing up from sitting and going up and down stairs; no known injury or trauma; pain partially relieved by ibuprofen, Aleve, or Tylenol but never completely pain-free except with rest; pain limits running ability from usual 5-6 miles to barely half a mile
* Past medical history: No previous knee injuries or broken bones despite being very active
* Social history: Works from home with mostly desk sitting; enjoys running regularly (5-6 miles daily); dislikes inactivity

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 120/70 mmHg, heart rate 60/min, respiratory rate 14/min
* Physical exam: Normal gait; bilateral lower extremity muscle strength 5/5 except for leg abduction at 3/5 bilaterally; no redness, bruising, swelling, or warmth in knees; no effusion; tenderness on palpation of knees; positive patellar grind test bilaterally; negative Lachman, anterior and posterior drawer, and McMurray tests bilaterally; symmetrical patellar and Achilles reflexes
* Test results: X-rays of both knees show no fractures or osteoarthritis; MRI reviewed (findings consistent with patellofemoral pain syndrome)

A (Assessment):

* Patellofemoral pain syndrome

P (Plan):

* Continue use of ibuprofen, Aleve, or other anti-inflammatory medications as needed for pain control
* Initiate physical therapy focused on lower extremity strengthening, mobility improvement, and correction of running mechanics
* Goal to gradually resume running activity
* Patient education provided; no further questions at this time

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Severe pain and bleeding
- History of present illness: Symptoms of severe pain and bleeding prompted diagnostic testing; associated constipation and weight loss; no vomiting
- Past medical history: Type 2 diabetes
- Obstetric/gynecologic history: No pregnancy, no children; menarche at age 13, menopause at age 28; no history of hormone replacement therapy; no history of endometriosis
- Family history: Unknown due to adoption
- Emotional status: Feeling depressed

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Abdomen tender to palpation in the left lower quadrant without rebound or guarding; palpable left adnexal mass on bimanual exam; no external lesions on labia; vaginal vault and cervix normal without lesions
- Test results: Abdominal CT shows a 3 cm left ovarian mass with localized lymph node involvement; no gross peritoneal or metastatic disease

A (Assessment):

- Ovarian cancer, suspected, likely stage IIIA disease based on lymph node involvement

P (Plan):

- Order blood tests including CA-125, hCG, AFP, and LDH to help characterize tumor type
- Refer for genetic counseling and testing for predisposition to ovarian cancer
- Surgical plan: Total hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, lymph node dissection including involved nodes, biopsy of any suspicious tissue for staging confirmation by pathology
- Chemotherapy plan: Postoperative chemotherapy with cisplatin and taxol; consideration of intraperitoneal chemotherapy depending on surgical findings
- Patient education: Discussed prognosis is favorable given current findings and patient’s young age and health status; awaiting final pathology for definitive staging and prognosis assessment
- Follow-up: To be determined after surgery and pathology results

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Difficulty urinating, weak urinary stream, nocturia (waking up 3-4 times per night)
- History of present illness: Urination issues ongoing for about six months, possibly longer; sensation of incomplete bladder emptying at times; no burning with urination; no urinary retention episodes; occasional diarrhea last week, likely from food
- Past medical history: Coronary artery stent placed in 2018; diabetes mellitus treated with metformin
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Heart—grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard at left base; lungs clear bilaterally; abdomen nontender, nondistended, no masses, rebound or guarding; prostate enlarged without masses on digital rectal exam
- Test results: No laboratory or imaging results yet available

A (Assessment):

- Enlarged prostate
- Coronary artery disease with known stent and possible systolic murmur, requiring follow-up
- Diabetes mellitus, stable on current treatment

P (Plan):

- Start Flomax (tamsulosin) 0.4 mg orally once daily at night to improve urinary symptoms
- Order prostate-specific antigen (PSA), urinalysis, urine culture, routine blood tests, lipid panel, and hemoglobin A1c
- Refer to urologist urgently; will attempt to schedule appointment within the week
- Order echocardiogram to evaluate heart murmur and follow-up coronary artery disease
- Continue Lipitor (atorvastatin) 40 mg daily, aspirin, and metoprolol as current cardiac medications
- Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily for diabetes
- Plan follow-up visit in 3-4 weeks; patient advised to contact physician via patient portal if concerns arise

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right foot pain
* History of present illness: Injured right foot about two days ago while playing tennis by falling on top of the foot during a volley; pain increased when trying to catch herself, unable to put weight on the foot afterward and had to stop playing; reports using ace wrap, ice, elevation, and ibuprofen with partial relief; no numbness or loss of sensation; no previous injury to right foot but has injured left foot before
* Social history: Attempts to learn tennis by playing casually with friends due to inability to afford lessons

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 125/70 mmHg, respiratory rate 18/min, temperature 97.1°F, oxygen saturation 100%, pulse 60 beats/min
* Physical exam: Right foot with bruising on plantar and dorsal aspects, swelling, tenderness to palpation at midfoot, positive piano key test on first and second metatarsals, warmth; neurovascular exam intact with capillary refill <3 seconds, strong dorsalis pedis pulse, sensation intact to light touch on right foot; left foot normal with strong pulses and intact sensation; cardiovascular exam shows regular rate and rhythm without murmur, rub, or gallop; lung exam reveals mild stridor without wheezes or rales; abdominal exam without rebound or guarding; skin and mucosal membranes normal and symmetrical
* Test results: Right foot x-ray shows subtle dorsal displacement of base of second metatarsal, 3 mm separation between first and second metatarsal bases, and bony fragment in Lisfranc joint space

A (Assessment):

* Right foot pain consistent with Lisfranc fracture

P (Plan):

* Recommend surgical repair of Lisfranc fracture using plates and screws to properly align bones and prevent complications
* Order MRI to assess fracture extent and ligamentous injury
* Inform patient of risks including bleeding, loss of sensation, nerve damage; provide paperwork detailing risks
* Surgery planned as day procedure with discharge same day
* Postoperative care: foot immobilization in cast, use of crutches with non-weight bearing for 6–8 weeks, followed by gradual weight bearing and physical therapy to strengthen muscles and restore function
* Schedule follow-up appointment approximately one week post-surgery
* Advise patient that foot will require rest for remainder of current tennis season with aim to return in following season

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Left back pain for 3 days with blood in urine  
- History of present illness: Constant left back pain started 3 days ago, pain radiates downward, has not passed the kidney stone yet, associated nausea, chills without fever, unable to eat due to pain  
- Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes, previous kidney stones (third episode)  
- Social history: No information provided  
- Family history: No information provided  

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure elevated today, prior measurements with home BP cuff show systolic readings in 130s to 150s, diastolic 70-80  
- Physical exam: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur on heart auscultation, clear lungs bilaterally, abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding, costovertebral angle (CVA) tenderness on the right flank  
- Test results: Last HbA1c 7.3%, recent home glucose readings in low 100s, previous glucose test ~300 mg/dL  

A (Assessment):

- Kidney stone with associated renal inflammation  
- Hypertension, controlled on Norvasc 2.5 mg  
- Diabetes mellitus, controlled on metformin 500 mg  

P (Plan):

- Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6–8 hours as needed for pain, continue acetaminophen for breakthrough pain  
- Encourage increased fluid intake to help pass the kidney stone  
- Provide urine strainer to catch passed stones  
- Refer to urology for recurrent kidney stone management regardless of stone passage  
- Continue Norvasc 2.5 mg for blood pressure management, no changes at this time  
- Continue metformin 500 mg for diabetes management  
- Refer to nutrition/dietitian for dietary counseling to assist with hypertension and diabetes control  
- Patient education on dietary sodium reduction and assistance to modify eating habits (e.g., reduce intake of french fries)  
- Follow-up as needed based on symptom progression and specialist evaluation

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Sudden onset of right back pain one week ago
* History of present illness: Pain started while working in the barn, moving hay; initially thought to be musculoskeletal but accompanied by sweating and nausea; pain radiated almost down to the groin; pain episodes have decreased in frequency and intensity since diagnosis; currently no pain; no visible blood in urine; straining urine with no stones seen
* Past medical history: No previous kidney stones
* Family history: Father has history of kidney stones
* Social history: No additional information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Normal blood pressure and heart rate, no fever
* Physical exam: Abdomen non-tender, no rebound or guarding; costovertebral angle tenderness on right side
* Test results: CT scan shows 0.5 cm stone in proximal right ureter, no hydronephrosis; no current evidence of obstruction

A (Assessment):

* Kidney stone in proximal right ureter

P (Plan):

* Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate stone passage
* Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6–8 hours for pain
* Continue acetaminophen for breakthrough pain as needed
* Continue urine straining to catch passed stones
* Order basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for infection
* Consider antibiotics if infection detected on urinalysis
* Follow-up in 1 to 2 weeks to assess stone passage and discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy if stone not passed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Nonhealing ulcer on right foot for approximately 6–8 weeks
- History of present illness: Ulcer on right lateral foot near fifth metatarsophalangeal joint, possibly worsened over time, no pain associated with the ulcer, no fever or chills, occasional neuropathy symptoms (numbness and tingling) especially in cold weather, frequent tension headaches
- Past medical history: Diabetes mellitus on insulin, coronary artery disease with a history of myocardial infarction in 2018 and right coronary artery stent placement
- Social history: Former smoker, smoked two packs per day for over 20 years, quit about 4 years ago
- Medication adherence: Taking baby aspirin daily, continues statin therapy
- Functional status: Active with yard work but avoiding long walks recently

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 127/80 mmHg, heart rate in the 60s, afebrile
- Physical exam: No jugular venous distention, no carotid bruits, lungs clear bilaterally, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base, absent palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses on lower extremities
- Right foot exam: 2 x 3 cm ulcerated lesion on lateral right foot near fifth metatarsophalangeal joint, no cellulitis, no pain on palpation, granulation tissue present, slight purulent discharge

A (Assessment):

- Nonhealing right foot ulcer
- Coronary artery disease with prior stent placement
- Diabetes mellitus with suboptimal glycemic control (Hemoglobin A1c >9)
- Peripheral arterial insufficiency suspected (based on absent distal pulses and nonhealing ulcer)
- Neuropathy, occasional, related to diabetes

P (Plan):

- Order arterial ultrasound of lower extremities to assess blood supply to right foot
- Refer to podiatry for wound evaluation and advanced wound care management
- Continue aspirin therapy
- Coordinate care with primary care physician to optimize glycemic control for improved wound healing
- Continue statin therapy; communicate with cardiologist to evaluate need for any cardiac procedure clearance or intervention
- Monitor patient closely for wound healing progress and vascular status

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Itchy scalp with dandruff and scalp pain
* History of present illness: Itchy scalp problem worsening over the past six months, presence of dandruff all over, inability to stop itching
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: No new hair products or chemicals used recently, hair dye used for years
* Family history: Possible dry scalp in sister, no other family members reported with similar scalp symptoms
* Additional symptoms: No joint pain, fever, or weight loss reported
* Psychosocial factors: No new mental or emotional stressors at work or at home

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 130/68 mmHg, heart rate 98/min, respiratory rate 18/min, temperature 97.7°F (36.5°C)
* Physical exam: Scalp shows demarcated scaly erythematous plaques in a patchy pattern diffusely across the back of the scalp, presence of visible dandruff on clothes
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Scalp psoriasis

P (Plan):

* Prescribe clobetasol 0.05% solution to apply twice daily on affected scalp areas during flare-ups (morning and before bed)
* Continue use of T-Gel shampoo regularly for scalp management
* Educate patient that scalp psoriasis has no cure, flare-ups are unpredictable, and long-term management is necessary
* Follow-up appointment scheduled in 3 months or sooner if symptoms significantly worsen

[doctor] okay i'm gon na do a quick physical exam now your vitals look good and i would like to do a focused exam of your right foot the there is some bruising on the bottom part of your foot and on the top part as well and i do appreciate the associated swelling and i also recognize that you do have tenderness to palpation for midfoot now for your neurovascular exam of your right foot your capillary refill is brisk in less than three seconds i do note a strong bounding dorsalis pedis pulse with motor and sensation is intact for that foot i also like to call out the fact that it matches bilaterally which is important i'm gon na go ahead and review the diagnostic imaging results so we did a x-ray of that right foot and i do notice dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal with a three millimeter separation of the first and second metatarsal bases and presence of bony fragments so let me tell you a little bit about my assessment and plan now your right foot pain is due to a lisfranc fracture which is a fracture to your second metatarsal bone and the top of your foot this is where the metatarsals meet those cuboids okay so it where the bones come together in your foot now there are a lot of ligaments in your foot so i do want to order an mri just to assess if there is any injuries to those ligaments now based on your exam and looking at the x-ray you're most likely going to need surgery now the reason why this is important is if we have poor bone alignment or ligament healing you can this can lead to losing the arch in your foot you could becoming flat-footed and also developing arthritis now what's gon na be key here is the surgery is going to allow those bones and ligaments to heal properly we are going to put them back into place using plates and screws now the key thing is going to be it's going to be outpatient surgery so it's going to be same day i'll see you in the morning and then you'll be discharged home that evening and we will do a follow-up i wan na see you in twenty four hours post procedure but then i'll see you again in two weeks you're gon na be in a cast and i'm gon na have you use crutches you're not gon na be able to weight-bear on that foot for six to eight weeks what we'll do is we'll advance your ambulating gradually based on how you heal and based on how you tolerate the procedure i know i have covered a lot of material quickly but this is really gon na be the best course of action for you to have a good outcome now do you have any questions come answers concerns before i have the nurse come in finish the paperwork and get you set up for your procedure which we are going to do tomorrow if you're agreeable to that

[doctor] you could but what we found is the best outcome is aligning those bones with plates and screws to make sure that they heal properly so you have the best outcome possible

[doctor] so what what we will do is the good news is we have an outpatient mri facility downstairs and i'm going to send the order down and we'll get you your mri this afternoon

[doctor] sure
[patient] okay
[doctor] alright thanks elijah
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right foot soreness and swelling after dropping a landscape brick on it yesterday
* History of present illness: Right foot sore and swollen since injury; no prior medical evaluation for this injury; pain rated 11/10 currently; numbness of the entire right foot present since before injury
* Past medical history: Right ankle fracture 20 years ago treated with casting, occasional soreness and swelling; surgery on the other ankle with occasional soreness and episodes of instability
* Social history: Involved in yard work and landscaping activities

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No abnormalities noted
* Physical exam: Bruising on dorsal and plantar surfaces of right foot, swelling present, tenderness to palpation at midfoot; neurovascular exam intact with brisk capillary refill (<3 seconds), strong bounding dorsalis pedis pulse bilaterally, motor and sensation intact and symmetrical
* Test results: Right foot X-ray shows dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal, 3 mm separation between first and second metatarsal bases, presence of bony fragments

A (Assessment):

* Lisfranc fracture of the right foot involving the second metatarsal base, with associated displacement and fragment presence

P (Plan):

* Order right foot MRI this afternoon to assess ligamentous injury
* Recommend outpatient surgical fixation with plates and screws scheduled for tomorrow; surgery intended to realign bones and ligaments for optimal healing
* Postoperative plan includes non-weight-bearing on the right foot for 6 to 8 weeks, casting, use of crutches, and gradual ambulation advancement based on healing and tolerance
* Postoperative follow-up appointments scheduled at 24 hours post-procedure and at 2 weeks
* Patient to consider surgery and discuss questions before proceeding
* Nurse to complete paperwork and prepare patient for the procedure if agreed upon

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: New right eye twitch
* History of present illness: Right eye twitch noticed a couple of weeks ago, frequency varies from several times an hour to none until late afternoon, occurs daily for several weeks; no associated pain but sometimes an urge to move the face with relief after movement; no impact on activities or school; no fever, chills, cough, headache, or sleep problems
* Past medical history: No significant past medical history, no history of seizures
* Family history: No history of seizures or Tourette’s syndrome
* Social history: Plays soccer weekly, experiences rough play from another child; enjoys spending time with father and occasional fast food (McDonald’s)
* Review of systems: No other symptoms reported

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Awake, alert, oriented times three; speech clear and fluent; gait steady; heel-toe walking normal; cranial nerves intact; no focal neurologic findings; no pronator drift; sensation intact and symmetric; reflexes two plus and symmetric at biceps, triceps, knees, and ankles
* Neurological exam: Normal findings; no abnormal movements observed during the exam

A (Assessment):

* Motor tic (eye twitch), transient tic suspected

P (Plan):

* Reassure family that tics are common in children and often transient, typically resolving within a year without treatment
* Advise to ignore the tic to avoid worsening it; minimizing attention to the tic is important
* No medication or other treatment initiated at this time since the tic is not impacting school or activities
* Monitor for changes or worsening; consider treatment if tic worsens or affects function
* Follow-up as needed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Recurrent lower respiratory infections with cough and mucus production
* History of present illness: Cough with a lot of mucus, shortness of breath, low-grade fever lasting from a few days up to a week, recurrent episodes occurring every month or every other month over the past six months, usually requiring antibiotics or urgent care visits, one ER visit reported; symptoms typically start on days when unloading hay on the farm without mask use
* Occupational history: Farmer, recently unloading hay more frequently than usual while helping brother
* Social history: Does not smoke, does not live with smokers
* Family history: No history of seasonal allergies reported
* Other: Denies personal history of allergies

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation 99% on room air
* Physical exam: Regular heart rate and rhythm, no murmurs/rubs/gallops, fine rales on lung auscultation, no wheezes, no finger clubbing
* Test results: Chest X-ray showing ground-glass opacities

A (Assessment):

* Hypersensitivity pneumonitis, also known as farmer’s lung, suspected as cause of recurrent lung infections and symptoms

P (Plan):

* Prescribe course of oral steroids to reduce lung inflammation
* Order chest CT scan to confirm diagnosis
* Order pulmonary function test to assess severity of respiratory impairment
* Advise elimination or prevention of hay exposure to avoid further lung damage
* Recommend use of respirator mask when handling hay if exposure cannot be avoided
* Counsel patient about involving siblings to reduce personal hay exposure and workload
* Follow-up plans to monitor response and disease progression

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Pain and redness in the right big toe
* History of present illness: Off and on pain for about two weeks, worsening last week at a trade show convention making walking impossible; describes pain as throbbing with occasional sharp stabbing, worsened by bending and walking on toe; pain aggravated by light pressure including bed sheets at night; no recalled injury; takes two ibuprofen a day without relief
* Past medical history: No history of stomach problems reported
* Social history: Enjoys biking and fishing, works on feet daily, prefers regular shoes or flip flops when biking
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Tenderness with movement of the big toe, more pain on plantar flexion, mild pain on lateral pressure; palpable bone spur on the dorsum of the big toe joint; grinding sensation noted on joint manipulation
* Test results: X-ray shows large dorsally located bone spur on big toe joint, significant cartilage loss indicating arthritis (hallux rigidus)

A (Assessment):

* Hallux rigidus (osteoarthritis of the first metatarsophalangeal joint)

P (Plan):

* Prescribe shoe orthotics to limit toe motion and provide support
* Start meloxicam once daily for inflammation, monitor for stomach irritation or heartburn and discontinue if symptoms occur
* Advise continuation of regular activities and work to assess treatment effectiveness
* Follow-up appointment in two weeks to evaluate response to treatment
* Discussed potential future treatments if no improvement, including corticosteroid injection or surgical options such as joint debridement or fusion

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Follow-up after anterior STEMI with recent drug-eluting stent placement
- History of present illness: Status post anterior STEMI with recent LAD stent, feels tired occasionally but overall doing okay, no chest pain or shortness of breath, able to do light walking around the block and light housekeeping, never sleeps fully flat, uses two pillows, no leg swelling, compliant with medications, aware of need to watch salt intake despite preference for pizza, interested in resuming walking and outdoor activities like gardening and photography
- Past medical history: Coronary artery disease status post RCA stent in 2018, hypertension, diabetes mellitus
- Social history: No specific information on smoking or alcohol provided; enjoys gardening and photography
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No specific measurements provided but described as good and stable
- Physical exam: No jugular venous distention, no carotid bruits, 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base unchanged from last year, lungs clear, no extremity swelling or edema, right radial artery catheter site clean, dry, intact with palpable pulse, EKG showed normal sinus rhythm, good R wave progression, expected evolutionary changes
- Test results: Echocardiogram showed newly reduced ejection fraction 35%, moderate mitral regurgitation, prior RCA stent in 2018, recent LAD drug-eluting stent placement

A (Assessment):

- Coronary artery disease
- Newly reduced left ventricular dysfunction and moderate mitral regurgitation
- Hypertension

P (Plan):

- Continue aspirin 81 mg daily, Brilinta (ticagrelor) 90 mg twice daily, atorvastatin (Lipitor) 80 mg daily, and metoprolol (Toprol) 50 mg daily
- Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily
- Add spironolactone (Aldactone) 12.5 mg daily
- Refer to cardiac rehabilitation program for education and exercise guidance
- Patient to monitor blood pressure regularly
- Obtain laboratory tests next week to monitor therapy
- Repeat echocardiogram in approximately two months
- Patient education on salt restriction and medication adherence emphasized

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Difficulty breathing during sports, mood changes with sadness and fatigue
* History of present illness: Asthma symptoms triggered primarily by aerobic activities and exposure to smoke, causing chest tightness, coughing, wheezing, and phlegm sensation, relieved partially by albuterol inhaler but with side effects of shakiness; mood issues started this year related to school stress including AP classes and SATs, described as sadness, low motivation, tiredness, and social withdrawal
* Past medical history: Asthma, no prior daily asthma medications used, seasonal allergies reported
* Social history: Participates in sports including water polo, avoids smoke exposure, stressed due to academic pressures
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Heart and lung auscultation normal, some fluid noted in ears, throat normal without tonsils, abdominal exam normal with normal reflexes
* Test results: No laboratory or imaging studies provided

A (Assessment):

* Asthma, considering initiation of daily controller medication due to frequent symptoms during exercise and allergy component
* Mood disturbance, likely related to academic and social stress, requiring further evaluation

P (Plan):

* Start montelukast (Singulair) as daily asthma controller medication
* Continue use of albuterol inhaler as needed with advising on expected side effects and rest after use
* Initiate mental health support with psychotherapy referral and screening questionnaires
* Follow-up appointment scheduled in approximately six weeks to assess asthma control and mood status

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Left foot pain after injury during a soccer game
- History of present illness: Injured left foot yesterday when another player fell onto it; experienced twisting of the foot and immediate pain, unable to continue playing and was helped off the field; pain level without ibuprofen is 7-8/10 and 3/10 with ibuprofen; has been playing soccer since age 4-5; no previous injury to the left foot
- Past medical history: No previous injury to the left foot
- Social history: Plays soccer regularly, including in school teams
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 118/72 mmHg, heart rate 58/min, respiratory rate 14/min, afebrile, oxygen saturation 99% on room air
- Physical exam: Bruising and swelling on top and bottom of left foot, tenderness to palpation of midfoot, positive piano key test; heart: regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, clicks, or ectopic beats; lungs: clear and equal bilaterally; neurovascular exam of left foot: brisk capillary refill <3 seconds, dorsalis pedis pulse intact and strong, motor and sensation intact to light touch
- Test results: X-ray shows subtle dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal, 3 mm separation of first and second metatarsal bases, presence of a bony fragment in the Lisfranc joint space

A (Assessment):

- Lisfranc fracture of the left foot
- Surgery likely needed to repair fracture and associated ligament injury

P (Plan):

- Order MRI to assess ligament injury in left foot
- Proceed with surgery to realign bones and fix with plates and screws; day surgery with same-day discharge
- Postoperative care: cast immobilization, non-weight bearing on left foot with crutches for 6 to 8 weeks
- Gradual weight bearing after 6 to 8 weeks based on tolerance
- Follow-up clinic visit scheduled
- Patient education about risks of poor healing including flat-foot deformity and arthritis
- Initiate paperwork and prepare for surgery appointment on Monday morning

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Pain on the inside of the right knee after injury playing basketball
* History of present illness: Injured right knee 7 days ago when another player ran into her; fell to the ground landing on her side, unable to continue playing; pain localized on the medial side of the right knee, with swelling and decreased range of motion; denies hearing or feeling a pop at injury; currently managing pain with exercises, ice, and meloxicam
* Past medical history: Diabetes mellitus managed with metformin 500 mg twice daily
* Social history: Plays basketball recreationally with spouse; family owns a sports store selling sporting equipment

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Right knee swelling and ecchymosis on the medial side, tenderness on medial palpation, small effusion noted, decreased range of motion with pain on extension and flexion, negative varus and valgus stress tests; no tenderness on lateral palpation
* Test results: Right knee x-ray shows good bony alignment, no fractures, small joint effusion

A (Assessment):

* Medial collateral ligament strain of the right knee, suspected

P (Plan):

* Continue use of ACE wrap and start wearing right knee brace for several days
* Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily for pain and swelling, discontinue other NSAIDs such as ibuprofen or naproxen
* Initiate physical therapy focusing on strengthening muscles around the right knee
* Encourage light walking as tolerated
* Monitor blood sugars carefully given diabetic status and reduced activity; follow up with primary care provider as needed for glucose management
* Re-evaluation appointment in 7 days to assess swelling and clinical status; consider MRI or CT scan if condition worsens or does not improve
* Patient education provided regarding activity restrictions, medication use, and follow-up plan

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Difficulty swallowing certain foods, pain when swallowing located in the chest
* History of present illness: Symptoms present for several weeks, pain occurs with most foods but especially with bigger pieces that feel stuck, occasional epigastric pain, no weight loss but weight gain reported, no nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or blood in stool
* Social history: Recent stressful move from West Coast to East Coast, increased consumption of pizza and burgers, concerns about traveling with dog, considering driving for relocation
* Family history: No information provided
* Past medical history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 133/70 mmHg, heart rate normal, temperature normal, oxygen saturation 100%, respiratory rate 19/min
* Physical exam: Mouth exam normal, no ulcers or thrush, tonsils midline, no cervical adenopathy or thyromegaly, abdomen nondistended with active bowel sounds, epigastric tenderness to palpation present, negative Murphy’s sign, no peritoneal signs, no rebound tenderness, lungs clear bilaterally, no skin rash, lesions, or bruising, eyes equal and reactive to light
* Test results: Barium swallow showing two areas of mild narrowing in mid and lower esophagus consistent with esophagitis, documented weight gain of approximately 10 pounds in past month

A (Assessment):

* Acute esophagitis

P (Plan):

* Prescribe Protonix 40 mg orally once daily in the morning
* Prescribe Carafate 1 gram orally four times daily for one month
* Schedule upper endoscopy to evaluate for other possible conditions
* Advise dietary modifications: decrease alcohol and caffeine intake, avoid citrus fruits and spicy foods until symptoms improve, eat slowly and chew food thoroughly
* Counsel on importance of healthy diet post-move
* Follow-up scheduled in one week for endoscopy and reassessment

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Shortness of breath, trouble sleeping for about two weeks
* History of present illness: Difficulty falling asleep due to feeling like choking and shortness of breath shortly after lying down, no shortness of breath during minimal activity, noticed about 10-pound weight gain, inability to see ankles due to swelling, occasional productive cough especially in the morning without fever, no chest pain or tightness, increased urination despite low fluid intake, ongoing back pain mainly in lower paraspinal areas causing prolonged sitting
* Past medical history: Diabetes, chronic heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), back pain
* Social history: Sedentary lifestyle, sitting on couch watching TV most days
* Medication adherence: Irregular use of Lasix, knows Lasix is a white round pill but not currently taking it regularly, taking metformin for diabetes but unclear on blood glucose monitoring frequency or understanding
* Diabetes control: Last hemoglobin A1c 7.5, recent blood sugar approx. 230 mg/dL, difficulty controlling diet and blood sugar
* Back pain history: Muscular pain, no weakness or numbness in legs

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Oxygen saturation 92% in office (noted to be low side)
* Physical exam: Neck exam with mild swelling and jugular venous distension, no bruits; lung exam with crackles and rales at both bases, intermittent wheezing noted; heart exam reveals 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, regular rate and rhythm; abdomen slightly distended, non-tender, no guarding; bilateral ankle edema approximately 1 to 1.5+ pitting edema, no calf tenderness, negative Homan’s sign; neurological exam normal; lower back exam shows paraspinal tenderness, no midline tenderness, normal reflexes

A (Assessment):

* Congestive heart failure exacerbation
* Diabetes mellitus with suboptimal control
* Chronic back pain, muscular in origin

P (Plan):

* Increase Lasix dosage from 20 mg to 60 mg daily for 4 days, instruct patient to check daily weights
* Prescribe albuterol and atrovent inhalers for breathing treatments; refill existing inhalers as needed
* Order hemoglobin A1c blood test and other blood work, results to be reviewed at follow-up
* Prescribe naproxen and Flexeril (muscle relaxant) for back pain; provide exercises to improve mobility and reduce pain; consider physical therapy if symptoms persist
* Advise patient to adhere to low salt diet and medication regimen
* Schedule follow-up appointment in a couple of days to assess response to treatments and adjust as needed
* Educate patient on importance of medication adherence and monitoring for worsening symptoms that may require hospitalization

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left ankle pain
* History of present illness: Injury occurred yesterday while walking, stepped off a curb and landed awkwardly on left ankle, pain localized on the outside of the ankle, no heard pop but felt stretching, able to walk home with pain, pain level 8/10 without medication and 7/10 with ibuprofen or acetaminophen
* Past medical history: No substantial previous injuries to the left ankle
* Social history: Regular walking for exercise during COVID-19 pandemic

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Stable, slightly elevated (exact values not provided)
* Physical exam: Ecchymosis and swelling over lateral malleolus of left ankle, edema present, tenderness to palpation lateral side, no joint laxity, no bony tenderness on foot palpation; neurovascular exam normal with brisk capillary refill (<3 seconds), strong dorsalis pedis pulses, intact motor and sensation bilaterally
* Test results: Left ankle X-ray shows no fracture or bony abnormality

A (Assessment):

* Ankle sprain of the lateral ligament complex of left ankle

P (Plan):

* Continue RICE protocol (rest, ice, compression, elevation)
* Provide air cast for ankle stabilization
* Prescribe crutches for non-weight bearing; start walking as tolerated in a few days
* Continue NSAIDs for pain and swelling
* Follow-up visit in 2 weeks for reassessment
* Advise patient to return sooner if pain worsens or other concerns arise

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right ankle pain after a fall
* History of present illness: Slipped on ice last night while taking out the trash, heard a pop at the time of fall, initial inability to bear weight, now able to put some weight but limping, constant throbbing pain rated 6/10 currently, warmth and tenderness on touch, ibuprofen taken with minimal relief, icing and elevation attempted
* Past medical history: No prior injury to this ankle, history of playing soccer with other injuries but not to this ankle
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, oxygen saturation 98%
* Physical exam: Ecchymosis (bruising) and swelling over lateral malleolus, tenderness to palpation of anterior lateral soft tissue, no laxity on anterior drawer and inversion stress tests, no bony tenderness on foot palpation, capillary refill < 3 seconds, strong dorsalis pedis pulse, intact sensation to light touch
* Test results: Right ankle X-ray negative for fractures or bony abnormalities

A (Assessment):

* Right ankle sprain

P (Plan):

* Keep leg elevated when seated
* Ice ankle five times daily for 20 minutes each session
* Apply air cast for ankle stabilization
* Use crutches and stay off the affected leg for 1 to 2 days
* Begin weight-bearing as tolerated after initial rest period
* Expected recovery time: 2 to 3 weeks for full resolution of symptoms
* No doctor's note provided due to work being computer-based
* Advise follow-up if pain persists beyond one week or worsens; possible MRI if needed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Back pain radiating down left leg for about four days  
- History of present illness: Pain started after bending to lift something while working in the yard, described as sharp pain down left leg with occasional tingling in certain positions, no weakness or numbness, no loss of bowel or bladder function  
- Past medical history: Diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, occasional past episodes of back pain, no previous back surgeries  
- Medications: Metformin 500 mg twice daily, Norvasc 5 mg once daily  
- Social history: Engages in yard work under spousal encouragement, diet includes sweets and cookies despite efforts to reduce carbohydrate intake  
- Patient’s report on disease control: Checks blood sugar 2-3 times weekly, blood sugar mostly in 120–140 range, acknowledges room for weight loss (~15 pounds), diet attempts to reduce sweets, blood pressure mostly controlled ranging 120–130/70–80 mmHg, noticed swelling in ankles started 1-2 months after starting Norvasc

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure approximately 120/70 mmHg in clinic  
- Physical exam: No jugular venous distension, no carotid bruits, lungs clear without rales or wheezes, heart regular rate and rhythm with 2/6 systolic ejection murmur (known), abdomen soft, tenderness over left paraspinal lower back area on palpation, negative straight leg raise test, normal reflexes and neurological exam, mild (1+) nonpitting bilateral lower extremity edema without calf tenderness, negative Homan’s sign  
- Test results: Previous hemoglobin A1c 7.1%, no new results yet

A (Assessment):

- Muscular sprain of lower back suspected  
- Diabetes mellitus, ongoing management  
- Hypertension, complicated by peripheral edema possibly related to Norvasc, suspected medication side effect

P (Plan):

- Prescribe Naprosyn 500 mg orally twice daily for back pain  
- Prescribe Flexeril 10 mg orally twice daily as muscle relaxant  
- Refer to physical therapy for lower back strengthening exercises  
- No imaging currently indicated; consider X-ray if no improvement  
- Order hemoglobin A1c test today to assess glycemic control  
- Continue Metformin 500 mg twice daily  
- Discontinue Norvasc; start Hydrochlorothiazide 10 mg once daily  
- Order blood tests including CBC and basic metabolic panel to evaluate kidney function  
- Obtain EKG and chest X-ray to further evaluate edema and cardiovascular status  
- Follow up in approximately two weeks to review lab results and adjust treatment if needed  
- Educate patient regarding importance of diet and exercise in diabetes management and edema monitoring

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right knee pain following skiing injury two weeks ago
- History of present illness: Twisted right knee after crashing into a tree while skiing downhill; pain mainly on medial (inside) aspect of right knee; left knee felt unstable with a pop but no significant pain; right knee pain rated 7/10, sometimes up to 11/10 especially when walking longer distances; swelling, stiffness notably in the morning; pain worsens with walking; prior right knee surgery during adolescence after a gymnastics injury; no current skiing or gymnastics due to pain; uses knee brace and THC cream which patient finds helpful; uses THC gummies occasionally; no other medications
- Past medical history: Previous right knee surgery (ligament reconstruction) at age 14 after gymnastics injury
- Social history: Skis approximately three times a week, active lifestyle including intense gym and skiing
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Mild swelling and bruising of the right knee; tenderness on medial aspect of right knee on palpation; no tenderness on lateral aspect; no pain on patellar movement but shooting pain down to ankle; slight limp noted during gait suggesting knee protection; pain on knee dorsiflexion (pulling knee toward body) but not plantar flexion (pulling away)
- Test results: Right knee x-rays show no fracture but early signs of arthritis

A (Assessment):

- Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) strain of the right knee
- Early degenerative arthritis changes in right knee
- Left knee mild strain, no medication or bracing recommended

P (Plan):

- Continue wearing right knee brace to reduce stress
- Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg orally once daily for swelling and bruising
- Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg orally twice daily as needed for left knee pain
- Recommend physical therapy three times weekly to improve knee strength, avoid skiing and gymnastics until recovery
- Advise patient to listen to body signals and follow therapist guidance on activity levels
- Counsel against concurrent use of prescribed NSAIDs and THC gummies

* Chief complaint: Osteoarthritis flare-up primarily in elbows, more on right side
* History of present illness: Increased elbow pain and stiffness, worse with prolonged typing and staying in one position; occasional numbness and tingling in hands after long typing sessions, relieved by shaking arms; no other joint pain reported

S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right knee pain that started about a month ago with increased swimming activity
* History of present illness: Began swimming more regularly using breaststroke; right knee pain occurs after a few laps, increasing with continued swimming; no history of injury, fall, or twist; chronic back pain present but currently well controlled without radiation; depression stable on medication and therapy; past carpal tunnel release surgery a few years ago with good recovery
* Past medical history: Carpal tunnel release surgery, chronic back pain, depression
* Social history: Increased physical activity by swimming regularly to improve health
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No joint swelling in right knee; pain with knee range of motion and patellar palpation/manipulation; good grip strength bilaterally; regular heart rhythm; clear lung sounds; no lymphadenopathy; normal thyroid on examination
* Test results: Right knee x-ray normal with no abnormalities detected

A (Assessment):

* Chondromalacia patellae due to overuse from increased swimming activity
* Chronic back pain, currently stable
* Depression, stable

P (Plan):

* Prescribe ibuprofen 600 mg orally four times daily with food for right knee pain
* Recommend straight leg raising exercises to strengthen quadriceps
* Advise avoidance of activities that put extra pressure on knees, including breaststroke swimming and lunges, until improvement
* Suggest alternative swimming strokes with legs kept straight if comfortable
* Continue current medication and therapy for depression without changes
* Continue current management for chronic back pain, with follow-up if flare-up occurs
* Continue monitoring carpal tunnel status, no changes needed
* Follow-up visit recommended if knee pain does not improve in 2 weeks

S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: High blood sugar
* History of present illness: Increased intake of sweets during holidays leading to light-headedness, dizziness, and visual spots; recently treated in emergency room with IV fluids and advised to avoid sweets and return to normal diet; difficulty maintaining routine due to family environment with frequent baked goods
* Past medical history: Osteoarthritis, atrial fibrillation, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
* Social history: Staying with family who frequently bake, making dietary control challenging
* Review of systems: No fever, chills, chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, dysuria; no new joint pain or muscle aches beyond osteoarthritis baseline; occasional heart palpitations during anxiety

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Patient in no distress, thyroid mildly enlarged but non-tender, no carotid bruits, irregular heart rate and rhythm consistent with atrial fibrillation, lungs clear, abdomen soft, no lower extremity edema
* Test results: Elevated blood glucose and hemoglobin A1c indicating chronic hyperglycemia; other diabetes labs pending
* Vital signs: No specific numerical data provided

A (Assessment):

* Diabetes mellitus, type to be determined (type 1 or type 2), suspected
* Osteoarthritis
* Atrial fibrillation
* Gastroesophageal reflux disease

P (Plan):

* Start metformin 500 mg orally twice daily
* Order complete metabolic panel and autoimmune labs to differentiate diabetes type
* Continue metoprolol 25 mg orally twice daily with refill prescribed
* Continue protonix 40 mg orally once daily for reflux
* Provide glucometer and teach blood sugar monitoring through nursing staff
* Advise strict avoidance of high-sugar foods
* Follow-up pending laboratory results and education completion

transcription:
[doctor] next patient is emily hernandez . date of birth , march 26 2001 . this is a 20 year old female being seen today for our yearly follow-up for asthma , allergic rhinitis and food allergy . due to insurance changes since our last office appointment in april 2020 , she was switched from symbicort to wixela . she also uses zyrtec in the spring , summer and fall for her seasonal allergy symptoms , which tend to work well . she also has known peanut allergy , she does tolerate almonds and cashews . please put in the asthma section at the very bottom that the act score is 21 . please put under interval history , written consent is obtained today to use dax for documentation .
[doctor] hi emily , how are you ?
[patient] i'm pretty good , how are you ?
[doctor] i'm good , thank you . so gosh , we last talked a little bit over a year ago and it was just a telemedicine visit , but it seems like you've been doing pretty good . i know there was an insurance change . i think you had switched over to wixela , is that right ?
[patient] yep , that's right , and it's what i'm currently using .
[doctor] okay , and that's the 250/50 dose , correct ?
[patient] yes , correct .
[doctor] perfect . so how does that compare ?
[patient] i mean , it's working well . i really have n't had any issues with it and i take it once in the morning and once at night .
[doctor] and that's one puff twice a day ?
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] okay . and have you been having to use your albuterol inhaler at all ?
[patient] rarely , and if i do it's really just before a workout or something out that , if i know i'm really going to be pushing it .
[doctor] so it sounds like it's around strenuous activity .
[patient] yes .
[doctor] okay . so you can do things like go on a walk or going to the grocery store no problem , and just use it for more exertional stuff ?
[patient] yes . like , if i'm gon na go for a run or something like that i'll really just take it before as a preventative .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] and i've been trying to use my daily if i can a little less because i'm trying to go into the military soon .
[doctor] no kidding , that's great .
[patient] yeah , so i have to be able to operate basically at a certain fitness level without an inhaler .
[doctor] really ?
[patient] yeah , and if i can prove that i'm capable of these activities without an inhaler it makes it easier .
[doctor] and so by inhaler do they mean both your daily and rescue inhalers ?
[patient] mm-hmm . so it's like they'll have a fitness test and basically they'll tell me not to take my inhaler that day before the test , and then they'll see how the asthma affects me . and they're looking to see if it's serious enough to hold me back from joining or whatever . so i have been taking it less and less . and really some days i feel like i do n't need it .
[doctor] and that is the wixela that you're not taking . so on average per week , how many days of the week do you use one puff in the morning and one puff at night ?
[patient] probably about three or four .
[doctor] okay , three to four days per week and the other days it's once a day ?
[patient] yes , that's correct .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] and it's either in the morning or at night that i'm taking it .
[doctor] okay , and do you think that's working okay ?
[patient] i do .
[doctor] great . and any urgent care or er visits at all for breathing over the past year ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] okay , so i'm going to assume no one has put you on prednisone for breathing issues then .
[patient] nope .
[doctor] okay . and now , military wise , what's the time frame of when you'll be completing some of these exertional tests ? like , what are your next steps ?
[patient] so , hopefully i'm going to be enlisted early spring of 2022 . so that gives me about six to seven months to get to a point where i'm able to exert my body where i do n't really need the inhaler . or at least show them that i have it under control .
[doctor] now when you were in the other room you completed a breathing test , correct ?
[patient] correct .
[doctor] okay , great . so now let me ask you about the allergies , 'cause i know typically you'll use the zyrtec in the spring , summer and fall , correct ?
[patient] yeah , i do n't really ... um , or i'm sorry , i use it more during the spring and fall . i do n't really have to use it too much in the summer .
[doctor] do you use it more just as needed in the summer ?
[patient] yeah , that's right .
[doctor] okay . and have you been taking the zyrtec every day recently since you're right in the mix of spring ?
[patient] not every day , but i do take it on days i know i'm going to be outside a lot . um , i do tend to work outside about three days a week so i'll definitely take it on those days .
[doctor] and does it seem to work pretty well still ? are you happy with it ?
[patient] yeah , it does , it works great .
[doctor] wonderful , good to hear . and then i'm assuming you're staying away from the peanuts . uh , last year you had told me it worked with ... uh , you worked with enterprise rent-a-car and one of the cars had a lot of peanuts in it that you were cleaning out and that gave you hives , uh , when you had touched it , is that correct ?
[patient] yep , that's correct .
[doctor] okay . and has there been anything like that since that experience ?
[patient] no , i do n't think so . i definitely became more cautious after that , so i usually wear , uh , wear long sleeves and change my gloves every time now . so i have n't had a reaction , but i imagine that i probably came into contact with cars that had peanuts in them , but they just d- did n't touch my skin .
[doctor] super . and it sounds like you're really smart about it .
[patient] yeah , and the airplanes , they have peanuts . they give everyone too , so .
[doctor] okay . and you have an epipen that k- that you keep with you , correct ?
[patient] yes .
[doctor] okay . and i'm assuming you're going to need refills , um , i can call you in a new set for the year . typically of course , they expire within a year .
[patient] yeah , okay .
[doctor] and i remember , um , sometime previously you've had some testing for tree nuts , but you do have almonds and cashews , correct ? and- and you do okay with them , or do you avoid all tree nuts ?

[doctor] okay .
[patient] and i remember having them and nothing happened , but i usually just tend to stay away from them , um , really if i can help it .
[doctor] okay . so sometimes when people have a peanut allergy , the nuts in general just are n't very important to them , so it is very common to avoid both . um , so let's do this . i'll have helen come in and i would love to complete a breathing test on you . if your breathing numbers are looking great we can work on getting you , uh , something lower than wixela . if you look at all of our asthma regimens it is a stepwise process , and wixela is a combination of two medications in one . and , well maybe you do n't need both of'em . uh , maybe you just need one of'em . so we can work our way backwards .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] and so the breathing test will help give us some- some more guidance , we will look at the results in just a moment .
[patient] all right , and so this past year i did get into the bad habit of vaping and smoking , but i have been trying to cut that out . so i should be good , and , um , now i only do just a little bit and i am trying to quit . so i am sure that might have an effect .
[doctor] it can . um , so what we can do today is compare your results with prior results , probably before you started smoking or using the vape .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] yeah . and we'll see where you stand at that point .
[patient] all right , that sounds good .
[doctor] well let me go ahead and listen , so hop on up here for me .
[patient] okay .

[patient] awesome .

[doctor] yes , you're absolutely right , that was a bad year . that was my first fall here and i was really alarmed . well that explains why at that time your numbers were a little bit lower and today they look better . here's what i think , so you'll have kaiser currently , correct ?
