SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Low back pain for about one week
* History of present illness: Pain started after twisting on the left side and possibly lifting something; initial pain went away but returned a few hours later and has persisted since; pain localized more to the center and lower part of the back with occasional radiation to the left side; aggravated by sudden leftward movements and twisting
* Past medical history: Diabetes mellitus, currently managed with metformin
* Social history: Exercises occasionally, owns/visits family bakery with frequent exposure to sweets and carbohydrates
* Patient reports attempts to manage blood sugar and exercise regularly, but blood glucose readings have been on the higher side recently

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Eyes and ears normal on inspection; lungs clear; heart regular rate and rhythm; tenderness on palpation at the center and left lower back extending towards the left buttock; right side less tender; straight leg raise causes mild pain on right and significant tenderness on left; no pain, numbness, or tingling in lower extremities
* Test results: No imaging or laboratory results yet; A1c test ordered

A (Assessment):

* Musculoskeletal low back strain, suspected
* Diabetes mellitus, under control but requiring updated A1c assessment

P (Plan):

* Order outpatient low back x-ray to assess joint spaces and possible disk issues
* Order A1c laboratory test for diabetes control assessment
* Prescribe ibuprofen 400 mg as needed up to three times daily for pain
* Prescribe Flexeril (muscle relaxant) one tablet once daily in the evening with caution for activities requiring alertness such as driving
* Recommend physical therapy to manage pain and strengthen back muscles
* Continue metformin without change for now
* Advise patient to monitor and record fasting blood glucose daily in the mornings
* Counsel patient to limit carbohydrate and sweet intake from bakery visits, allowing occasional treats but avoiding routine consumption
* Discuss potential future referral to pain specialist if pain persists after initial diagnostics and treatment, with possibility of CT scan if indicated
* Follow-up plan based on A1c results and clinical progress

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Pain and clicking on the outside of the right knee after injury
- History of present illness: Injury occurred about two and a half weeks ago stepping off a curb with no fall; initial ankle soreness resolved but right lateral knee pain and clicking persist, worse with full squat and standing on one foot for extended periods; no pain at rest except when resting on heel; ibuprofen taken occasionally at night with some relief; symptoms stable over last two weeks, worsened transiently with physical exertion like gardening; fear of injury present
- Past medical history: Repeated fractures of second toe on right foot with longstanding numbness and tingling unrelated to current injury
- Social history: Works in sales, currently working from home; cycles indoors in winter on Peloton and uses a winter bike outside; not actively doing high-impact exercises like burpees
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Slight edema and slight effusion of right knee; no pain on palpation of right lateral knee; pain only when foot is pulled outward (positive varus test); full range of motion of right knee; negative Lachman test; palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibialis pulses
- Test results: Right knee X-ray shows no acute fracture or bony abnormality

A (Assessment):

- Lateral collateral ligament strain of the right knee

P (Plan):

- Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily
- Refer to physical therapy for strengthening around the injury
- Continue icing right knee (20 minutes on, 20 minutes off at least 4 times daily)
- Consider MRI if pain persists despite therapy
- Patient education on injury healing and symptom monitoring
- Follow-up as needed; patient instructed to call if symptoms worsen or new concerns arise

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Pain in the back of the right heel extending up into the calf, typically after workouts and upon first getting up in the morning
* History of present illness: Training for a triathlon with running 10 kilometers in the morning, cycling for 45 minutes to an hour at lunchtime, and swimming for 30 minutes to an hour in the evening, five days per week; pain is tight and tearing on waking, eases after 10-15 minutes walking, worsens again after prolonged sitting or increased activity; no stretching routine due to time constraints
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Triathlon training five days per week, one day off; no stretching performed; previously played hockey in Detroit

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Pain on dorsiflexion and plantar flexion against resistance of the right foot; tenderness on palpation along the right Achilles tendon and heel; negative Thompson test; no calf tenderness or signs of deep vein thrombosis; left leg examination unremarkable

A (Assessment):

* Achilles tendinitis due to overuse from aggressive triathlon training

P (Plan):

* Discontinue all training activities for 1-2 weeks to allow healing
* Prescribe ibuprofen (Advil) 3 tablets every 6 hours as anti-inflammatory treatment
* Refer for physical therapy to learn stretching and strengthening exercises for lower extremities
* Follow-up appointment in 7-10 days after initial physical therapy sessions to monitor progress
* No imaging studies ordered at this time; consider further evaluation if pain persists after activity modification

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Nonhealing foot ulcer
- History of present illness: Ulcer present for about one year, started as a blister without trauma, became red and infected after picking at it; treated with Keflex antibiotics about five months ago with temporary improvement but no complete healing; no pain but decreased sensation in the foot; recent increase in drainage and feeling more tired
- Past medical history: Type 2 diabetes with poor glycemic control, last HbA1c approximately 10
- Social history: Plans to walk around at the zoo and eat out over the weekend, not using recommended diabetic footwear
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No fever, vitals stable
- Physical exam: Right dorsal lateral foot ulcer measuring approximately 1 by 2 cm proximal to the fifth metatarsophalangeal joint, yellow slough present, minimal granulation tissue, no surrounding erythema or cellulitis, no fluid collection, no necrosis, no odor, no bony exposure, non-tender on palpation
- Test results: Recent right foot X-ray shows no evidence of osteomyelitis

A (Assessment):

- Diabetic foot ulcer

P (Plan):

- Order ankle brachial index (ABI) to evaluate blood supply to the affected foot
- Perform debridement of the ulcer in office to remove dead tissue
- Prescribe collagenase ointment once daily with sterile dressing
- Provide surgical shoe for offloading pressure from the ulcer site
- Advise to minimize pressure on foot, especially during walking activities such as weekend zoo visit
- Schedule follow-up visit in two weeks for wound reassessment and possible repeat debridement

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up after inferior STEMI and stent placement
* History of present illness: Experienced severe chest pain similar to previous heart attack leading to emergency room visit and additional stent placement; currently no chest pain or shortness of breath; able to walk dog daily for 1.5 to 2 miles; noticed leg swelling since hospital discharge; uses a couple of pillows to sleep, sometimes sits up more; has not been strict with salt intake lately, especially enjoys pepperoni and cheese pizza; monitoring blood sugars and taking metformin to avoid insulin; aware of importance of medication adherence and able to afford medications
* Past medical history: Coronary artery disease, hypertension, diabetes mellitus
* Social history: Walks dog daily, no specific holiday plans, looking forward to family visits and nice weather
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No abnormalities reported, stated as “vital signs look good”
* Physical exam: No jugular venous distention; no carotid bruits; 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base; clear lung sounds; mild lower limb pitting edema (1+) on right leg; right radial artery catheter site clean, dry, intact without hematoma; palpable right radial artery pulses
* Test results: EKG shows normal sinus rhythm, good R wave progression, post-STEMI evolutionary changes; echocardiogram shows reduced left ventricular ejection fraction of 35%, moderate mitral regurgitation

A (Assessment):

* Coronary artery disease
* Newly reduced left ventricular dysfunction
* Moderate mitral regurgitation
* Acute heart failure, suspected
* Hypertension

P (Plan):

* Continue aspirin 81 mg daily and Brilinta (ticagrelor) 90 mg twice daily
* Continue atorvastatin (Lipitor) 80 mg daily
* Continue metoprolol (Toprol) 50 mg daily
* Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily
* Add furosemide (Lasix) 40 mg once daily
* Add spironolactone (Aldactone) 12.5 mg daily
* Refer to cardiac rehabilitation for education and exercise support
* Order laboratory tests (specific labs not detailed)
* Repeat echocardiogram in approximately 2 months
* Recommend nutrition counseling focusing on salt reduction, avoidance of preserved meats such as pepperoni, and diet modifications appropriate for diabetes and heart failure management

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Concern about multiple medications, dizziness when standing up quickly, feeling down since heart attack
* History of present illness: Heart attack six months ago with left anterior descending artery stent placement; currently taking aspirin, Brilinta, fish oil, Crestor, and metoprolol; experiences dizziness on standing rapidly, uncertain if from heart attack or medication; some puffiness in legs; difficulty controlling diabetes with elevated HbA1c near 6.0, fasting glucose approx. 130 mg/dL; reports affinity for sweets, especially chocolate chip cookies; feelings of loneliness living alone with dog, no suicidal ideation
* Past medical history: Heart attack, coronary artery disease, stage three chronic kidney disease, diabetes mellitus
* Social history: Lives with dog, describes feeling lonely
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 127/80 mmHg
* Physical exam: No jugular venous distention or carotid bruits, grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at left heart base, one plus nonpitting edema in lower extremities
* Test results: Stable kidney function (creatinine), HbA1c close to 6.0 (high), fasting glucose ~130 mg/dL, no new stress test performed

A (Assessment):

* Coronary artery disease post-left anterior descending artery stent placement
* Stage three chronic kidney disease
* Diabetes mellitus with suboptimal glycemic control
* Adjustment disorder with depressed mood, suspected

P (Plan):

* Continue aspirin lifelong and Brilinta for additional six months to prevent stent thrombosis
* Continue metoprolol 50 mg once daily and Crestor 40 mg once daily; refill all medications
* Referral to cardiac rehabilitation for supervised exercise and confidence building
* Referral to nephrologist (Dr. Miller) for CKD follow-up; schedule appointment
* Order repeat hemoglobin A1c test and refer to dietitian for diabetic dietary education
* Coordinate with primary care physician regarding insulin regimen
* Referral to psychiatry for evaluation and support related to adjustment disorder/depression
* Advise taking acetaminophen (Tylenol) for headaches instead of NSAIDs due to kidney disease
* Educate patient about dizziness related to metoprolol and importance of slow position changes
* Monitor for any recurrent chest pain or exertional shortness of breath for potential further evaluation

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Abdominal pain for one week
- History of present illness: Gradually increasing upper abdominal pain on both sides, associated with on-and-off nausea (approximately three times in the past week) and vomiting (a couple of times), worsened by physical activity such as jogging or running; recent increased coffee intake possibly contributing, also consuming a lot of spicy food recently; no fever reported
- Past medical history: Type 2 diabetes mellitus, asthma
- Medications: Currently taking metformin 500 mg twice daily, flovent twice daily, and albuterol as needed
- Social history: Moderately heavy alcohol use, advised to limit to less than 2-3 drinks per week
- Patient comments: Plans to reduce caffeine and spicy food intake, sometimes forgets to take flovent

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur (unchanged), mild epigastric tenderness, no tenderness in right lower or right upper quadrant, mild end-expiratory wheezes with excellent air movement, otherwise normal heart and lung exam, abdomen soft
- Test results: Plan to perform urinalysis, urine pregnancy test, complete blood count, and comprehensive metabolic panel (results pending)

A (Assessment):

- Acute gastritis, suspected, likely related to caffeine intake and possibly spicy food; alcohol use also contributing factor
- Type 2 diabetes mellitus
- Asthma

P (Plan):

- Prescribe Zantac (ranitidine) twice daily as needed for acid suppression and abdominal pain
- Advise reduction of caffeine intake, alcohol use limited to less than 2-3 drinks per week, and decrease spicy food consumption
- Increase metformin dose to 1000 mg in the morning and 500 mg in the evening; continue blood glucose monitoring and report readings at follow-up
- Continue flovent twice daily and albuterol as needed; encourage adherence to flovent for asthma control
- Order urinalysis, urine pregnancy test, complete blood count, and comprehensive metabolic panel
- Follow-up appointment in four weeks; patient to contact provider sooner if needed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Numbness and tingling in right hand, pain mostly while typing
* History of present illness: Symptoms on and off for six months, more persistent over the last month; numbness and tingling constant; pain occurs with keyboard and mouse use; pain relieved by rest and ibuprofen; no pain or tingling disrupts sleep
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Uses keyboard extensively for work (data entry)
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Pain with wrist flexion and extension on right hand, decreased grip strength on right hand, positive Tinel’s sign at wrist causing shooting pain on tapping
* Vital signs: No information provided
* Test results: EMG and nerve conduction study ordered (pending)

A (Assessment):

* Carpal tunnel syndrome

P (Plan):

* Prescribe wrist splint to be worn at night
* Continue ibuprofen, increase dose to 600 mg four times daily
* Order outpatient EMG and nerve conduction studies of the right wrist
* Consider physical therapy or surgery based on test results and clinical progress; conservative treatment to be tried first
* Follow-up visit to discuss EMG results and further management options

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right elbow pain
- History of present illness: Right elbow pain started about one week ago while playing lacrosse with his 13-year-old child, sharp pain at the tip of the elbow, pain radiates down the forearm, pain worsens with movement, no history of fall but possible trauma from being hit with a lacrosse stick, took Advil with some relief but often forgets to take it
- Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes
- Social history: Played lacrosse with children
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 150/70 mmHg
- Physical exam: Right elbow tender to palpation over the olecranon area, mild pain with flexion and extension, normal range of motion, lungs clear bilaterally, grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur on heart exam
- Test results: Right elbow x-ray normal, no fracture or bony abnormality

A (Assessment):

- Elbow contusion
- No new assessment provided for hypertension or diabetes

P (Plan):

- Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling
- Advise icing the elbow three times a day for 20 minutes each time
- Recommend avoiding playing lacrosse for the next couple of weeks to allow healing
- Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension
- Continue metformin 500 mg daily for diabetes
- Order HbA1c to evaluate diabetes control and consider medication adjustment after results
- Follow-up visit planned; prescriptions to be prepared by nurse

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Follow-up after acute on chronic congestive heart failure (CHF) exacerbation
- History of present illness: Patient noticed ankle swelling and severe shortness of breath leading to 911 call and hospital admission; reports improved symptoms and no shortness of breath or chest pain since hospital discharge; admits occasional missed medication doses; dietary indiscretion with high intake of cheese, pizza, and chicken wings during weekend parties despite advice to limit salt; currently compliant with medications and diet since discharge to avoid hospital readmission; performs afternoon naps without sleep problems
- Past medical history: Hypertension, stage 3 chronic kidney disease, chronic heart failure exacerbation
- Social history: Attends social gatherings on weekends with high-salt foods, enjoys football and pizza; no mention of tobacco or alcohol use
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 128/72 mmHg, heart rate 79 bpm, respiratory rate 26 breaths/min, oxygen saturation 99%
- Physical exam: No jugular venous distention; 2/6 systolic ejection murmur stable on heart exam; lungs clear bilaterally; trace edema in lower extremities
- Test results: Echocardiogram shows preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation

A (Assessment):

- Congestive heart failure exacerbation caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension, suspected
- Hypertension
- Stage 3 chronic kidney disease

P (Plan):

- Continue bumex 2 mg once daily
- Continue Cozaar 100 mg once daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily
- Advise strict dietary sodium restriction and reduction of high-salt foods including pizza and chicken wings
- Monitor weight daily; instruct patient to call if weight increases by 3 pounds in 2 days
- Refer to nutritionist for dietary education
- Order renal artery ultrasound to evaluate for secondary causes affecting kidney and hypertension
- Obtain additional blood work to monitor kidney function and medication tolerance
- Follow-up appointment scheduled in 3 months

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right ankle pain and swelling after a fall on ice yesterday
* History of present illness: Slipped on ice while taking out trash, unable to walk initially, used rest, elevation, and ice; today feels improved with some weight bearing but still limping
* Past medical history: No known previous injury to this ankle despite history of playing soccer extensively
* Social history: Plays community league soccer, children watch and participate in soccer leagues; husband also plays soccer

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No abnormality reported, described as good
* Physical exam: Ecchymosis and swelling over lateral malleolus of right ankle, tenderness to palpation anterolaterally, no laxity on anterior drawer and inversion stress tests, no bony tenderness on foot palpation; neurovascular exam intact with capillary refill <3 seconds, strong dorsalis pedis pulse, sensation intact to light touch
* Test results: Right ankle x-ray showed no fracture

A (Assessment):

* Right ankle sprain

P (Plan):

* Keep right leg elevated when seated
* Continue icing the ankle
* Provide aircast for ankle stabilization
* Provide crutches for 1 to 2 days
* Start walking as tolerated after initial period
* Continue NSAIDs (ibuprofen) as needed for pain
* Follow-up in 2 weeks to assess recovery and readiness to resume soccer
* Advise patient to contact clinic if new symptoms develop before follow-up

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Newly diagnosed elevated cholesterol
* History of present illness: Patient found elevated cholesterol on finger prick test during annual checkup; surprised by result as tries to eat clean diet and stays active by bicycling; prior borderline cholesterol noted last year with advice to watch diet
* Past medical history: No significant past medical history
* Social history: Lives independently, denies exposure to tobacco smoke at home or among friends, physically active with regular bicycle riding
* Family history: No known history of early hypercholesterolemia or anemia in parents or grandparents; cousin died of possible heart attack at age 44–45

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure normal
* Physical exam: Heart exam normal—no murmurs, rubs, or gallops; lung exam clear; eye exam—no xanthomas; neck exam—no thyroid enlargement; abdominal exam—no hepatomegaly or splenomegaly
* Test results: Total cholesterol elevated at 210 mg/dL

A (Assessment):

* Elevated cholesterol

P (Plan):

* Order full cholesterol panel, glucose, complete metabolic panel, thyroid studies, liver panel, and genetic testing to evaluate for familial or secondary causes
* Recommend follow-up in 3 to 6 months after dietary intervention and nutritionist consultation
* Advise a well-balanced diet lower in saturated fats and sugars
* Refer to nutritionist for dietary counseling
* Encourage continuation of regular physical activity, especially bicycling

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Chest pain described as pressure occurring with walking, present intermittently over the past three months
* History of present illness: Chest pain is dull, non-radiating, occurs mainly during walking and resolves with rest; no chest pain, shortness of breath, sweats, or clamminess at present
* Past medical history: Diabetes mellitus, hypertension (not formally diagnosed but previously noted elevated blood pressure)
* Social history: Attempts diet modification including reducing soda intake; no information about tobacco or alcohol use provided
* Family history: Heart disease

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No specific values provided; blood pressure trend noted to be elevated over several years
* Physical exam: No jugular venous distension, no carotid bruits, clear lung sounds without crackles or rhonchi, heart exam with 2/6 systolic ejection murmur (known), regular rate and rhythm, equal pulses, abdomen soft without tenderness or masses, no back abnormalities, +1 nonpitting edema in ankles without calf tenderness
* Test results: Electrocardiogram (ECG) normal without signs of acute myocardial infarction
* Laboratory: Last hemoglobin A1c was 7.0%; recent hemoglobin A1c ordered but results pending

A (Assessment):

* Unstable angina, suspected, given chest pain with exertion, diabetes, suspected hypertension, and family history of heart disease
* Diabetes mellitus, currently managed with metformin
* Hypertension, suspected based on elevated blood pressure trend and clinical findings
* Lower extremity edema, mild nonpitting

P (Plan):

* Cardiology referral for evaluation and stress testing of chest pain
* Start aspirin 81 mg orally once daily
* Prescribe nitroglycerin sublingual tablets to be taken at onset of chest pain during activity; up to three doses every five minutes; if pain persists, seek emergency care
* Continue metformin 500 mg twice daily for diabetes management
* Order hemoglobin A1c measurement today; follow-up in two weeks to assess diabetes control and adjust treatment if necessary
* Continue ophthalmology appointment for diabetic eye exam scheduled in two weeks
* Initiate hydrochlorothiazide low dose for hypertension and edema management
* Provide home blood pressure monitoring device; patient to record readings daily and upload via patient portal (Epic MyChart)
* Follow-up appointment in two weeks to review blood pressure log, symptoms, and medication effects
* Patient education on potential hydrochlorothiazide side effects including increased urination, possible cross-reactivity with sulfa drugs, and when to seek medical attention

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Bilateral knee pain for about six months
* History of present illness: Deep, achy pain behind kneecaps with occasional creaking sounds; pain worsens when standing up from seated position, going up and down stairs, and after prolonged sitting; pain improves with rest; decreased running tolerance from 5-6 miles daily to less than half a mile due to knee pain; no swelling or redness reported
* Past medical history: Broken arm in sixth grade; no prior knee injuries or bone fractures
* Social history: Works from home, spends a lot of time sitting at desk; enjoys outdoor running and treadmill running in winter

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No abnormalities noted; overall normal
* Physical exam: Normal gait; lower extremity muscle strength 3/5 for bilateral leg abduction, 5/5 for other muscle groups; no erythema, ecchymosis, warmth, or effusion in knees; tenderness to palpation of bilateral retinaculum; positive patellar grind test; painful squatting; Lachman, anterior/posterior drawer, and McMurray tests negative bilaterally; symmetrical patellar and Achilles reflexes
* Test results: Knee X-rays show no fractures or osteoarthritis; MRI reviewed (findings not detailed in transcript)

A (Assessment):

* Patellofemoral pain syndrome

P (Plan):

* Continue ibuprofen or other anti-inflammatory medications as needed for pain
* Initiate physical therapy focusing on lower extremity strengthening, mobility improvement, and correction of running mechanics
* Advise limiting running activity temporarily with gradual return as tolerated
* Follow-up visits planned to assess progress

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Severe low back pain started a couple of weeks ago after lifting a box of books
* History of present illness: Pain described as achy and sharp, initially localized in low back but now radiating down left leg; pain worsens with bending forward, no pain with sitting; no numbness, tingling, loss of sensation, weakness, or bladder/bowel incontinence
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Sedentary job, inconsistent exercise a few times a week, does not smoke
* Family history: Father has back pain
* Sports history: Played soccer as a midfielder

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure approximately 130/70 mmHg, respiratory rate 18/min
* Physical exam: Heart sounds normal with regular rate and rhythm, lungs clear bilaterally; midline tenderness at L4-L5 disk space, right-sided lumbar paravertebral tenderness, pain on lumbar flexion, ability to bend forward and backward present; supine straight leg raise test positive; patellar and Achilles reflexes symmetrical; no decreased sensation on neurological exam
* Test results: MRI shows disk desiccation, disk bulge with paracentral disk herniation causing moderate right neuroforaminal stenosis

A (Assessment):

* Lumbar back pain at L4-L5 due to herniated disk with radiculopathy

P (Plan):

* Recommend lumbar spine corticosteroid and strong NSAID injection under fluoroscopy for inflammation and pain relief
* Procedure offered and can be scheduled today in office
* Provide patient with informational paperwork about procedure risks and answer questions to ensure comfort

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left knee pain
* History of present illness: Injury occurred about one week ago while running with niece and fell, twisting knee; pain localized more on the medial (inside) aspect than lateral side; limping since injury with pain worsening from initial 4/10 to throbbing sensation; heard a pop at time of injury; unable to bear full weight; taking Tylenol with partial relief; unable to take ibuprofen due to history of ulcer; has been using kinesiology tape

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Edema and effusion noted in left knee; moderate range of motion with pain on flexion and extension; tenderness on medial side upon palpation; negative Lachman test; negative valgus and varus stress tests
* Test results: Left knee X-ray normal with no fractures or bony abnormalities

A (Assessment):

* Medial collateral ligament (MCL) strain of left knee

P (Plan):

* Prescribe tramadol 50 mg orally twice daily for pain control; continue Tylenol as needed for breakthrough pain within safe dosing limits
* Use knee immobilizer on left leg for one week to limit motion and reduce inflammation
* Instruct patient to ice knee 3–4 times daily for 20–30 minutes each session
* Advise avoidance of running or strenuous activity for approximately three weeks to allow healing
* Plan follow-up in a few days if symptoms worsen, with possible additional imaging such as MRI if needed
* Estimated recovery time about one month with adherence to treatment instructions

S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up for high blood pressure after emergency room visit
* History of present illness: Experienced light-headedness and near-fall while walking outdoors; blood pressure in ER was nearly 200 mmHg; headaches present during episode; blood pressure elevations occur about once weekly or monthly, often related to travel for work and poor eating habits; not regularly monitoring blood pressure during travel; mild nasal congestion attributed to seasonal allergies

* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: No carotid bruits; grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur on heart exam; lungs clear bilaterally; trace pitting edema in bilateral lower extremities

A (Assessment):

* Hypertension, uncontrolled at this time
* Depression, currently stable without medication

P (Plan):

* Increase lisinopril to 40 mg orally once daily to improve blood pressure control
* Continue home blood pressure monitoring and report readings via patient portal
* Consider addition of second antihypertensive agent if needed based on blood pressure control
* No new medication for depression at this time; patient encouraged to contact provider if issues arise
* Follow-up as needed for blood pressure management and depression monitoring

- Chief complaint: Shortness of breath and lightheadedness after a long bike ride
- History of present illness: Experienced shortness of breath and lightheadedness following a three-hour bike ride over the weekend; occasional mild chest discomfort that resolved within about an hour; no fever, cough resolved from a previous cold about a year and a half ago; no nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain

- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No family members currently sick

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Oxygenation normal (exact values not provided)
- Physical exam: Neck supple, no jugular venous distension, regular heart rhythm without murmurs, bilateral expiratory wheezes on lung auscultation, trace lower extremity edema

A (Assessment):

- Asthma exacerbation, suspected related to exercise and allergies
- Stable gastroesophageal reflux disease
- Controlled migraines

P (Plan):

- Prescribe albuterol inhaler, two puffs every four hours as needed for wheezing or shortness of breath
- Order pulmonary referral
- Continue current medications: Imitrex as needed for migraines, Protonix for reflux
- Patient education: Instructed to contact physician promptly if shortness of breath recurs
- Follow-up appointment in two weeks

* Chief complaint: Fatigue and low energy over the past couple of months
* History of present illness: Progressive tiredness and exhaustion, decreased ability to exercise compared to previous activity level of 1-2 hours/day running and climbing; denies blood in stools, dark or black stools, heavy menstrual bleeding, chest pain, shortness of breath, fever, chills, or body aches; reports mild weight loss attributed to exercise; COPD stable with occasional seasonal breathing difficulty related to allergies; congestive heart failure managed with diet and salt restriction; no leg swelling
* Past medical history: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), congestive heart failure
* Social history: Quit smoking several years ago, no current smoking
* Family history: No information provided
* Support system: Boyfriend and brother nearby

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: No cervical lymphadenopathy, slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur heard on heart exam, clear lung sounds, mild right lower quadrant abdominal tenderness on palpation, no lower extremity edema

* Anemia, etiology pending further lab work
* COPD, stable
* Congestive heart failure, stable
* Systolic ejection murmur previously noted

P (Plan):

* Order endoscopy and colonoscopy to evaluate for potential gastrointestinal bleeding
* Referral to gastroenterology for endoscopy and colonoscopy scheduling
* Continue current management for COPD including smoking cessation reinforcement; no inhalers indicated at this time
* Maintain current congestive heart failure medications: Toprol, lisinopril, and Lasix 20 mg daily
* Monitor anemia labs when available and adjust management accordingly
* Follow-up and close contact over the next week to reassess and finalize workup results

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up for chronic problems including depression, type 2 diabetes, and hypertension  
* History of present illness: Patient reports increased anxiety and stress preparing for Thanksgiving, enjoyment of social gatherings after two years but found them stressful, currently unable to continue morning walks due to cold weather and seeking alternative strategies for depression management without medication, no suicidal or homicidal thoughts  
* Past medical history: Depression, type 2 diabetes, hypertension  
* Social history: No significant details provided beyond holiday gatherings and plans for vacation to a warm place  
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure in office normal  
* Physical exam: No carotid bruits on neck exam, grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base (previously noted), lungs clear, 1+ non-pitting edema bilaterally in lower extremities  
* Test results: EKG normal with no concerning abnormalities, Hemoglobin A1c elevated at 8.0%, diabetes logs reviewed, no additional lab results provided

A (Assessment):

* Depression  
* Type 2 diabetes with inadequate glycemic control (HbA1c 8.0%)  
* Hypertension with existing systolic ejection murmur (stable, previously evaluated)

P (Plan):

* Depression: Referral to psychiatry for talk therapy only, no medication initiation at this time  
* Type 2 diabetes: Increase metformin dosage to 1000 mg twice daily, order repeat hemoglobin A1c in next two months, order lipid panel  
* Hypertension: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily, order echocardiogram to re-evaluate heart murmur  
* Patient education and encouragement to maintain blood pressure control and monitor diabetes management  
* Follow-up and routine monitoring with nursing staff as planned

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Follow-up visit for diabetes and other chronic conditions
- History of present illness: Blood sugars not well controlled, last A1c was 9.9; patient currently taking glimepiride 2 mg twice daily but advised to increase dose; reports feet pain described as "feet feel like hell," leg and hip pain; difficulty walking due to leg discomfort; no headaches, dizziness, chest pain, nausea, vomiting, or GI symptoms; recent cough with clear sputum but no fever or shortness of breath; urinary symptoms include slower urine stream, frequent urination several times per day, occasionally waking at night once to urinate; vision improved after cataract surgery but dissatisfaction with one lens
- Past medical history: Diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, vascular disease in legs, cataracts
- Social history: Currently smoking, not ready to quit; drinks seltzer water, rarely drinks soda or alcohol; diet includes wheat bread (2 slices in the morning), avoids pasta, occasional peanut butter sandwiches
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 140/60 mmHg (clinic), home readings reportedly better
- Physical exam: Carotid pulses normal, no bruits; heart rhythm regular, normal rate; S1, S2 crisp; no murmurs; lungs clear with no wheezing or crackles; extremities without edema, dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses palpable; feet with thickened nails, mildly dry skin, no skin breakdown; mildly decreased sensation on tips of first and second toes
- Test results: No new lab results provided yet; plan to check blood work and kidney function today

A (Assessment):

- Peripheral neuropathy
- Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus (A1c 9.9)
- Hypertension
- Hyperlipidemia
- Vascular disease in lower extremities
- Cataracts status post surgery

P (Plan):

- Increase glimepiride dose: take current 2 mg tablets two tablets twice daily until new prescription arrives (4 mg tablets, one twice daily)
- Continue metformin and current antihypertensive medications: metoprolol 50 mg daily, lisinopril/hydrochlorothiazide 20/25 mg daily, amlodipine 10 mg daily
- Continue atorvastatin at high dose for cholesterol management
- Monitor for hypoglycemia symptoms with dose increase; advise to report if they occur
- Advise patient to reduce carbohydrate intake further and limit bread slices
- Encourage foot care: keep feet moisturized; patient encourages use of foot scrub or cream after shower
- Plan lab work including kidney function today
- Blood pressure to be monitored; current readings variable
- Encourage smoking cessation, though patient not ready currently
- Follow-up appointment in 4 months to reassess condition and review labs
- Eye care to continue with current optometrist; consider possible laser treatment if lens issues persist

transcription:
[doctor] patient mrn : abc123 . date of birth : january 1st , 1960 . patient is a 60 year old , right-handed male , referred today for evaluation of numbness and tingling .
[doctor] hello , mr. cook . how are you doing this morning ?
[patient] hi , dr. martinez . this weekend was a bit rough . i've had this numbness and tingling for a few weeks now .
[doctor] so it's in both of your hands ?
[patient] yes , ever since my car wreck last december when i broke them ... well , once they healed , i mean , i noticed it more , the tingling and the numbness .
[doctor] and you still wear the splint only on the right wrist ?
[patient] no , i also wear the left sometimes . the right is just worse , but the splint helps . both have really gotten worse over the last month . when i broke them , my right wrist was definitely in worse shape . i've also been having some s- mild stiffness in my neck too . i hit my head during the accident , and they told me it was a contusion .
[doctor] and where would you say the tingling and numbness is ?
[patient] on this side , it goes from here and here up to about here . on the other side , it's from here to here .
[doctor] i see . so on the right side , you're pointing from the middle and ring finger , all the way up the forearm . and on the left , the symptoms extend from the pinky and ring finger . and is there any pain or just tingling and numbness ?
[patient] eh , it's mainly just sore . sometimes they throb , but overall , they feel weaker too , especially when i'm using them . the tingling happens more when they hurt , but when it goes away , the tingling is dull .
[doctor] and when do you feel these symptoms ?
[patient] well , really , i guess , just more so at night , and they come and go throughout the day .
[doctor] okay . and do you experience any loss of sensation in your hands or fingers ?
[patient] like , feeling something ? no , not that i can really think of . though , in general , they may be less sensitive than they should be , but i can still feel . they also gave me some nerve pain medicine , but i have n't been taking it like i should .
[doctor] and are you still on the coreg for hypertension and the lexapro for anxiety ?
[patient] yes , i'm still taking those . i had prediabetes too , but i got it under control by changing my diet .
[doctor] and no history of thyroid issues , correct ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] all right , thank you , mr. cook . okay , first , we'll go over your review of systems . correct me if i'm wrong in any of this .
[doctor] constitutional , you have fatigue and weight gain ; gi , you have excessive appetite and bloating ; eyes have floaters ; cardiovascular shows shortness of breath and leg swelling ; endocrine , you're always hungry ; skin , you have some nail bed changes , dryness , itching ; musculoskeletal , you have gout and muscle pain . and the remainder of the review of systems is negative .
[patient] yep , that's all correct .
[doctor] all right , we're going to go ahead and do the neurologic examination . let's look at the right hand first . can you feel this ?
[patient] yeah , but a little less on these two fingers .
[doctor] sensation is normal , except pin prick sensation diminished in third and fourth fingers on the right .
[doctor] and how about on the left ?
[patient] um , yeah , but these two a little less .
[doctor] sensation is decreased in the fourth and fifth fingers on the left
[doctor] okay , let's test your reflexes now . reflexes are 1+ and symmetric ; 2+ knees ; toes are downgoing bilaterally .
[doctor] all right , i'm going to tap on your right wrist . do you feel anything ?
[patient] yeah , it feels like a zing up my wrist and something into my elbow too .
[doctor] and how about the left side ?
[patient] yeah , same on that side too .
[doctor] tinel sign positive at both wrists and both elbows . rest of exam is normal .
[doctor] all right , so what i am seeing today is bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome or , potentially , this could also be bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome . however , your symptom presentation suggests car- bilateral carpal syndrome , as the nerve in your wrists are aggravated by your past trauma . this is causing the pain and tingling you were describing to me .
[patient] okay , so how do we make it better ?
[doctor] first , i want to determine exactly where the nerve irritation is coming from . we'll need to schedule you for a nerve test , which is called an emg test . they will measure the responsiveness of your nerves to truly pinpoint where you are having your issues .
[patient] that sounds fine to me .
[doctor] great . after the tests are complete , you can return here for a follow-up visit . if you're still having symptoms , we can consider a referral to our hand clinic , possibly for injections or carpal tunnel release se- surgery . you could also refer ... we could also refer you to an orthopedist for the same treatment .
[patient] sounds good , doc .
[doctor] all right , keep wearing your splints , and i will see you after those studies .
[patient] thank you .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Numbness and tingling in both hands
* History of present illness: Symptoms began a few weeks ago after a car accident in December with bilateral wrist fractures; tingling and numbness worsened over the last month, right wrist symptoms worse than left; mild neck stiffness since head contusion during accident; symptoms mainly at night and intermittent during the day; soreness and throbbing in wrists with weakness during use; tingling more apparent when pain is present but dull when pain improves; no significant loss of sensation reported though possible decreased sensitivity; patient wears wrist splints, mainly right but sometimes left
* Past medical history: Hypertension (on Coreg), anxiety (on Lexapro), prediabetes now controlled by diet, no thyroid issues
* Review of systems: Fatigue, weight gain, excessive appetite, bloating, floaters in eyes, shortness of breath, leg swelling, always hungry, nail bed changes, dry and itchy skin, gout, muscle pain; remainder negative
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Pinprick sensation decreased in third and fourth fingers on right hand, decreased sensation in fourth and fifth fingers on left hand; reflexes 1+ and symmetric in upper extremities, 2+ knees, toes downgoing bilaterally; Tinel sign positive at both wrists and both elbows; otherwise normal neurological exam
* Vital signs: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome, suspected
* Differential diagnosis includes bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome

P (Plan):

* Schedule nerve conduction studies including EMG to localize nerve irritation
* Continue wearing wrist splints
* Follow-up visit after nerve testing to review results
* Consider referral to hand clinic or orthopedist for possible injections or carpal tunnel release surgery if symptoms persist after testing
* Patient education about current plan and symptom management

[patient] yeah . ever since my car wreck last december when i broke them . well , once they heal , i mean , i noticed it more , the , the tingling and numbness .
[doctor] are you still wearing the splint only on your right wrist ?
[patient] no . i wear the left one also sometimes . the right one's just worse . the splint seems to help . both have gotten worse over the last month . when i broke them though , my wrist was definitely in worse shape than it is today . i've been having some mild stiffness in my neck too . i hit my head during the accident , and they told me it was a contusion .
[doctor] okay . and where exactly on the right side would you say the tingling and numbness is ?
[patient] on the right , i can really notice it from my middle and ring finger all the way up to my forearm , and on my left , a bit more the pinky and the ring and not the middle .
[doctor] all right . and , um , is there is pain or , or just tingling and numbness ?
[patient] uh , mainly just sore . sometimes they throb , but overall , they feel weaker too , especially when i'm using them . the tingling happens some more , but when they hurt , you know , it goes away and then the tingling's just dull .
[doctor] what kind of activities ?
[patient] well , really , i guess , just more so at night , and then it just kind of comes and goes throughout the day .
[doctor] okay . and do you experience any loss of sensation in your hands or fingers ?
[patient] uh , like , like feeling something ? no , not that i can think of really . in general , they might be less sensitive than they should be , but i can still feel . they gave me some nerve pain medicine , but i have n't been taking it like i should be .
[doctor] okay . looks like your medical history is notable for chronic kidney disease , gout , hypertension , anxiety , gerd , and diabetes .
[patient] well , i had pre-diabetes , but i got in under control changing my diet .
[doctor] okay . good . and are you still on the carvedilol 25 milligrams two times a day for hypertension and lexapro 10 milligrams a day for anxiety ? looks like your allergic to sulfa drugs as well . is that correct ?
[patient] yeah , i'm still taking those and sulfa just causes me to break out in a rash .
[doctor] and no history of thyroid issues , right ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] all right . thank you ms. taylor . i'll be right back for your exam . i want to look up that medication you mentioned for your nerve pain .
[patient] all right . thanks .
[doctor] review of systems , please make the following changes . uh , constitutional , patient reports fatigue and weight gain . gi , um , excessive appetite and bloating . eyes , floaters . uh , cardiovascular , shortness of breath and leg swelling . endocrine , positive diabetes , always hungry . skin , nail bed trenches , dryness , itching . musculoskeletal , gout , muscle pain . neurological , parasthesia , bilateral hands .
[doctor] um , please use the default normal neuro-physical exam with the following changes . sensations normal except pin prick sensation diminished in the third and forth fingers on the right . and the fourth and fifth fingers on the left . reflexes are one plus and symmetric , two plus knees , toes are down going bilaterally , tinel's sign positive at both wrists and both elbows .
[doctor] let's move onto assessment and plan , bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome , question of bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome . i discussed my impression with the patient , i will schedule her for emg , ncv . if her symptoms do not resolve , we can consider hand clinic referral for possible symptomatic injections or carpal tunnel release surgery although she can pursue these uh , through her current orthopedist . i encouraged her to wear her splints , returned for emg , ncv . end of note .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Bilateral hand numbness and tingling  
- History of present illness: Numbness and tingling in both hands started a few weeks ago after a car accident last December during which both hands were broken; tingling and numbness worse after splints removed, right hand worse than left; onset after wrist healing; mild neck stiffness since the accident with a prior head contusion; symptoms worse over the last month; right hand tingling and numbness mainly in middle and ring fingers up to forearm; left hand mainly pinky and ring fingers; sensations described as numbness, tingling, soreness, throbbing, weakness especially with use; tingling more at night, fluctuates during the day; no reported loss of sensation but possible reduced sensitivity; patient admitted nonadherence to prescribed nerve pain medication  
- Past medical history: Chronic kidney disease, gout, hypertension, anxiety, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), diabetes (previously pre-diabetes controlled by diet)  
- Medications: Carvedilol 25 mg twice daily for hypertension, Lexapro 10 mg daily for anxiety; not regularly taking prescribed nerve pain medication  
- Allergies: Sulfa drugs causing rash  
- Review of systems: Fatigue, weight gain, excessive appetite, bloating, floaters in eyes, shortness of breath, leg swelling, nail bed trenches, skin dryness and itching, muscle pain, bilateral hand paresthesia  

O (Objective):

- Imaging: CT brain with and without contrast dated 2/5/21 showed no metastatic disease and no acute intracranial abnormalities  
- Physical exam: Normal neurological exam except diminished pinprick sensation in the right third and fourth fingers and left fourth and fifth fingers; reflexes 1+ and symmetric in upper limbs, 2+ at knees; bilateral downgoing toes; positive Tinel’s sign at both wrists and elbows  

A (Assessment):

- Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome  
- Question of bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome  

P (Plan):

- Schedule electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction velocity (NCV) studies  
- Encourage continued use of wrist splints  
- Consider referral to hand clinic for possible symptomatic injections or carpal tunnel release surgery if symptoms persist; patient may also pursue interventions through current orthopedist  
- Educate patient on medication adherence and follow-up after EMG/NCV studies

transcription:
[doctor] michelle king , date of birth 01/05/1986 , mrnq27631 . new patient visit for acid reflux . past medical history of anxiety and seasonal allergies .
[doctor] hello , are you mrs. king ?
[patient] i am .
[doctor] i'm dr. phillips . very nice to meet you .
[patient] you as well .
[doctor] how can i help you today ?
[patient] well , my primary doctor , dr. scott , he referred me here .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] i've just got really bad acid reflux .
[doctor] okay . can you tell me more about it ?
[patient] yeah . though i mean i ... right now , i take 40 milligrams of omeprazole twice a day . some days , it is fine , but others are just really bad .
[doctor] what do you feel ?
[patient] it feels like burning .
[doctor] in your chest ?
[patient] yes , in my chest and also in my throat .
[doctor] in your throat and chest . all right . any difficulty with swallowing ? feels like food or liquids kinda get stuck ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay . that's good . any abdominal pain ?
[patient] no , not really .
[doctor] nausea or vomiting , changes in bowel movements ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] constipation , diarrhea , rectal bleeding ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] okay . very good . and how long have you had this problem ?
[patient] i've had acid reflux since i was around 12 , but it has gotten worse over the past few years .
[doctor] okay . and how long have you been on the omeprazole ?
[patient] on the way , it is now i think about a year .
[doctor] okay . do you find that it's done anything for you in the past ?
[patient] i mean , i can tell it's helped because some days , i'll be fine , and then some days , i eat something and it feels terrible .
[doctor] are there any things that make your symptoms worse that you can pinpoint , like food choices or stress ?
[patient] sure . probably stress and food choices sometimes .
[doctor] okay . what things bother you ?
[patient] spicy foods , um , so i try not to eat them too often , but sometimes even drinking a soda can cause it .
[doctor] we do know that caffeine and caffeinated beverages will do that , even sodas . um , even just the carbonation can cause that . how about tomato-based products or citrus products ?
[patient] yeah , sometimes , but i still eat them .
[doctor] okay . it's reassuring that you are n't having any difficulty swallowing , though . how's your weight been ? pretty stable ?
[patient] i'd say pretty stable , although i have n't had much of an appetite for the past two months . i have been under a lot of work stress .
[doctor] what do you do for work ?
[patient] i'm a paralegal .
[doctor] okay . and any family history of gi issues ?
[patient] um , my grandmother had esophageal cancer .
[doctor] on your mom or dad's side ?
[patient] mom's side . and my mom had some issues like acid reflux , and she was taking some medication that coats the lining of your stomach .
[doctor] okay . have you ever had an upper endoscopy ?
[patient] i think maybe when i was younger .
[doctor] but not in the last 10 years ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] have you ever tried any medication other than omeprazole ?
[patient] um , at one point i was on omeprazole and ranititine -dine . it did help . but other than that , those are the only medications i have taken .
[doctor] okay . have a seat here , and let me listen to your heart and lungs , and then we can talk about a plan for you .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so normal physical exam per my new patient template , except for well-healed abdominal surgical scars noted . what's the surgical scar here on your abdomen from ?
[patient] i always forget about that surgery . i had it when i was a baby . my mom said my intestines were twisted , so i had to have surgery when i was around one month old .
[doctor] hm , gotcha . okay . so let's talk about what you have going on . from what you've told me , it sounds like you've had a several-year history of gerd , which is the medical term for acid reflux . and recently your symptoms have been poorly controlled with the omeprazole , 40 milligrams twice daily . you've been having heartburn despite taking this medication , correct ?
[patient] yes .
[doctor] and you've identified trigger foods like spicy foods , carbonated bev- beverages , citrus , and tomato-based foods , but you have n't cut these foods out of your diet completely yet . so the first thing i'd try is changing your diet because these foods can exacerbate your gerd , even though you're taking the ppi .
[patient] okay , yeah , i could definitely do a better job of avoiding those foods .
[doctor] great . so stress is another trigger that we need to address . high stress can cause worsening of your symptoms .
[patient] yeah , stress and anxiety are definitely big problems for me .
[doctor] so working on that may help with your gerd . additionally , we can consider trying a different ppi since the only one you've tried up to this point is omeprazole . if you're okay with this , we can switch your omeprazole to nexium .
[patient] that's fine with me . i'm definitely open to trying whatever .
[doctor] perfect . i will send a prescription for nexium 40 milligrams twice daily to your pharmacy on file . i'll also recommend that you have a procedure called a egd , or upper endoscopy , to look for potential causes of the gerd . we'd sedate you and then pass a small camera through your mouth , down your throat , through your stomach , and end in the small intestines . we'd look for any ulcers or signs of precancerous or cancerous conditions that we can take biopsies at the same time if we see anything .
[patient] okay . can i schedule that today ?
[doctor] yeah . you can get scheduled at checkout desk . i'll have you follow up with me in the office for the egd so we can discuss the results and talk about how you're doing with the dietary , stress , and medication changes . how does all of that sound ?
[patient] that sounds good .
[doctor] perfect . i will walk you to the checkout desk . be sure to call my office and let me know if anything changes or if you have problems before your egd and follow-up appointment .
[doctor] please insert the procedure paragraph in the plan . i suspect that she likely has gerd with underlying functional etiology as well . reassuringly , she has no unintentional weight loss and denies any dysphagia . if her egd is normal and her symptoms pers- persist despite a trial of nexium , we can consider a trial of protonix and obtain a ph-impedance study . this will allow us to rule out abnormal acid reflux exposure and to decipher between a functional etiology and hypersensitivity .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Acid reflux
* History of present illness: Longstanding acid reflux since age 12, worsening over the past few years; currently on omeprazole 40 mg twice daily for about a year with intermittent relief; symptoms include burning sensation in chest and throat, no difficulty swallowing, no abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or bowel changes; triggers include spicy foods, carbonated beverages, citrus and tomato-based foods, and stress; decreased appetite over past two months related to work stress
* Past medical history: Anxiety, seasonal allergies, abdominal surgery as an infant for intestinal twisting
* Family history: Grandmother with esophageal cancer (maternal side), mother with acid reflux managed with stomach lining-coating medication
* Social history: Works as a paralegal, experiencing significant work-related stress

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Normal heart and lung exam, well-healed abdominal surgical scars consistent with prior surgery as an infant
* No additional vital signs or laboratory/imaging data provided

A (Assessment):

* Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), suspected with poor control on current omeprazole therapy
* Underlying functional etiology suspected

P (Plan):

* Switch acid suppressant from omeprazole 40 mg twice daily to Nexium (esomeprazole) 40 mg twice daily
* Recommend dietary modification to avoid known triggers: spicy foods, carbonated beverages, citrus, tomato-based products
* Address stress and anxiety as contributing factors to symptom exacerbation
* Schedule upper endoscopy (EGD) to evaluate for ulcers, precancerous or cancerous conditions, and allow for biopsy if indicated; procedure to be sedated and involve passing a camera from mouth to small intestines
* Follow-up appointment to discuss EGD results and response to dietary, stress, and medication changes
* If EGD is normal and symptoms persist despite Nexium, consider trial of protonix and perform pH-impedance study to differentiate abnormal acid reflux from functional etiology or hypersensitivity
* Patient advised to contact office for any change or worsening of symptoms prior to EGD or follow-up

transcription:
[doctor] . next patient is michelle king . date of birth : 05/07/1982 . please use toc template . she was admitted to district regional hospital on 06/29/2021 , and was discharged on 07/02/2021 . the patient is a 39-year-old female with history of quadriplegia due to , uh , prior spinal cord injury . she was experiencing increasing concerns for spasms and lightheadedness , significant constipation , and reported diaphoresis . she was evaluated in the emergency department where she was , uh , febrile and had significantly elevated white blood cell count of 23,000 . there were concerns for ongoing urinary tract infection , but she was treated with iv antibiotic therapy . she had labile blood pressure , headache , and vomiting . in the end , she slowly improved . she does have a supra-pubic catheter . cultures were obtained and reviewed . she was eventually discharged after clinical improvement of her symptoms . she presents today to follow up regarding these concerns . hi , michelle . how are you doing ?
[patient] not too bad . and yourself ?
[doctor] i'm good , thanks . so , it looks like you had an infection , right ?
[patient] yeah . but you know , i really do n't think it was a uti .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] i told them when i went to the er ... is that your phone ?
[doctor] it is , yeah . it listens to you and me and it does all of my documentation . it's pretty good stuff . um , tell me what's going on .
[patient] it is , in my humble opinion , that i was just constipated and that was what was causing my blood pressure to be so high . and i hardly pooped when i was there . then when i got home i had a massive poop and i felt much better . i told them that when i was admitted , and they did x-rays and everything , but they said , " no , " as they did n't think that was n't ... that was it . but you know , i felt so much better when i got home and finally pooped .
[doctor] okay . um , and the white cell count was the only thing that i think they were kind of concerned about because it was a little high .
[patient] so i wondered if automatic dysreflexia can affect the white count ?
[doctor] typically , it does n't .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] but , i mean , when i looked at the urine cultures that they checked , the cultures are not very impressive .
[patient] yeah , that's what they said .
[doctor] and when i go back and look , sometimes your white count is just elevated a little bit , and last year it was normal , so ...
[patient] hm .
[doctor] but in saying that , you know , inflammation can do that . so , yeah , you could be backed up and inflamed .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] uh , they did n't do a cat scan , they just did an x-ray . but you feel like you're back to your normal self now ?
[patient] yeah . i mean , i went in because i knew my blood pressure was out of control .
[doctor] mm-hmm .
[patient] it was giving me a headache and making me throw up . and i know , at that point , i'm at the loss of what i can do at home .
[doctor] yeah , it was good that you went in .
[patient] so i went in and they made me feel better , and then i went home , as you know .
[doctor] well , maybe that's all it was .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] so you're doing good otherwise ?
[patient] yes , i am .
[doctor] good . let me take a quick listen to you .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] all right . go ahead and take a few deep breaths . and breathe normally . now take several deep breaths . and two more . okay , good . you can relax . any pain or discomfort anywhere ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] great . so here are my thoughts .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] you may recall it was extremely hot during that period leading up to you going to the hospital . i do n't know if you were inside for the most part ?
[patient] yeah , it was pretty hot , was n't it ? and i go out a bit , but i do tend to stay in more when it's hot .
[doctor] okay . well , if you do get dehydrated even just a little bit it can lead to further , um , or worsening constipation issues .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] i've had a lot of patients over the last couple of weeks coming in with just weird stuff , and i blame that a little bit on how hot and humid it was the last two weeks of june . so what i would do is wait a couple of weeks and then , if you could , come back in and we could do some , uh , complete blood work , uh , including your white blood cells and a full panel of cholesterol , since it's been a while .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] and it should normalize , but it's too soon to do it now . um , but maybe if i put some labs in you could come in in two to three weeks ?
[patient] sure , i can do that .
[doctor] great . so that appointment will let us kill a bird ... two birds with one stone since you're due to get blood work anyways for cholesterol .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] and then , i just wanted to make sure that the white count is okay , because if it remains elevated then that means there's something else going on with your bowels .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] i do n't think that's what we'll find , but we'll see .
[patient] i mean , i knew going in that i had n't had a regular bowel movement in a while , even though i drink the miralax every day .
[doctor] yeah .
[patient] when i do n't go , i double up on that .
[doctor] have i ever given you lactulose ? it would be a medicine you use in , um , conjunction with miralax . sort of a rescue type thing .
[patient] is that the stuff that comes in a bottle ?
[doctor] yes .
[patient] then , yes . i have it . it takes about two days to work and then it's a brutal two days .
[doctor] got it . yeah , it can be a little rough , but it works .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] all right . so we have our plan . any questions ?
[patient] yeah , well , i would like to talk to you about covid , if we can .
[doctor] sure . so where are you at when it comes to the vaccine ?
[patient] i am unvaccinated .
[doctor] so what are your concerns about the vaccine ?
[patient] well , we do n't know the side effects .
[doctor] correct , we do n't .
[patient] it's too soon to tell the side effects , and i'm hearing more and more reports of people getting what's now termed as " vaccine injury " .
[doctor] right .
[patient] which i had never heard of before . i do n't know if it is a new term or not , but my take on the whole thing is that i'm young and healthy enough to beat it , even if my respiratory is limited . i also take a lot of vitamin c.
[doctor] okay .
[patient] i also take multivitamins and i'm closely monitored . so i guess i do n't feel as though i really the vaccine .
[doctor] well , my thoughts are that you actually should be vaccinated . i think you are high risk . if you get covid it's not going to be good for you .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] and i think it's safe . i mean , i understand and hear you . all of these stories out there about this , uh , regarding the vaccine . but i've seen all the bad things that could happen from covid . people have died in my practice , and i do n't disagree that if you got covid you'd probably be okay .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] but i would consider you as someone that would make me a little bit concerned . i have had healthy people die from covid .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] i've had some people get really , really sick from it . so personally , i believe that this vaccine is completely safe . i really think that .
[patient] all of them ?
[doctor] yeah , i do , i do . i think there are side effects from all vaccines , so you have to go back and think about it . do you get flu shot every year ?
[patient] no , i do n't .
[doctor] right , well , it's hard for me to convince you because you're making a consistent viewpoint .
[patient] well , i am open-minded to this .
[doctor] mm-hmm . to me , it's , you know , a lot of the stuff out there is fear and most of us health providers have gotten the vaccine . we've seen what the virus can do . i also have gotten all of my kids vaccinated .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so i'm not concerned about the side effects of this . i do n't think it does anything . um , and we have vaccinated 50 % of the country .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] the er is full of these vaccines .
[patient] i understand .
[doctor] so there are definitely potential side effects to the vaccine . i mean , there's guillain-barre , and all these things that could happen from the vaccine , but they're just very rare . my thing for you is i'm not convinced that there's alternative stuff or even the treatment we have , like the monoclonal antibodies , that will give help , but it's just my opinion .
[patient] well , that's what i'm here for .
[doctor] yeah . right now the numbers are low . even with the delta variant , when it starts mutating , it's actually good because it becomes more contagious , but less deadly .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so that's what's gon na happen with covid . that's what's mo- most of the science supports and this is how most pandemics end , is that the virus starts losing its potency .
[patient] sure .
[doctor] but think about it , and if you have any more questions you can certainly let me know , okay ?
[patient] will do .
[doctor] all right . anything else we can discuss today ?
[patient] nope . i think i'm all set . thank you .
[doctor] you're welcome . so we'll see you in two to three weeks . have a good rest of your day .
[patient] thanks , you too .
[doctor] next line heading will be " acute to chronic constipation " . she believes her hospitalization was more likely due to her dysreflexia , from her quadriplegia that typically occurs . she did have a lot of vital signs changes , including blood pressure fluctuations . the patient feels like she has a good bowel regimen , including taking the miralax regularly as a primary treatment for constipation issues as well as lactulose for severe constipation . she feels like this was less likely a true urinary tract infection and was just related to her constipation . however , we did have a good discussion regarding her leukocytosis .
[doctor] i would recommend just in the next three or four weeks to come back in for some updated fasting labs , and we'll repeat the cbc just to make sure her white blood cells tend downward . uh , next line and heading will be " quadriplegia " . um , next line and heading will be " covid vaccine status " . again , she's hesitant . we had a good discussion , and i recommended that the only true preventative mechanism for covid is the vaccine . i do not believe that supplements are necessarily going to help stave this off . i would be concerned if she does n't get the vaccine and i would consider her at high risk based on her quadriplegia status . she does not want to get covid . however , she needs to make these decisions . she is somewhat homeopathic .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Follow-up after recent hospitalization for suspected infection, concerns about spasms, lightheadedness, significant constipation, diaphoresis, labile blood pressure, headache, and vomiting
- History of present illness: Hospitalized from 06/29/2021 to 07/02/2021 for febrile episode with elevated white blood cell count (23,000), treated with IV antibiotics for presumed urinary tract infection; patient believes symptoms were due to constipation rather than UTI; felt much better after bowel movement at home; reports ongoing bowel regimen including daily Miralax and occasional lactulose for severe constipation; experienced blood pressure spikes with headache and vomiting prior to hospitalization; no current pain or discomfort; feels returned to normal self now
- Past medical history: Quadriplegia due to prior spinal cord injury; has supra-pubic catheter
- Social history: Mostly stays indoors during hot weather; unvaccinated for COVID-19; takes vitamin C and multivitamins; somewhat homeopathic
- Family history: No information provided
- Other: Expressed concerns about COVID-19 vaccine side effects and vaccine injury reports; prefers natural approach and believes she is healthy enough to handle COVID-19 without vaccination

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Labile blood pressure documented during hospitalization; no current vital signs provided
- Physical exam: Patient cooperative and comfortable; no pain or discomfort; respiratory exam with deep breaths normal; no focal findings noted
- Test results: Elevated white blood cell count 23,000 during admission; urine cultures not supportive of significant infection; prior year white blood cell count normal; no CT scan performed, only x-rays; no other lab results provided

A (Assessment):

- Acute to chronic constipation, suspected as primary cause of recent symptoms and hospitalization
- Quadriplegia secondary to prior spinal cord injury
- COVID-19 vaccine hesitancy, discussed risks and benefits

P (Plan):

- Repeat fasting blood work including complete blood count and cholesterol panel in 2 to 3 weeks to monitor white blood cell trend and overall health status
- Continue current bowel regimen with Miralax daily and lactulose as needed for severe constipation
- Patient education regarding potential risks of untreated constipation and importance of monitoring symptoms
- Discussed COVID-19 vaccination; recommended vaccination as primary preventative measure due to high-risk status from quadriplegia
- Patient to consider vaccination and follow up with any further questions or concerns
- Schedule follow-up appointment after laboratory testing in 2 to 3 weeks

[doctor] um , as far as the physical exam . scattered inflammatory papules and pustules across the upper back and posterior shoulders . there are less than 5 inflammatory papules on the forehead , cheeks , and chin . acne vulgaris is improved and well controlled on the face , but there is a mild flare on the back . recommend continuing current treatment plan for the face and initiation treatment with PanOxyl 10 % foaming wash to the back in the shower daily .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Acne follow-up
* History of present illness: Patient reports improvement of facial acne, currently uses clindamycin lotion, tretinoin cream, and 4-5% benzoyl peroxide wash on face; no use of benzoyl peroxide wash on chest and back due to lack of bother; denies redness, peeling, dryness, or irritation from medications; chest and back acne not bothersome to patient
* Patient adherence: Uses benzoyl peroxide wash and antibiotic ointment plus sunscreen moisturizer twice daily on the face
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Scattered inflammatory papules and pustules across upper back and posterior shoulders; fewer than 5 inflammatory papules on forehead, cheeks, and chin; facial acne vulgaris improved and well controlled; mild flare of acne on back

A (Assessment):

* Acne vulgaris, improved on face and well controlled
* Mild flare of acne on back

P (Plan):

* Continue current treatment for face acne: clindamycin lotion, tretinoin cream, and 4-5% benzoyl peroxide wash
* Initiate PanOxyl 10% foaming wash daily on back and chest in the shower
* Provide samples and coupons for PanOxyl 10%
* Prescribe one-year supply with refills: clindamycin with 11 refills, tretinoin cream with 3 refills
* Schedule follow-up visit in one year or as needed if medications run out or symptoms change
* Provide patient education and acne printout with treatment steps at checkout

SOAP:

* History of present illness: Six weeks status post right medial unicompartmental arthroplasty, no pain, occasional numbness on the side of the knee, no other problems reported
* Social history: Works for UPS, currently unable to return to full duties involving going up and down steps; employer offers a sitting job with breaks

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Evaluation of abnormal renal ultrasound with atrophic right kidney
* History of present illness: Patient experienced sudden right-sided abdominal pain with vomiting; initially treated as stomach virus; symptoms worsened; ultrasound revealed smaller right kidney and larger left kidney; cysts found on kidney and ovaries; swollen lymph nodes and infection detected; ongoing stomach pain and burning sensation especially after eating; occasional difficulty initiating urination; no blood in urine; burning during urination triggered by certain drinks like soda; no vomiting recently
* Past medical history: Multiple hospitalizations at age 4 for recurrent infections treated with fluids and antibiotics without definitive diagnosis; prior good health until recent symptoms
* Medications: Pepcid 40 mg daily, Claritin for allergies
* Family history: Renal disease in father (with kidney transplant), great aunt with end-stage renal disease and chronic kidney disease stage five related to diabetes and hypertension, mother with breast cancer
* Social history: Active in softball, planning to join drill team; drinks primarily Gatorade or water to avoid urinary burning
* Review of systems: Abdominal pain with burning, occasional difficulty starting urination, no hematuria

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Well-appearing 14-year-old female, alert and oriented, sitting comfortably without acute distress; heart and lung exam normal
* Vital signs: No specific values provided, reported normal blood pressure
* Test results: Renal ultrasound showing atrophic (small) right kidney and compensatorily enlarged left kidney; cysts noted on kidney and ovaries; swollen lymph nodes; no clinically significant mutations found on prior genetic testing; kidney function currently good
* Other: No proteinuria or hematuria reported or observed; family history records reviewed

A (Assessment):

* Abnormal renal ultrasound showing atrophic right kidney with compensatory hypertrophy of left kidney
* Increased risk for hypertension and proteinuria due to solitary functioning kidney
* No acute renal failure or infection identified at present

P (Plan):

* Annual monitoring with renal ultrasound, urinalysis for protein and blood, and blood pressure checks
* Avoid non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen; prefer acetaminophen for pain
* Recommend maintaining good hydration with at least 2 liters of water daily, especially during sports activities
* Continue healthy diet and active lifestyle
* Follow-up with primary care physician or adult nephrologist near home for ongoing care
* Patient and family education about risk factors and symptom monitoring; advised to call if symptoms worsen or new concerns arise
