SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Left lower back pain
- History of present illness: Persistent left lower back pain since back surgery in November 2020, pain sometimes occurs on the right side depending on the day, worse with bending over and weight-bearing, relieved by stretching, pain can happen randomly
- Past medical history: Back surgery (microdiscectomy for a broken disk connected to spinal thecal sac) in November 2020, previous severe nerve pain down leg, history of gabapentin use and difficult withdrawal
- Medications tried: Ibuprofen 800 mg daily for pain relief
- Social history: No additional information provided
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: No pain with forward flexion or extension of the back, pain present on standing and tenderness to palpation at left L5 region, no pain on right side palpation, normal dorsiflexion strength and range of motion, no leg pain or nerve symptoms
- Test results: X-ray of spine shows no fractures, surgical site healed properly with no abnormalities

A (Assessment):

- Muscle pull due to spinal misalignment causing left lower back pain

P (Plan):

- Prescribe physical therapy at VA facility
- Prescribe meloxicam for pain management instead of ibuprofen
- Referral to pain management for discussion of pain control options without narcotics
- Prescribe Demerol as requested for pain management

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Sudden visual distortions and blurring of vision
* History of present illness: Decrease in vision when reading, straight lines and door frames appear crooked, difficulty adjusting to dim lights in restaurants
* Social history: Currently smoking a pack of cigarettes a day, has tried to stop smoking but struggles to quit
* Past medical history: No explicit information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Anterior segment examination shows posterior chamber intraocular lenses in both eyes, clear corneas with no MVI, right eye cup-to-disc ratio 0.2, left eye cup-to-disc ratio 0.3; fundus exam right eye shows retina attached 360°, no tears or holes, drusen in macula, retinal thickening, subretinal fluid, exudates, and hemorrhage; left eye retina attached with no hemorrhage or subretinal fluid, no PE changes in fovea
* Test results: OCT shows drusen deposits, retinal pigment epithelium changes, subretinal fluid accumulation, choroidal neovascular membrane visualization; fluorescein angiography reveals focal leakage areas in right eye consistent with neurovascular age-related macular degeneration

A (Assessment):

* Neurovascular (wet) age-related macular degeneration, diagnosed and described as advanced stage with potential for severe vision loss

P (Plan):

* Administer monthly intravitreal injections of Lucentis after numbing the eye
* Educate patient that treatment may slow or stop further vision loss but disease progression and vision loss can continue despite therapy
* Emphasize importance of regular follow-up and monitoring
* Encourage blood pressure monitoring and maintaining a log
* Address smoking cessation efforts (patient has difficulty quitting)

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right ankle pain after twisting injury
* History of present illness: Patient fell during a mountain biking lesson, twisted right ankle outward, experienced a crack sound at the time of injury, pain localized to outer right ankle, some numbness reported elsewhere (heart area), inability to walk well, limping present, no tingling in toes, took Tylenol without pain relief
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Mountain biking for about three years
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Temperature 98.6°F, blood pressure 118/77 mmHg, heart rate 77 bpm, no current fever or chills reported
* Physical exam: Right lateral malleolus shows edema, erythema, ecchymosis, and excoriations; tenderness to palpation; decreased flexion, extension, internal and external rotation of right ankle; no injury to knee or foot observed
* Test results: Right ankle X-ray shows no acute fracture or bony abnormality; soft tissue injury present

A (Assessment):

* Acute right ankle sprain

P (Plan):

* Apply air cast to right ankle
* Provide crutches for ambulation
* Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily
* Advise icing area 20 minutes, five times per day
* Weight-bear as tolerated
* Anticipate improvement within a few weeks
* Plan follow-up if no improvement to consider physical therapy or further imaging

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Post-heart attack recovery, feeling better but not perfect
* History of present illness: Underwent stent placement in right coronary artery after heart attack, hospitalized for about 48 hours, no chest pain since stent placement except mild soreness shortly after surgery, shortness of breath on exertion such as climbing stairs, limited physical activity with mostly light work and resting, trying to watch diet with occasional pizza consumption on weekends
* Past medical history: Recent inferior myocardial infarction treated with stent placement
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 127/60 mmHg
* Physical exam: No jugular venous distention, no carotid bruits, grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base, lungs clear bilaterally, right radial artery catheterization site clean, dry, intact with no hematoma and palpable pulse
* Test results: Echocardiogram shows ejection fraction approximately 50% (low normal), mild mitral regurgitation observed

A (Assessment):

* Inferior myocardial infarction
* Mild mitral regurgitation

P (Plan):

* Continue aspirin lifelong until further notice
* Continue Brilinta twice daily for at least one year
* Continue Crestor 40 mg once daily
* Continue Toprol 50 mg once daily
* Schedule repeat echocardiogram in 6 months
* Order liver function studies and lipid panel for follow-up
* Enroll patient in cardiac rehabilitation for exercise guidance and dietary counseling
* Advise gradual return to swimming with light laps, as catheterization site is healing well
* Follow-up appointment in 6 weeks

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right knee pain following a fall from a tandem bike
* History of present illness: Fell off a tandem bike about two weeks ago, hitting right knee on a curb; initial soreness treated with ibuprofen and band-aid; persistent daily pain, described as medial knee pain worsened by walking up inclines; occasional sensation of the knee shifting or clicking; no prior knee issues
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Works in a children's hospital as a baby rocker; regular walking with dog; swims occasionally; no current athletic activities beyond work-related tasks and walking
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Medial joint line tenderness on right knee, small dime-sized abrasion over medial patella (~1 week old), no deformities, full and symmetric range of motion with some pain and occasional clicking on extension; medial collateral ligament intact, lateral collateral ligament intact; about 1+ laxity on posterior drawer test, normal anterior drawer and negative Lachman test; negative McMurray test bilaterally; patella tracks well without crepitus; popliteal space nontender; no swelling reported besides residual swelling noted by clinician
* Imaging: Right knee X-rays show normal bone edges, no bone spurs, no fractures, good kneecap tracking, normal joint space indicating healthy cartilage

A (Assessment):

* Suspected posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury of the right knee
* Possible concomitant meniscal injury or cartilage chip, needs MRI for further evaluation

P (Plan):

* Order right knee MRI to evaluate internal structures including ligaments, menisci, and cartilage
* Initiate trial of knee brace (temporary, non-custom) for support
* Prescribe physical therapy referral to restore motion, reduce swelling, and strengthen knee; initial therapy frequency to be determined by therapist with monitoring of patient progress
* Continue ibuprofen as tolerated up to three times daily for short-term pain control; alternative prescription medication offered for easier dosing if needed, to be called in to pharmacy
* Recommend ice packs multiple times daily to reduce swelling
* Advise avoiding swimming until reassessment
* Schedule follow-up visit in 4 to 6 weeks to reassess knee status and response to conservative management
* Surgery not currently indicated unless instability or symptoms persist after conservative therapy completion

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left arm pain and chest pain
* History of present illness: Left elbow pain starting since yesterday, described as achiness and heaviness extending from elbow up to the neck and along the arm; no known trauma or unusual activity, only usual work around the house and mowing grass; intermittent chest pain on the same side, aching and comes and goes, started yesterday, frequency a few times a day; no shortness of breath reported
* Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes mellitus
* Medications: Norvasc 2.5 mg, Metformin 500 mg
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure 150/90 mmHg during visit, previously reported average blood pressure around 125/72 mmHg
* Physical exam: Heart auscultation revealed a slight murmur not heard before
* Test results: Last HbA1c 7.2%; current blood glucose test planned; EKG planned due to concern for cardiac event

A (Assessment):

* Chest pain, concern for mild heart attack, suspected
* Hypertension, controlled with Norvasc 2.5 mg
* Diabetes mellitus, HbA1c 7.2%, on Metformin 500 mg

P (Plan):

* Obtain EKG immediately to evaluate chest and arm pain etiology
* Administer aspirin and nitroglycerin to address possible cardiac ischemia
* Perform point-of-care glucose test to assess current diabetic control
* Continue current medications: Metformin 500 mg and Norvasc 2.5 mg
* Close monitoring of blood pressure, encourage home monitoring with a blood pressure cuff
* Depending on EKG results, call emergency services (911) if acute cardiac event is confirmed
* Patient education regarding importance of testing and immediate evaluation of chest pain symptoms
* Follow-up plans to adjust diabetes medication based on glucose results

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Abdominal pain
* History of present illness: Abdominal pain started about 10 days ago with mild right-sided discomfort, worsening over the last few days especially after meals, pain level generally 4-5/10 with peaks up to 7-8/10, localized mostly to right side with occasional slight radiation to the left, associated with nausea and heartburn but no vomiting, no urinary symptoms or bowel changes, tenderness on palpation and certain positions worsen pain, decreased appetite due to nausea, increased fatigue over the past week, chills but no documented fever
* Past medical history: Chronic migraines, hypertension
* Social history: No recent travel or unusual exposures, no alcohol binges or unusual eating habits recently
* Medications: Excedrin migraine as needed, sumatriptan as needed, lisinopril 20 mg daily
* Current status of chronic conditions: Migraines are rare and mostly responsive to over-the-counter analgesics, hypertension reportedly well controlled with blood pressure readings usually in the 120s-130s/70s range

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Mildly elevated blood pressure today, exact values not provided
* Physical exam: Grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur unchanged from prior, otherwise normal cardiovascular exam; abdomen soft except mild to moderate tenderness in right upper quadrant with equivocal Murphy’s sign, no right lower quadrant tenderness, no costovertebral angle tenderness; remainder of exam unremarkable
* Test results: No test results available yet; blood tests (CBC, chem12), urinalysis, pregnancy test, and right upper quadrant ultrasound ordered today

A (Assessment):

* Acute abdominal pain with right upper quadrant tenderness, possible gallstones or gallbladder infection suspected
* Chronic migraines, stable with current management
* Hypertension, controlled

P (Plan):

* Order CBC, chemistry panel, urinalysis, pregnancy test, and right upper quadrant ultrasound immediately; monitor results and consider emergency referral if indicated
* Keep patient nil per os (NPO) until evaluation complete in case surgical intervention needed
* Continue Excedrin migraine as needed and sumatriptan as needed; provide refill for sumatriptan
* Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily; provide refill prescription, advise daily blood pressure monitoring
* Follow-up appointment in approximately 4 weeks; physician to review test results and adjust plan accordingly

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Hacking cough for about three days
- History of present illness: Gradual onset cough starting three days ago after exposure to sister with similar symptoms, now productive with green phlegm; associated sore throat and nasal congestion; no fever, no shortness of breath, no body aches, no nausea or vomiting
- Past medical history: Type 2 diabetes mellitus, newly started on metformin 500 mg; hypertension
- Social history: Recently returned from vacation last week
- Family history: Sister currently ill with similar respiratory symptoms; otherwise family members well
- Current medications: Metformin 500 mg, hydrochlorothiazide
- Symptom management: Drinking lots of water, taking over-the-counter cough medication without relief
- Allergies/seasonal history: Seasonal allergies in spring with sneezing and runny nose
- Blood sugar monitoring: Blood sugars around 120 mg/dL, tolerating metformin well without diarrhea
- Blood pressure monitoring: Reports home blood pressure readings around 140/70 mmHg, taking hydrochlorothiazide daily, attempting to limit salty foods but struggling with sugar intake

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 144/72 mmHg, otherwise vitals within normal limits (exact other vitals not provided)
- Physical exam: No frontal sinus tenderness, mild bilateral maxillary sinus tenderness; erythematous pharynx, symmetrical tonsils without exudate; anterior cervical lymphadenopathy; heart with regular rate and rhythm, grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base; lungs clear to auscultation without wheezes, rales, or rhonchi; no lower extremity edema

A (Assessment):

- Upper respiratory infection, likely viral
- Type 2 diabetes mellitus, stable on metformin
- Hypertension with elevated blood pressure readings, current hydrochlorothiazide dose low

P (Plan):

- Upper respiratory infection: Supportive care with continued hydration, rest, and symptomatic treatment; consider switching to Coricidin HBP as cough medication due to blood pressure and diabetes; COVID-19 testing to be performed today
- Type 2 diabetes mellitus: Continue metformin 500 mg once or twice daily as tolerated; follow-up hemoglobin A1c testing at next visit in approximately three months
- Hypertension: Increase hydrochlorothiazide dose to 25 mg once daily in the morning; continue regular home blood pressure monitoring multiple times per week; dietary advice to limit sodium and sugar intake continued
- Follow-up: Review COVID-19 test results and reassess blood pressure and diabetes control at next visit

* History of present illness: Left shoulder pain started without specific injury, associated with physical activity and basement renovation, no history of trauma or fall, pain is constant and worsens with movement or pressure, especially when lying on left side; unable to raise arm overhead due to pain; pain level 7/10 without tylenol, 2-3/10 with tylenol; taking two extra strength tylenol every 6-8 hours with some relief
* Past medical history: Occasional aches and pains managed with tylenol previously, no prior significant shoulder pain
* Social history: Very active lifestyle, engaged in home renovation
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Reviewed and normal (no specific values provided)
* Physical exam: Limited active and passive range of motion in left shoulder, tenderness over greater tuberosity of humerus, no tenderness over sternoclavicular or clavicular joints, good bilateral hand grip strength, brisk capillary refill <3 seconds, intact motor and sensation to light touch in left arm
* Test results: Left shoulder X-ray shows no fracture or bony abnormality

A (Assessment):

* Rotator cuff tendinopathy, suspected

P (Plan):

* Order MRI of left shoulder to evaluate tendon injury further
* Refer to physical therapy for approximately 6-8 weeks
* Continue acetaminophen (tylenol) as needed for pain management
* Consider steroid injection if symptoms do not improve after physical therapy
* Follow-up visit planned in about two weeks

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right knee pain after playing basketball
- History of present illness: Right knee popped during basketball rebound, with immediate swelling and difficulty walking; pain described as achy, located on inside of right knee, pain level about 4/10; swelling decreased overnight; able to bear weight now but favors leg; took Tylenol with little relief
- Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes mellitus
- Social history: Played basketball for the first time in two years
- Medications: Norvasc 5 mg daily for hypertension, Metformin 500 mg daily but taken irregularly due to stomach upset
- Patient reports occasional blood glucose checks with levels around 150 mg/dL, infrequent monitoring
- Dietary habits: Eats anything wanted, no restrictions
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure approximately 140/80 mmHg
- Physical exam: Right knee with medial tenderness to palpation, mild swelling, edema, ecchymosis, and slight redness; painful on bending and straightening; negative varus and valgus stress tests; lung sounds normal; heart exam reveals grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur known for several years
- Test results: Right knee x-ray normal without fractures or bony abnormalities; recent HbA1c 7.2%

A (Assessment):

- Medial collateral ligament (MCL) strain of right knee, possible tear pending MRI evaluation
- Hypertension, blood pressure elevated above goal despite Norvasc 5 mg daily
- Type 2 diabetes mellitus with suboptimal control (HbA1c 7.2%), poor medication adherence and irregular glucose monitoring

P (Plan):

- Right knee: Continue Tylenol for pain, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg for pain and swelling, apply knee immobilizer, advise non-weight-bearing for next two weeks, order MRI of right knee to evaluate MCL injury
- Hypertension: Increase Norvasc dose to improve blood pressure control, aim for target of 120/80 mmHg
- Diabetes: Initiate daily blood glucose monitoring with log book, refer to nutrition consult for dietary improvement, counsel on adherence to Metformin or consider alternative if gastrointestinal side effects persist
- Follow-up: Return visit in two weeks for reassessment and review of blood pressure, glucose logs, and knee MRI results

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Elevated and fluctuating blood pressures
- History of present illness: Blood pressure usually well controlled over the last 3 to 4 weeks; occasional lightheadedness and slight headache; episodic systolic blood pressure readings occasionally over 180; lightheadedness occurs with high blood pressure readings; no recent syncope; occasional mild chest heaviness without sustained pain; no respiratory difficulty; mild unsteadiness and slight headache when blood pressure elevated; dizziness described as lightheadedness without vertigo; no fever, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea; no palpitations or heart racing
- Past medical history: Essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, osteoarthritis
- Social history: Uses pillbox and medication app to track medications; grandson assisted with app setup; moderate alcohol intake advised to limit to no more than two drinks per week due to blood pressure fluctuations
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No specific numerical vitals provided
- Physical exam: Grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur unchanged from prior; mild bibasilar rales without wheezes or rhonchi; excellent air movement; trace bilateral lower extremity edema; otherwise unremarkable exam
- Test results: No current lab results; blood tests ordered including cholesterol panel, CBC with differential, comprehensive metabolic panel, and urinalysis

A (Assessment):

- Elevated blood pressure, uncontrolled
- Hyperlipidemia
- Osteoarthritis

P (Plan):

- Increase lisinopril to 60 mg twice daily
- Add hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg once daily
- Monitor blood pressure twice daily for 2 weeks
- Follow-up visit in 2 weeks for blood pressure evaluation
- Continue atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia
- Order cholesterol panel, CBC with differential, comprehensive metabolic panel, and urinalysis to assess kidney function and lipid profile
- Encourage continued physical activity including walking and golfing as tolerated for osteoarthritis
- Use acetaminophen (Tylenol) as needed for mild osteoarthritis pain
- Advise adequate hydration with 6–8 glasses of water daily, increasing fluid intake with warmer weather or increased activity
- Recommend limiting alcohol intake to no more than two drinks per week due to blood pressure concerns
- Follow-up appointment scheduled in 2 weeks

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Left-sided back pain of variable character, some days sharp, some days not, sometimes moving
* History of present illness: Recurrent sore throats diagnosed as strep throat approximately four times in the last five months, occasional waking at night to urinate more frequently, increased water intake, no change in appetite or fatigue reported
* Past medical history: Recurrent strep infections
* Social history: Rides a bike occasionally, brother smokes at home despite being asked not to, changing jobs with no insurance coverage in new job
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Throat without erythema or swelling, tonsils midline, no cervical lymphadenopathy, clear lung sounds without wheezes, rales, or rhonchi, normal heart sounds without murmur, rub, or gallop, no tenderness on palpation of left back or abdomen, no rebound or guarding abdominally
* Test results: CT scan shows findings concerning for glomerulonephritis with some swelling suggestive of possible kidney involvement

A (Assessment):

* Glomerulonephritis, suspected secondary to recurrent streptococcal infections

P (Plan):

* Refer to ENT for evaluation and possible tonsillectomy to address recurrent strep infections
* Order laboratory tests including lipid panel, urinalysis, comprehensive metabolic panel, complete blood count, vitamin D level, and thyroid stimulating hormone level
* Advise fasting before blood tests; patient to complete labs as soon as possible
* Follow-up appointment scheduled in one week; telehealth follow-up possible if results are normal
* No vaccinations administered today
* Patient education on importance of managing recurrent infections and potential dietary considerations related to kidney health

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Cough lasting about one week with worsening symptoms over the last two days, producing yellow sputum
* History of present illness: Feeling generally unwell for two days, no measured fever but subjective warmth, no chills, occasional achiness, congestion with postnasal drainage and sinus pressure, no shortness of breath, twisted right knee after falling down four to five stairs this morning due to coughing, right knee pain mostly on the inside with a mild limp, able to walk and bend/straighten knee, no sensation of instability in knee
* Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes mellitus
* Medications: Lisinopril 20 mg daily, Metformin 1000 mg twice daily, over-the-counter cough and cold medications (e.g., DayQuil)
* Social history: Works as a teacher, no other household members currently sick
* Other: Does not monitor blood pressure at home, does not monitor blood sugars nor watches sugar or salt intake

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Temperature 98.4°F, blood pressure 125/62 mmHg, heart rate in the 80s, oxygen saturation 97% on room air
* Physical exam: Facial tenderness to palpation bilateral maxillary sinuses, nasal turbinates erythematous and edematous with yellow discharge, throat without erythema, edema, or exudate, bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, lung exam with coarse rhonchi bilaterally that clear with cough, heart exam normal rate and rhythm without murmur, right knee shows pain to palpation, decreased flexion and extension, ecchymosis medially, no effusion
* Imaging/tests ordered: Right knee X-ray ordered, lipid panel and hemoglobin A1c to be ordered

A (Assessment):

* Viral upper respiratory infection with probable mild bronchitis
* Right medial collateral ligament strain, suspected from recent fall
* Hypertension, ongoing management
* Diabetes mellitus, ongoing management

P (Plan):

* For cough and bronchitis: Continue supportive care, prescribe guaifenesin 600 mg twice daily, no antibiotics at this time, advise to call if symptoms worsen for possible chest X-ray
* For right knee injury: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily, refer to physical therapy for strengthening, order right knee X-ray to rule out fracture
* For hypertension: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily, order lipid panel for further evaluation
* For diabetes: Order hemoglobin A1c, encourage monitoring of sugar intake and blood glucose reporting through patient portal
* Follow-up: Results to be communicated after tests; patient encouraged to report symptoms and adhere to management plan

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Headaches and high blood pressure
- History of present illness: On and off throbbing headaches on the top of the head for about one month, associated occasional dizziness and blurry vision, headaches relieved by Tylenol; has a history of high blood pressure treated with chlorthalidone but medication adherence poor due to stomachache; diabetes present with poor adherence to metformin (taken approximately every other day)
- Social history: Eats a high sodium diet including frequent fast food (McDonald's, Filet-O-Fish); ate a lot of kids’ Easter candy recently
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 172/98 mmHg, heart rate normal, oxygen saturation normal
- Physical exam: No jugular venous distention, no carotid bruits, lungs clear bilaterally, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur unchanged from last year, slight bilateral upper extremity edema, 1+ pitting edema bilaterally in legs
- Test results: Blood glucose approximately 170 mg/dL fasting

A (Assessment):

- Uncontrolled hypertension
- Diabetes mellitus, elevated blood glucose levels

P (Plan):

- Continue current chlorthalidone medication with encouragement to improve adherence; suggest setting daily medication reminders (e.g., phone reminder)
- Monitor blood pressure at home three times per week; recommend purchase of a home blood pressure monitor
- Schedule follow-up in one month to assess blood pressure control and medication adherence
- Refer to nutritionist for dietary counseling focused on reducing sodium intake and healthier food alternatives
- Increase metformin dose to 1500 mg daily; continue regular blood glucose monitoring to assess effectiveness of medication adjustment

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Chronic back pain for about two years
- History of present illness: Pain started after a hard fall during basketball, sharp pain rated 7/10, throbbing sometimes, radiates down left leg with occasional toe numbness, occasional weakness when standing or standing too long, lying on side alleviates pain, standing worsens pain, one episode of fecal incontinence
- Past medical treatment: Previous spinal injections (unsure type), physical therapy with minimal benefit, pain medications including an unidentified "white pill" that was somewhat effective
- Social history: Currently sedentary, gained approximately 80 pounds in the past year, former smoker (details not provided), currently not smoking
- Family history: Distant relative with scoliosis (fourth cousin), no immediate family history of spinal conditions

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No specific values provided; physician notes patient is in approximately the 95th percentile for weight
- Physical exam: Regular heart rate and rhythm without murmurs; no overlying skin erythema or bruising of the back; midline tenderness at L4-L5 disk space with right-sided lumbar paravertebral tenderness; pain on lumbar flexion and mild pain on extension; positive straight leg raise test on the right; decreased sensation to light touch at right lateral thigh (L4 dermatome); symmetrical patellar and Achilles reflexes
- Imaging: MRI shows disk desiccation, disk bulge with paracentral disk herniation at L4-L5 causing moderate right foraminal stenosis

A (Assessment):

- Chronic lumbar back pain consistent with herniated disk at L4-L5 with radiculopathy

P (Plan):

- Recommend spinal injection of corticosteroid under fluoroscopy
- Provide prescription for anxiolytic medication to be taken approximately three hours before the injection to reduce procedure anxiety
- Monitor pain after injection; if pain persists, consider pain medication with caution due to prior limited effectiveness and avoidance of long-term use
- Discuss surgery as a future option only if conservative treatments fail
- Patient to schedule injection procedure at front desk; procedure expected to be quick (~1 hour) with possibility of up to four injections per year if effective

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right shoulder pain
* History of present illness: Right shoulder pain began about three weeks ago after falling while painting on a ladder and bracing herself; able to move arm but pain with raising arm overhead; pain is intermittent but present all the time; initial numbness and tingling resolved; pain rated 6/10 without medication and decreases to 4/10 with ibuprofen
* Past medical history: No previous right shoulder pain reported
* Social history: Engaged in house remodeling work (painting)

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No abnormality noted
* Physical exam: Limited active and passive range of motion of right shoulder, tenderness at the greater tuberosity of the humerus, no tenderness at sternoclavicular joint, strong bilateral hand grips, brisk capillary refill under 3 seconds, equal and bilateral sensation and touch response in right arm
* Test results: Right shoulder X-ray showed no fracture or bony abnormality

A (Assessment):

* Rotator cuff tendinopathy, suspected

P (Plan):

* Order MRI of right shoulder to evaluate further
* Refer to physical therapy for 6 to 8 weeks
* Continue NSAIDs as tolerated
* Take acetaminophen for pain relief
* Follow-up visit in 2 weeks to evaluate progress and consider additional treatments such as steroid injection if needed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Vision changes, trouble with right eye
* History of present illness: Difficulty adjusting to dark or dim environments, decreased vision when reading especially in dark places, straight lines appear crooked or wavy for about 3 to 4 months worsening over time
* Social history: Smoking about a pack a day with multiple unsuccessful quit attempts (hypnosis, lozenges, chewing gum)
* Past medical history: History of high blood pressure, nonadherent to blood pressure medication currently not taking pills regularly

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Anterior segment exam shows posterior chamber intraocular lenses in both eyes; right eye cornea clear, no neovascularization of the iris (NVI), cup to disc ratio 0.2; left eye cornea clear, no NVI, cup to disc ratio 0.3
* Fundus exam right eye: Retina attached 360 degrees, no holes or tears, retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) changes in the fovea, drusen in the macula, retinal thickening, presence of subretinal fluid and exudate accumulation, positive for hemorrhage
* Fundus exam left eye: Retina attached appropriately, RPE changes in the fovea, no hemorrhage or subretinal fluid noted
* Diagnostic tests: Optical coherence tomography (OCT) shows drusen deposits under the RPE, subretinal fluid accumulation, choroidal neovascular membrane in the right eye; fluorescein angiography reveals focal leakage consistent with neovascular age-related macular degeneration in the right eye

A (Assessment):

* Neovascular (wet) age-related macular degeneration, advanced stage

P (Plan):

* Monthly intravitreal injections of Lucentis (ranibizumab) into the vitreous of the right eye after numbing for pain control
* Emphasize adherence to blood pressure medication starting immediately, with strategies to improve compliance
* Strongly advise smoking cessation and reduction efforts
* Schedule and administer first Lucentis injection today
* Patient education on disease progression, treatment benefits, and possible outcomes including slowed vision decline but potential for some vision loss

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right knee pain and swelling after skiing injury
* History of present illness: Patient sustained injury during skiing when skis caught in snow, causing a partial cartwheel and a popping sensation in the right knee on the previous Saturday; knee is swollen, painful especially with movement, able to walk a little; also reports mild bruising and tenderness in left shoulder after fall onto that shoulder
* Past medical history: No previous knee injuries
* Social history: Skiing recreationally; trip to Mount Saint Helens, Washington recently
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Temperature 97.9°F, heart rate 64/min, respiratory rate 16/min, blood pressure 110/74 mmHg, oxygen saturation 98%
* Physical exam: Right knee with edema and ecchymosis, positive pain to palpation, mild pain with flexion and extension but full range of motion with tightness; left shoulder with bruising and tenderness on raising the arm, mild tenderness on movement without limitation
* Test results: Right knee and left shoulder x-rays show no fractures or bony abnormalities

A (Assessment):

* Knee contusion

P (Plan):

* Rest and avoid weight-bearing as much as possible
* Apply ice to right knee 2–3 times daily for 20 minutes per session
* Take NSAIDs such as ibuprofen every 6–8 hours as needed for pain and inflammation
* Monitor symptoms; if no improvement, consider physical therapy
* Left shoulder: maintain observation and await x-ray results; no immediate treatment changes
* Follow-up visit as needed based on symptom progression or additional findings

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Shortness of breath, painful swallowing
* History of present illness: Stage three non-small cell lung cancer diagnosed recently, experiencing shortness of breath worsening over the weekend limiting usual physical activity (unable to walk down the street as before), dry cough without phlegm, no fever, pain on swallowing without food impaction, able to take liquids though with some difficulty due to pain, nausea and fatigue following recent chemotherapy dose, controlled by prescribed Zofran
* Past medical history: Stage three non-small cell lung cancer, undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide and radiation therapy
* Social history: Lives with husband and daughter, husband provides support, emotionally devastated by diagnosis but feels supported

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Normal, pulse oximetry normal
* Physical exam: No cervical or subclavicular lymphadenopathy, regular heart rate and rhythm without murmurs, bilateral faint crackles on deep inspiration in lungs, erythema on anterior left chest wall consistent with radiation burn, no lower extremity edema
* Test results: Chest X-ray showing mild radiation pneumonitis

A (Assessment):

* Stage three non-small cell lung cancer
* Radiation pneumonitis
* Odynophagia secondary to radiation-induced inflammation

P (Plan):

* Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation therapy (currently at 45 Gray)
* Prescribe prednisone 40 mg orally once daily for 5 days to reduce lung inflammation
* Prescribe lidocaine oral viscous solution four times daily for painful swallowing
* Emphasize hydration with liquids and nutrition support during treatment
* Follow-up in two weeks after medication initiation

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right flank pain radiating to groin for 2 weeks
* History of present illness: Intermittent pain worsens with certain activities and fluid intake, pain score 1-2/10 usually, peaks at 4/10, no pain on urination, no hematuria, one episode of pain radiating to testicle which subsided, no nausea or vomiting, possible chills without fever
* Past medical history: History of kidney stones, passed some spontaneously and required surgery several times
* Family history: Multiple family members with kidney stones
* Social history: Very active lifestyle

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure slightly elevated (attributed to pain)
* Physical exam: Abdomen non-tender on palpation, right costovertebral angle (CVA) tenderness present
* Test results: CT scan shows 0.5 cm stone in proximal right ureter, no hydronephrosis observed

A (Assessment):

* Kidney stone in proximal right ureter

P (Plan):

* Continue ibuprofen for pain control
* Prescribe tramadol 50 mg for breakthrough pain as needed
* Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate stone passage
* Use urine strainer to catch stone during urination
* Order basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture to assess for possible infection
* Follow-up in 1-2 weeks to reassess symptoms and stone status
* Discuss further treatments such as lithotripsy if stone not passed or symptoms persist

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Shortness of breath for about one week
- History of present illness: Shortness of breath worsened over the past week, similar episode about six months ago treated with increased Lasix dose; swelling in legs; nocturia increased to one or two times per night; shortness of breath mainly on exertion such as walking or stairs; requires two pillows to sleep but no current episodes of waking up short of breath
- Past medical history: Coronary artery disease with a stent placed in 2018, reduced ejection fraction (~35%), stage 3 chronic kidney disease; prior knee pain managed occasionally with Motrin
- Social history: Dietary indiscretion during recent holidays with poor salt intake adherence, occasional use of Motrin for foot pain; not using Motrin regularly
- Family history: No information provided
- Additional complaints: Foot pain in the area in front of the big toe lasting 4–5 days, resolved; no history of gout known; ineffective pain relief from Tylenol

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 135/80 mmHg
- Physical exam: Jugular venous distention ~9 cm, no carotid bruits; bibasilar crackles with occasional rhonchi that clear on cough; 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base; bilateral 1–2+ pitting edema on lower extremities
- Test results: No current imaging or labs reported yet; prior echocardiogram showed ejection fraction about 35%

A (Assessment):

- Acute heart failure exacerbation
- Possible gout flare
- Coronary artery disease, stable but requires evaluation of murmur and heart function
- Stage 3 chronic kidney disease

P (Plan):

- Increase Lasix from 40 mg once daily to 80 mg once daily in the morning; consider adding second dose around 4 PM if needed; monitor weight and symptoms, patient to call in 2 days or earlier if worsening symptoms
- Order chest x-ray to evaluate current pulmonary status
- Order echocardiogram to assess heart murmur and ejection fraction; communicate with cardiologist (Dr. White) for follow-up
- Advise strict salt intake restriction; refer to dietitian for dietary counseling including potassium management
- Avoid NSAIDs such as Motrin and Advil due to kidney disease; continue Tylenol for pain; if pain persists, discuss alternative pain treatments
- Order complete metabolic panel to monitor kidney function and electrolytes
- Order serum uric acid to evaluate for possible gout flare; consider alternative gout medication compatible with kidney function if confirmed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Minimal dry cough, sore throat, slight fatigue
* History of present illness: Diagnosed with stage three non-small cell lung cancer with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule positive for adenocarcinoma; currently undergoing neoadjuvant chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide and receiving radiation therapy (45 gray dose); symptoms include a persistent dry cough without mucus, sore throat that is intermittent and sometimes worse, no shortness of breath noticed, no nausea or vomiting, decreased appetite but no sensation of food sticking, mild fatigue not overwhelming
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: Supportive family members accompanying for treatment
* Emotional/mental status: Mentally strong with good support from nursing staff, family, and friends

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Stable with good oxygen saturation
* Physical exam: No cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy, heart with regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, bilateral lung crackles on deep breath, erythema on left anterior chest likely related to radiation, no lower extremity edema
* Test results: Chest x-ray shows mild radiation pneumonitis indicating lung inflammation likely due to radiation therapy

A (Assessment):

* Stage three non-small cell lung cancer with adenocarcinoma confirmed by biopsy
* Radiation pneumonitis causing cough and mild respiratory symptoms
* Esophageal inflammation causing painful swallowing

P (Plan):

* Continue chemotherapy regimen with cisplatin and etoposide
* Continue radiation therapy at 45 gray dose; repeat imaging after completion to evaluate tumor shrinkage for possible surgical removal
* Prescribe prednisone 40 mg daily for 5 days to reduce radiation pneumonitis inflammation
* Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times daily to manage esophageal inflammation and painful swallowing, support nutrition and hydration
* Follow-up at next visit; patient advised to ask questions if any arise before then

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Status post mitral valve repair with occasional chest pain and shallow breathing on exertion  
- History of present illness: Underwent mitral valve repair on 8/3/2020; reports overall feeling better since surgery but still experiences intermittent chest pain lasting a few minutes a couple of times per month, with shallow breathing during exertion that resolves with rest  
- Past medical history: Mitral regurgitation, atrial fibrillation, diabetes, asthma, recurrent chest discomfort with negative cardiac work-up for coronary artery disease  
- Medications: Taking Coumadin 4 mg daily, Lasix 4 mg daily, Atenolol 50 mg daily; reports initial irritability with atenolol that has improved  
- Social history: No information provided  
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided  
- Physical exam: No jugular venous distention; lungs with reduced breath sounds but clear on auscultation and percussion; heart rhythm irregularly irregular consistent with atrial fibrillation, S1 slightly accentuated, no S3; abdomen and feet non-tender; trace peripheral edema on extremities  
- Test results: ECG on 12/26/2020 shows atrial fibrillation with controlled ventricular response and anterior T wave inversion, no significant changes compared to prior study

A (Assessment):

- Status post mitral valve repair  
- Atrial fibrillation, controlled  
- History of mitral regurgitation, diabetes, asthma  
- Recurrent chest discomfort with negative cardiac work-up for coronary artery disease

P (Plan):

- Continue current medications: Coumadin 4 mg daily, Lasix 4 mg daily, Atenolol 50 mg daily  
- Encourage patient to maintain activity as tolerated and continue monitoring symptoms  
- Follow-up appointment in 6 to 9 months for cardiac evaluation  
- Patient education on recognizing symptoms and medication adherence

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: New worrisome heart murmur
- History of present illness: Noted heart murmur recently; no chest pain; severe leg pain for about one month; shortness of breath only with overexertion such as walking too fast or drinking a whole glass of water without stopping; uses a walker, can walk to end of driveway or around cul-de-sac; leg swelling (ankles) for about 6 months with variability; gradual weight loss from 130 to 120 pounds over one year; lightheadedness and dizziness treated intermittently with meclizine; no syncope; no palpitations; fatigue attributed to medications
- Past medical history: No specific details provided; multiple surgeries mentioned but not specified
- Social history: Never smoked
- Family history: Son with heart attack; brother had a stroke related to diabetes; older sister had a heart problem; heart problems run in family
- Allergies: None known

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure well controlled (no specific numbers provided)
- Physical exam: Elderly woman in no acute distress; cardiovascular exam normal with preserved S1 and S2, regular rate and rhythm; 4/6 systolic murmur at right upper sternal border with mild radiation to carotids; neurologic exam showed normal gait for age
- Test results: EKG showed sinus rhythm with frequent premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) and anterior septal infarct pattern; chest X-ray performed recently; no current echocardiogram results available

A (Assessment):

- Cardiac murmur: 4/6 systolic murmur at right upper sternal border with mild radiation to carotids, most likely aortic stenosis, possibly moderate severity based on relatively preserved S2
- Premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) identified on EKG; asymptomatic from palpitations currently
- Diastolic dysfunction noted in prior external records
- Hyperlipidemia managed by primary care physician
- Lightheadedness and dizziness, possibly related to aortic stenosis and/or PVCs
- Severe bilateral leg pain (etiology to be further evaluated)
- Consideration of transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) evaluation, depending on echocardiogram results and severity of aortic stenosis

P (Plan):

- Schedule and perform echocardiogram today to assess cardiac structure, function, and valvular disease
- Continue current medications including amlodipine, lisinopril, levothyroxine, and simvastatin; no change to antihypertensives or thyroid medication
- Discuss possible statin discontinuation with primary care physician given age, bilateral leg pain, and absence of coronary artery disease
- Consider ischemic evaluation and cardiac monitoring for PVC burden after echocardiogram results
- Follow-up appointment in 3 to 4 weeks after echocardiogram to review results and determine next steps
- Educate patient about symptoms and procedural options, including explanation of TAVR and surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR), with no urgent decisions required at this time

transcription: [doctor] kayla ward , date of birth 4/28/2007 , mrn 384920 . she is here for a new visit with her mother for acne located on the face which started about 2 years ago and is present most every day . she has been using perc gel and washing regularly which is somewhat helpful . there are no associated symptoms including itching , bleeding , or pain . no additional past medical history . she lives with her parents and sister . they have a dog , bird and bonnies . she is in seventh grade . she plays basketball , volleyball and tap . she wears sunscreen in the summer . spf 30 . no additional family history . hi kayla , i'm dr. juan price . i hear you are starting to get some acne on the face . how about the chest and back ? [patient] it's not too bad . [doctor] so it's not bad on the chest or back . you've used some over the counter items like washes and person gel ? [patient] yeah . [doctor] do those seem to be helping ? [patient] yes , i think so a little bit . [doctor] good . what's your skin care routine like now ? [patient] do you wan na know like the things i currently use ? [doctor] yes . what do you do for your acne in the morning and then what do you do at nighttime ? i wash my face more like i wipe it down in the morning then at night i use an l facial cleanser called the superclarity cleanser . i finish with a toner and then the person gel . when you say wipe your face in the morning , do you use a product or just water ? [patient] hmmm just water and a wash cloth really , if i feel really greasy , sometimes i'll use the elf cleanser in the morning too . [doctor] okay and is today a good day , bad day or an average day for you ? [patient] hmmm i would say it's probably a good day for me of course since i'm here right ? [doctor] acne is always good when you come to see the doctor . do you find that your acne flares with your periods ? [patient] no , not really . [doctor] and do you get a regular period ? [patient] yep . [doctor] how long have you been getting a regular period ? [patient] hmmm i think about 2 years . [doctor] okay . the biggest flare probably was when she started school sports in the fall just with all the sweating . yeah , i'll do it . is there anything else that you've noticed , mrs. ward ? [patient] no , kayla really has been doing a good job with the facial care regimen . it just does n't seem to help as much as we wanted . [doctor] got it . okay . well , let's take a look then . full exam is performed today except for under the underwear and under the bra multiple benign navy on the trunk and extremities scattered skin colored papules open and closed comedones and erythematous papules on the face primarily on the forehead and with also some on the central cheeks and chin . the chest and back are relatively spared . and the remainder of the examination is normal . so what i'm seeing from your exam today is mild to moderate acne , mostly comedonal with small inflammatory component . [patient] okay , so is there anything we can do to help it ? [doctor] yes , i would like to start with a topical therapy first . every morning you will wash your face with a mild cleanser . then use a moisturizer label noncommittogenic with sunscreen , spf 30 or higher . this means it wo n't clog your pors . now in the evening , wash your face with the same cleanser and allow it to dry . apply adapalene 0.1 % cream in a thin layer to the areas you generally get acne . i want you to start off using this a few nights a week and slowly work up to using it every night . if it , it is , excuse me , if it is very expensive or not covered by insurance , you can try differin gel over the counter . you can follow that with clean and clear bursa gel and a thin layer where you generally get acne and then a noncommunogenic moisturizer . your topical retinoid wo n't cause sun sensitivity so you will need to wear sunscreen when you are outside . it may also cause some dryness or irritation . [patient] okay . i can do that . [doctor] you also have multiple benign moles on your arms , legs , back , and abdomen . this means they all look normal with no worrisome features . we will see if you have any progress over the next 6 months and follow up at that time . [patient] okay . that sounds good . thank you . [doctor] do you have any questions for me ? [patient] no , i do n't think so . [doctor] okay . if you have questions or concerns before your next visit , please call the office . [patient] thank you , doctor , we will .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Acne on the face present most every day for about 2 years  
* History of present illness: Mild to moderate acne primarily on forehead, central cheeks, and chin; no itching, bleeding, or pain; acne not bad on chest or back; acne worsens somewhat with school sports and sweating; no flare related to menstrual periods  
* Current skincare routine: Morning – face wiped with water and washcloth, sometimes uses ELF cleanser if greasy; evening – washes face with Superclarity cleanser, uses toner and perc gel; regular use of sunscreen SPF 30 in summer  
* Past medical history: No additional past medical history  
* Family history: No additional family history  
* Social history: Lives with parents and sister; has a dog, bird, and bunnies; in seventh grade; plays basketball, volleyball, and tap  
* Menstrual history: Regular periods for about 2 years

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Multiple benign navy nevi on trunk and extremities; scattered skin-colored papules; open and closed comedones; erythematous papules on face primarily forehead, central cheeks, and chin; chest and back relatively spared; remainder of examination normal

A (Assessment):

* Mild to moderate acne, mostly comedonal with small inflammatory component  
* Multiple benign moles without worrisome features

P (Plan):

* Morning: wash face with mild cleanser; apply noncomedogenic moisturizer with sunscreen SPF 30 or higher  
* Evening: wash face with same cleanser, allow to dry, apply adapalene 0.1% cream in a thin layer to acne-prone areas starting few nights per week, increasing to nightly use as tolerated  
* If adapalene prescription is expensive or not covered, consider over-the-counter Differin gel  
* Follow with Clean & Clear BPO gel in thin layer and then noncomedogenic moisturizer  
* Patient education: topical retinoid may cause dryness or irritation but does not cause sun sensitivity; sunscreen use advised when outdoors  
* Monitoring: follow-up in 6 months to assess acne and moles progress; patient instructed to call office if questions or concerns before next visit

transcription: [patient] alright , today i'm seeing jose james date of birth 9/29/1957 . mr. james is a new patient , who is having pain in his left shoulder and elbow . he fell 5 months ago going up the stairs and the pain has been present since . [doctor] hi mr. james , i'm dr. isabella , how're you doing ? [patient] i'm okay , thank you . [doctor] that's good . that's good . tell me what brings you in today ? [patient] sure , so i've been having constant pain in my left shoulder and left elbow for a while about 5 months or so , hurts all the time , pretty bad at times . [doctor] hmmm that does not sound like fun . it sounds like you injured it going up the stairs ? [patient] yes , that's correct . it was icy and i have to walk up a flight of stairs to my house . i stepped and my feet just went out , fell on my left side . seems like my shoulder and wrist took the brunt , it's been hurting since . [doctor] yeah , that does seem like a likely cause of your symptoms . anything seemed to make the pain worse ? [patient] well , i've always at the gym and lifted weights . i've been trying to keep with my routine of 2 days a week , but it's been hard . the pain is worse when i lift and i have n't been able to lift more than 15 or 20 pounds , which is very frustrating . [doctor] mm-hmm i can imagine it is when you're so accustomed to your routine . [patient] exactly . i really enjoy my exercise , but over the past 1 to 2 weeks i stopped hitting the gym because the pain just was n't worth it honestly . i do keep up with my walking though . my wife and i walk about 30 minutes almost everyday . we have done this since i retired from my office job last year . [doctor] i do not blame you mr . james . does anything seem to help the pain that you've tried ? [patient] not too much . i have iced a bit , but i have not taken anything for the pain . stopping the exercise and some ice has helped a bit , but it still hurts enough for me to come to see you . [doctor] yeah , okay . how about any numbness or tingling , have you felt that at any point ? no , document just pain . no tingling or numbness , numbness thankfully . understood , understood . alright , well , let's go ahead and take a look and see what's going on . [patient] sounds good . thank you . [doctor] okay . use my general physical exam template . mr. james , i'm going to gently press around your shoulder and elbow here to see where your pain might be stemming from . just let me know when it hurts . [patient] okay . it hurts when you press there on my elbow and here on my shoulder . [doctor] okay . left shoulder and elbow tender sa space . no warmth , erythema , or deformity . positive kiss the elbow and neer's test . normal proximal and distal distal upper extremity strength . intact median , radial , ulnar sensation and abduction to 90 degrees . normal empty can test . okay mr. james what i think you are dealing with is impingement syndrome of your left shoulder . i do n't think there is an additional injury or issue with your wrist but because everything is connected . [patient] you're experiencing pain in your wrist because of your shoulder . we do see this type of issue when someone has a fall , so it's good you came to see us , he came in to see us so we could help . so what are the possible treatments ? [doctor] well , we have a few options you can try . first option would be to start with physical therapy . i would recommend two sessions per week as well as any other exercises they give , [patient] you to do at home we can start if that does n't improve your pain then we could try a cortisone injection . [doctor] i like the idea of starting with the physical therapy and have a next step if it does n't help . i am not opposed to a shot , but would like to try the therapy first . alright , great . i'll get a referral ordered and they will call you within the next day or two to get you scheduled . [patient] okay . [doctor] mm-hmm also please continue to ice especially your shoulder and rest as much as you can . [patient] okay , i will . [doctor] give us a call or email if you have symptoms worsen , if your symptoms worsen or do not improve with the therapy . [patient] will do . thank you . i appreciate your help . [doctor] you're welcome . have a great day . [patient] you too . [doctor] alright , assessment is impingement syndrome of left shoulder . plan discussed with patient . referral is requested for dr. martha rivera to being physical therapy 2 days/week .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Constant pain in left shoulder and left elbow for about 5 months
* History of present illness: Pain started after a fall going up icy stairs 5 months ago, landed on left side with shoulder and wrist taking the brunt, pain worsens with lifting weights (unable to lift more than 15-20 pounds), stopped gym exercise for past 1 to 2 weeks but continues daily 30-minute walks with wife, pain persists despite icing, no numbness or tingling reported
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Retired from office job last year, exercises regularly with walking and previously weightlifting twice a week
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Tenderness over left shoulder and left elbow, no warmth, erythema, or deformity; positive Kiss test at elbow and Neer's test at shoulder; normal proximal and distal upper extremity strength; intact median, radial, and ulnar nerve sensation; able to abduct arm to 90 degrees; normal empty can test

A (Assessment):

* Impingement syndrome of left shoulder

P (Plan):

* Referral to Dr. Martha Rivera for physical therapy, 2 sessions per week plus home exercises
* Continue icing left shoulder and rest as much as possible
* Consider cortisone injection if symptoms do not improve with physical therapy
* Patient instructed to call or email if symptoms worsen or fail to improve with therapy

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Runny nose, nasal congestion, cough, irritability, ear pulling, decreased appetite, low-grade fever
* History of present illness: Symptoms started suppertime last night with runny nose and clear mucus, mild cough that is not barky, pulling on ears, rubbing nose frequently, rectal temperature of 100.3°F, variable appetite with decreased intake of cereal and second bottle this morning, irritable and fighting sleep, energetic but not settling well
* Social history: Exposure to older sister with illness and nephew with sinus infection
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided
* Medications tried: Saline nasal mist, acetaminophen (Tylenol) early morning for fever, baby Vicks on feet, humidifier

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Rectal temperature measured at home 100.3°F (low-grade fever)
* Physical exam: Ears appear normal on examination, lung auscultation tolerated well, no barky cough observed
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Viral upper respiratory infection, initial stage, no current indication for antibiotics
* Cradle cap worsening

P (Plan):

* Supportive care with fluids and rest
* Monitor closely for development of barky cough; if barky cough develops, start half teaspoon of sister’s prescribed medication for 5 days
* Provide prophylactic same medication as sister’s to have on hand, not to be used unless barky cough appears
* Recommend use of Zarbee’s syrup at appropriate dosing for regular cough to provide symptomatic relief
* Advise no honey for patient under one year old due to risk of botulism; use alternatives such as agave nectar if needed
* For cradle cap, use dandruff shampoos like Head & Shoulders, Selsun Blue, or Nizoral A.D. regular strength twice weekly, continue brushing with soft brush and baby oil to remove scales, avoid getting shampoo in eyes
* Return visit scheduled in 1 week or sooner if symptoms worsen or change significantly

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Consultation for breast reduction due to large breast size causing symptoms
- History of present illness: Considering breast reduction for about 6 to 7 years, experiencing back and neck pain since high school, bra strap indentations present, occasional numbness or tingling in hands and nipple pain, sweaty breasts without rashes, activity limitations during exercise (jumping, running) due to pain, chiropractic care for back pain, no physical therapy or pain medications except propranolol for migraines
- Past medical history: No children currently, possible future pregnancy, family history of breast cancer (mother diagnosed at age 40)
- Social history: Drinks wine occasionally, no tobacco or drug use, currently studying psychology
- Other subjective: Weight loss of about 10 pounds recently, desires to lose 20 more pounds, uncertain about breastfeeding in future

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Asymmetrical breasts with severe bilateral ptosis, no nipple retraction or discharge, no breast tenderness, no palpable masses or axillary lymphadenopathy
- Measurements: One breast lower than the other, G cup size, minimum required resection per Schnur scale 1792 g based on BSA of 2.65
- No other vital signs or laboratory results provided

A (Assessment):

- Symptomatic macromastia
- Ideal candidate for bilateral reduction mammoplasty
- Potential need for free nipple graft due to extremely large breasts and measurements

P (Plan):

- Take clinical photos for insurance documentation today
- Wait for new insurance activation in July before submitting approval request
- Upon insurance approval, schedule surgery and preoperative visit to review instructions and address questions
- Surgery plan: Bilateral breast reduction with removal of breast tissue and fat, nipple elevation to improve back and neck pain, expected size reduction to approximately small C or B cup depending on blood supply
- Postoperative care: Surgery duration about 3 hours, one-night hospital stay for pain and nausea control, drains placed bilaterally for about one week, no heavy lifting or driving for 2-3 weeks, clear tape over incisions to aid scar healing
- Patient education: 30% chance of impaired breastfeeding, possible temporary or permanent nipple sensation changes, breasts may change size with weight or pregnancy hormones, activity restrictions for about 6 weeks after surgery
- Patient advised to notify office once insurance details are confirmed to proceed with approval process

transcription: [patient] judy gomez , mrn 869723 , date of birth 5/7/1961 . she is in office today for ongoing management of psoriatic arthritis . hello judy , how're you doing today ? [doctor] i'm doing good , thank you , how are you ? [patient] i'm great , thanks , so how have you been since the last time , i know the last time we were talking about decreasing your prednisone dose , correct ? [doctor] yes , i'm just on one now and that seems to be enough . [patient] that's great to hear . [doctor] yeah , there are a couple of days there , i took an extra one just because there was a little extra pain in my feet and i do have a desk job , so when i have a day off where i'm moving around a lot , they do tend to hurt a bit more . [patient] okay , how many times did you do that ? [doctor] it was n't often maybe once a week . [patient] okay so it sounds like we are still on track for discontinuing the prednisone , we'll do that today and you can let me know how it goes on your next visit and how about the methotrexate , do you think that helped with your joint pain ? [doctor] yeah , definitely because i went to get my covid shots but from the letter i got about it , it said that it could interfere with the vaccine , you know , reduce the efficacy , so i did n't take it on the week that i got the first shot . [patient] okay and what happened ? [doctor] i felt absolutely horrible until i took it again a week later . [patient] i'm sorry to hear that and , and what did you do about the second dose ? [doctor] well i called into the hotline because i was in so much pain with the first one and they said no , just go ahead and take it , so i did . [patient] okay , that's good then . we do have to keep an eye out on it since it's a high risk medication . do you have an appointment to get your blood drawn for the next time ? [doctor] no , they did n't give me one . [patient] okay . so we can do that for you too . so what questions do you have for me , judy ? [doctor] well i just wanted to know why i was getting all these bruises here so like when i bump myself , i do n't know where they are coming from . [patient] okay , that's probably from the prednisone , it can increase bruising . [doctor] okay , i did n't know that . i do n't even feel it when it happens , they just show up . [patient] yeah , unfortunately that can happen but we are working on discontinuing that , so let's see if the bruises do go away . [doctor] okay , that sounds good , thanks . [patient] okay judy , please sit up here and i'll take a look , shoes and socks off please . [doctor] alright . [patient] alright , let me see here , okay , so where is it hurting , in your joints right here ? [doctor] yeah , a little also in my feet joints as well . [patient] okay and how about when you bend the knee like this ? [doctor] well , it hurt before we increased the methotrexate , but it's doing pretty good now . okay , good . can you flex your toes please ? [patient] good range of motion also ridges and nails that's from the psoriasis . [doctor] yeah , they've been like that for a long time now . [patient] okay . alright miss gomez it looks like we are moving along with your treatment nicely . we will stop your prednisone and continue with the methotrexate . make sure you stop by the front desk and make an appointment for the blood work and i'll see you in 3 months . [doctor] alright , it sounds good . thank you so much . it was great to see you . [patient] it was great seeing you too . thank you .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Ongoing management of psoriatic arthritis
* History of present illness: Patient recently decreased prednisone dose to 1 mg daily; occasional extra dose about once a week due to increased foot pain related to activity; reports joint pain improvement with methotrexate; experienced severe pain after first COVID vaccine dose while off methotrexate, improved after resuming medication; notices unexplained bruising without feeling trauma
* Past medical history: Psoriatic arthritis, psoriasis with nail ridging present for a long time
* Social history: Desk job with periods of increased movement on days off
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Joint tenderness in feet and other joints, good range of motion in toes and knees, ridging and nail changes consistent with psoriasis noted on nails
* Vital signs: No information provided
* Test results: No recent blood work yet; patient has not had blood drawn for monitoring

A (Assessment):

* Psoriatic arthritis, ongoing management
* Bruising likely related to prednisone use

P (Plan):

* Discontinue prednisone today
* Continue methotrexate therapy
* Schedule blood work appointment prior to next visit
* Follow-up appointment in 3 months to monitor treatment response and side effects

transcription: [doctor] kelly wood , date of birth february 15 , 1979 . established patient here for renal ultrasound because of hematuria . urine dipstick today negative for leukocytes , nitrates , protein , ketones , bilirubin and glucose color yellow and clear . urobilinogen 0.2 , ph 5.5 , and specific gravity 1.020 . there is a trace amount of blood in the urine and intact . renal ultrasound , impression , right kidney is 10 cm in length by 5 cm wide . there are no stones , masses , or hydronephrosis . the left kidney is 10.8 cm in length and 5 cm wide . there is a 6 mm left renal stone nonobstructing . 533 ml prevoid and 0 ml post void . hi mrs. wood , i see you just finished your ultrasound . [patient] yes ma'am . [doctor] well , it looks like you have 1 stone in the left kidney , but it's not obstructing anything . [patient] i knew it had to be a kidney stone . i passed what looked like two small stones last week after i scheduled this appointment and then for the past 6 weeks , i've had a few episodes of bright red urine , the color of like cherry cholestee , and last week i was constantly having to pee , and it hurt something terrible . [doctor] how bad was your pain on a scale of 0-10 , zero being no pain and 10 being worst as you can imagine . [patient] at the time i'd say an eight . [doctor] are you having any flank pain now or tenderness in your lower back ? [patient] no , after passing those stones , things have felt a lot better . [doctor] that's good to hear . now , it looks like you're only taking alavert 10 mg a day and have no drug allergies . is that correct ? [patient] that's right . [doctor] alright , well let's take a look at you today . let's use my default pe . well mrs. wood , we know that the blood in your urine was due to the kidney stones . fortunately you passed two last week and the blood has nearly subsided . you do still have 1 stone in the left kidney . since it's not obstructing or causing pain , i do n't recommend any surgical intervention at this time . [patient] i would like to know what i can do to stop getting these stones . [doctor] as we discussed last time , the formation of kidney stones can not be attributed to a particular cause . but several factors increase the risk such as dehydration , family history , certain foods , digestive tract disease , and certain medical conditions . [patient] yeah i know i do n't drink near the amount of water that i should . i drink more mountain dew than anything . [doctor] you should drink about half of your body weight in ounces of water a day . [patient] so if i weigh 250 pounds , i should drink . [doctor] that would be 125 ounces of water a day and you should avoid drinking sugary drinks like mountain dew . [patient] okay . is there any food i should n't eat ? [doctor] great question . you should avoid food rich in sodium , oxalate , and animal protein . so that would be salty , processed foods because they are high in sodium . ideally you should consume less than 1000 mg of sodium a day and reduce the amount of beef , poultry , fish , and pork . [patient] what's oxalate ? [doctor] it's an organic acid found in plants that when digested , it binds to minerals that stones are formed from foods like spinach , chocolate , beets , rubar , and soy products . [patient] well , i'll do whatever it takes to try to avoid getting these stones again . [doctor] great and here is a handout that you can look over . it goes over the dietary recommendations and what to avoid . [patient] okay , good . i like to have things in writing to help you remember . [doctor] perfect . well , if you have any more questions , if you do n't have any more questions , you're all set , i wo n't need to see you back until next year as long as you do n't have any more issues like bleeding or pain . if you do have any issues , you can always call the office sooner and if you experience any severe pain or bright red blood in your urine , you should go to the emergency room . [patient] alright , well , let's hope we do n't have to do either of those and i see you next year . [doctor] yes , so let's hope . come right this way and i'll walk you to check out . update pe abdomen , no flank pain and to gu . normal vaginal exam . primary diagnosis is hematuria . secondary diagnosis is chronic urolithiasis . thank you . this is complete . mrs. wood encounter .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Hematuria
* History of present illness: Several episodes of bright red urine resembling cherry color over the past 6 weeks, passed two small kidney stones last week, experienced severe urinary pain last week with pain intensity rated 8/10 at that time, currently no flank pain or lower back tenderness after passing stones
* Past medical history: Chronic urolithiasis
* Medications: Alavert 10 mg daily
* Allergies: No drug allergies
* Social history: Consumes mostly Mountain Dew, admits to inadequate water intake

O (Objective):

* Urine dipstick: Negative for leukocytes, nitrates, protein, ketones, bilirubin, glucose; color yellow and clear; urobilinogen 0.2; pH 5.5; specific gravity 1.020; trace amount of blood present and intact
* Renal ultrasound: Right kidney 10 cm by 5 cm, no stones, masses, or hydronephrosis; left kidney 10.8 cm by 5 cm with one 6 mm nonobstructing renal stone
* Bladder volumes: Prevoid 533 ml, post void 0 ml
* Physical exam: No flank pain or tenderness; abdominal exam normal; genitourinary exam normal; vaginal exam normal

A (Assessment):

* Hematuria, primary diagnosis
* Chronic urolithiasis, secondary diagnosis

P (Plan):

* No surgical intervention recommended for the left kidney stone as it is nonobstructing and asymptomatic
* Patient education on kidney stone prevention including:
  - Increase water intake to about half of body weight in ounces daily (approximately 125 ounces for a 250-pound person)
  - Avoid sugary drinks such as Mountain Dew
  - Dietary restrictions to limit sodium (less than 1000 mg/day), oxalate-containing foods (spinach, chocolate, beets, rhubarb, soy products), and animal protein (beef, poultry, fish, pork)
* Provided patient with written handout covering dietary recommendations and foods to avoid
* Follow-up plan: No routine follow-up until next year unless hematuria, pain, or bleeding recur; instructions to call office sooner if symptoms worsen; advised to visit emergency room if severe pain or bright red blood in urine occurs

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right shoulder pain for a few weeks, bilateral foot soreness
- History of present illness: Right shoulder soreness started after backyard work with multiple projects; pain localized more to the outside of the shoulder, tender with arm elevation, pain occurs only with movement, slight night pain when sleeping on the affected side; no numbness in the arm or hand; feet and ankle joints are sore and stiff, possibly related to extensive yard work, improved somewhat with elevation and ice
- Past medical history: Previous right shoulder injury playing baseball during youth with some ongoing mild issues
- Social history: Engaged in physically demanding yard projects including installing an outdoor shower, extending a patio, creating flower boxes, and placing stones
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Temperature 97.8°F, heart rate 62/min, respiratory rate 16/min, blood pressure 116/84 mmHg, oxygen saturation 99%
- Physical exam: Right shoulder shows limited active and passive range of motion; tenderness at the greater tuberosity of the humerus; no tenderness at sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints; good hand grip strength; neurovascular exam of right arm with capillary refill <3 seconds, intact sensation to touch
- Test results: Right shoulder x-ray negative for fracture

A (Assessment):

- Rotator cuff tendinopathy of the right shoulder, suspected

P (Plan):

- Order MRI of right shoulder to evaluate for possible additional pathology due to prior shoulder problems
- Refer to physical therapy for approximately 6 to 8 weeks
- Continue acetaminophen for pain management during physical therapy
- Consider steroid injection for the shoulder if symptoms do not improve after therapy
- Recommend patient try Epsom salt foot soaks for bilateral foot soreness and muscle relaxation
- Advise continued elevation and icing of feet as supportive care
