SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Sudden visual distortions and blurring of vision
* History of present illness: Decrease in vision when reading, straight lines and door frames appear crooked, difficulty adjusting to dim lights in restaurants
* Social history: Currently smoking a pack of cigarettes a day, has tried to stop but finds it difficult
* Past medical history: No explicit past medical history provided except for presence of posterior chamber intraocular lenses in both eyes
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Anterior segment exam reveals posterior chamber intraocular lenses in both eyes, corneas clear without microvascular or other visible issues; right eye cup to disc ratio 0.2, retina attached 360° without tears or holes, retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) changes in the fovea, drusen in macula, retinal thickening, presence of subretinal fluid and exudates, positive for hemorrhage; left eye cup to disc ratio 0.3, RPE changes in fovea, retina attached, no hemorrhage or subretinal fluid
* Test results: Optical coherence tomography (OCT) shows drusen deposits, RPE changes, subretinal fluid accumulation, choroidal neovascular membrane in right eye; fluorescein angiography reveals focal leakage areas consistent with neovascular age-related macular degeneration (AMD) in right eye

A (Assessment):

* Neovascular (wet) age-related macular degeneration in the right eye

P (Plan):

* Initiate intravitreal injections of Lucentis (ranibizumab) once a month after topical anesthesia
* Educate patient that injections are given regularly over time to slow or stop vision loss, but progression may continue despite treatment
* Advise regular blood pressure monitoring and keeping a log
* Encourage smoking cessation efforts

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Right flank pain radiating to groin for 2 weeks
* History of present illness: Intermittent pain varying with fluid intake and activity, pain score 1-2/10 normally and up to 4/10 at worst, no pain on urination, no hematuria, one episode of pain radiating to testicle which subsided, no nausea or vomiting, possible chills without fever
* Past medical history: History of kidney stones, passed some spontaneously and required surgery several times
* Family history: Multiple family members with kidney stones
* Social history: Very active lifestyle

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure slightly elevated (exact value not provided)
* Physical exam: Abdomen non-tender on palpation, right costovertebral angle (CVA) tenderness present
* Test results: CT scan shows 0.5 cm stone in proximal right ureter, no hydronephrosis observed

A (Assessment):

* Kidney stone, confirmed

P (Plan):

* Continue high fluid intake to promote stone passage
* Continue ibuprofen for pain control
* Prescribe tramadol 50 mg for breakthrough or increased pain over the weekend
* Use urine strainer to catch stone during urination
* Order basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture to assess for possible infection
* Follow-up in 1-2 weeks to reassess symptoms and stone status
* Discuss further treatments such as lithotripsy if stone not passed or symptoms persist

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Weight gain, acne, foot swelling, constipation, sensitive skin with rash on sides
- History of present illness: Unable to start newly prescribed thyroid medication due to cost, continuing old medication; weight gain possibly related to previous birth control use; has acne and never tried topical antibiotics before; feet swell frequently; constipation present; reports sensitive skin prone to rash with various products; trying to improve diet and planning to resume gym in July; interested in weight loss options; questions about supplements such as CLA, chromium, and amino acids for metabolism and workout support; no known medication allergies

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Lungs and heart auscultation normal, feet and ankles examination currently normal without swelling
- Test results: Dexamethasone suppression test normal (passed), salivary cortisol testing abnormal in 1 of 3 samples (may need repeat), total cholesterol 222 mg/dL (high), LDL 153 mg/dL (high), HDL 44 mg/dL (low), non-HDL cholesterol 178 mg/dL (high), diabetes screening normal, vitamin D deficiency confirmed (currently on supplementation), liver enzymes improved with ALT decreased from 254 to 128 to 30, other pituitary hormones and iron levels within normal limits

A (Assessment):

- Abnormal liver enzymes, improved since discontinuation of birth control
- Abnormal weight gain, dexamethasone suppression test normal, salivary cortisol inconsistent, ruling out Cushing’s syndrome
- Normal androgen levels, no endocrine cause for weight gain or acne identified
- Vitamin D deficiency
- Acne vulgaris

P (Plan):

- Prescribe individual ingredients clindamycin gel and benzoyl peroxide for acne instead of Epiduo due to cost; advise bedtime application and caution about bleaching sheets; avoid sun exposure after application
- Provide discount card for Unithroid thyroid medication to reduce cost; suggest trying different pharmacies including CVS
- Continue vitamin D supplementation with 2000 IU daily after initial dose completion
- Encourage low carbohydrate, low fat, and low cholesterol diet; avoid alcohol
- Recommend weight loss study involving weekly injections of diabetes medication affecting satiety hormones; study start pending paperwork; patient currently prefers to wait
- Address constipation with Miralax as previously recommended
- Follow-up labs to repeat thyroid function tests and other relevant levels before next visit
- Monitor feet swelling and advise patient to report worsening
- Consider alternative contraception (Fexie) applied before intercourse if needed
- Print prescriptions and provide patient education on medication use and cost assistance options

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Follow-up for chronic congestive heart failure with diastolic dysfunction and preoperative evaluation for right knee replacement surgery
- History of present illness: Increasing dyspnea; previously elevated BNP with values 3000 in March and 6000 in April; weight loss of 3 to 3.5 pounds since last visit; leg cramps recently resolved with pickle juice; urgency to urinate improved with oxybutynin; no current heartburn after short course of Prilosec; no current problems with bowel movements; awaiting colonoscopy as overdue screening
- Past medical history: Chronic congestive heart failure with diastolic dysfunction, anemia history, heartburn treated with Prilosec, overdue colonoscopy
- Social history: No information provided
- Family history: No family history of colon cancer reported

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Lungs clear on auscultation, breathing non-labored
- Test results: Hemoglobin stable, potassium 3.9 mEq/L, creatinine 0.79 mg/dL, BUN 23 mg/dL (mildly elevated), magnesium 1.7 mg/dL (normal), blood pressure well controlled, non-fasting blood glucose 169 mg/dL, last A1c 5.5% in March, EKG repeated today (results not provided), chest X-ray recent, no additional blood work needed today

A (Assessment):

- Chronic congestive heart failure, mixed presentation with diastolic dysfunction, recent exacerbation in spring
- Preoperative evaluation for right knee replacement surgery scheduled end of June
- Overdue screening colonoscopy, no family history of colon cancer noted
- Diabetes: A1c 5.1% on last check, elevated non-fasting blood glucose today, no immediate change in management

P (Plan):

- Continue current heart failure regimen: torsemide 20 mg daily, lisinopril increased to 10 mg daily, no potassium supplement currently
- Consider starting magnesium supplement twice daily to maintain levels around 2 mg/dL for cardiac muscle stabilization
- Preoperative instructions: discontinue clopidogrel one week before knee surgery, schedule preop check within 1-2 weeks after surgery in early June
- Repeat EKG prior to surgery (done today)
- Arrange colonoscopy at county hospital within next 30 days prior to change in insurance status; screening colonoscopy will not delay surgery
- Monitor for symptoms of worsening heart failure; patient education to avoid excessive intake of pickle juice due to salt content
- No additional blood work today; consider repeating A1c prior to surgery for diabetes monitoring
- Follow-up and patient to notify if any new symptoms develop or concerns arise

transcription: [doctor] patrick allen , date of birth 7/7/1977 . new patient visit . past medical history includes gerd , anxiety , depression , here for chronic abdominal pain , he had an abdominal ct on 1/23/2020 . impression is a normal ct of the abdomen . hello , are you mr. allen ? [patient] yes , i am . [doctor] hi , my name is dr. edwards , nice to meet you . [patient] nice to meet you . [doctor] welcome to the gi specialty clinic . [patient] thank you . [doctor] did you have any problems finding this ? [patient] no , i've been here with my sister once before . [doctor] good , so how can i help you today ? the referral i have is for abdominal pain and diarrhea . [patient] right so i've had been having this pain right here in my stomach like right around here . [doctor] so in the area of your mid abdomen just below the belly button ? [patient] correct . i've had the pain on and off for about 2 years . i finally went to the er and a a few months ago and they did a ct scan . [doctor] i saw that . [patient] yeah , they said they did n't really see anything on the scan . [doctor] yes , i agree , it looked normal . [patient] and the problem is i'm either constipated or have explosive diarrhea . [doctor] is the pain there all the time ? [patient] it's a nagging feeling and it just depends , sometimes it bothers me , sometimes it does n't . [doctor] has this been the case over the past 2 years as well ? [patient] more recently in the past couple of months at least with the constipation and diarrhea . [doctor] and before that , how were your bowel movements ? [patient] they were normal . [doctor] okay , so any blood in your stool ? [patient] nope . [doctor] do you feel like you have more constipation or diarrhea ? [patient] probably more constipation . [doctor] okay , so when you're constipated , do you not have a bowel movement or is the stool hard ? [patient] i usually do n't go , but when i do , it's hard . [doctor] and how often do you have a bowel movement when you are constipated ? [patient] about 3-4 times a week it's like when i need to go to the bathroom if i can massage it , it feels like it's moving some and i can eventually go . [doctor] okay and when you have a bowel movement , does the pain change ? [patient] yeah . it gets a little better . [doctor] and are you eating and drinking okay , any nausea or vomiting , heartburn or indigestion ? [patient] none of that . [doctor] okay , so tell me about the diarrhea . how often do you get it ? [patient] it kinda just depends on what i eat . i think i have a very sensitive stomach if i eat pasta with a creamy sauce i'm probably gon na have diarrhea . [doctor] okay and does it happen for multiple days in a row or is it just one time ? [patient] it's usually just one time and then it's over . [doctor] and how has your weight been , any fluctuation ? [patient] no , it's been pretty stable , although i could stand to lose about 25 pounds . [doctor] okay , and is there any family history of gi issues that you know of ? [patient] not that i can think of . well , actually my sister does have problems with her stomach too . she has irritable bowel syndrome and that is kind of what i always thought i had even though i have never been diagnosed with it . [doctor] okay and is there any family history of gi cancer or liver disease ? [patient] no . [doctor] have you ever had any surgeries on your abdomen ? [patient] i have never had any surgery . [doctor] okay , so your gallbladder , appendix , all of those are still intact ? [patient] yep . [doctor] and have you ever had a colonoscopy ? [patient] no . i thought that happened when you turned 50 . [doctor] well that's for colon cancer screening , but there are other reasons to have a colonoscopy like unexplained abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits . [patient] okay . [doctor] well , come have a seat here and lay back so i can examine you . [patient] okay . [doctor] i'm gon na start by listening to your belly with my stethoscope . [patient] okay . [doctor] and i hear bowel sounds in all four quadrants . [patient] what does that mean , is everything okay ? [doctor] it just means that i can hear little noises in all areas of your belly , which means your bowels are active and working . [patient] okay , good . [doctor] so now i'm going to push on your upper and lower abdomen , let me know if you have any pain . [patient] it hurts a little when you push right there on the left side near my belly button . [doctor] okay , i do feel stool in your lower colon which would coincide with constipation but i also feel a slight enlargement of your liver here on the upper right side . have you had any lab work done recently ? [patient] yes . i had a physical about 4 months ago and they i had blood drawn then . [doctor] okay and did your primary care physician say anything about the lab results ? [patient] he said i had some very slightly elevated liver enzymes but we would recheck them in about 6 months . [doctor] and do you remember what enzymes were elevated , alt , ast , alp ? [patient] he said the alt and the ast were elevated . [doctor] and do you take any medications either prescription or over the counter ? [patient] i take crestor and , and olmesartan daily and then tylenol for occasional , occasional pain . [doctor] and how frequently do you take the tylenol ? [patient] hardly ever , maybe once a month . [doctor] and do you consume alcohol ? [patient] yes , but only a couple of beers after working in the yard on saturdays . [doctor] okay and no previous history of heavy alcohol or drug use ? [patient] no . [doctor] and have you had any recent issues with excessive bruising or bleeding ? [patient] nope . [doctor] and how about any issues with your ankles or feet swelling ? [patient] no . [doctor] okay , i'm gon na take a look at your eyes and skin . i do n't see any jaundice . [patient] what would cause that ? [doctor] issues with your liver . let me take a quick listen to your heart and lungs . [patient] okay . [doctor] lungs are clear bilateral . heart sounds are normal . no murmurs , gallops , or rubs noted . [patient] that's good . [doctor] yes , the rest of your physical exam is normal other than what seems to be an increased stool burden in your colon and a slight hepatomegaly . [patient] what's that ? [doctor] increased stool burden means that there is a lot of stool sitting in your colon . [patient] and that's the constipation , right ? but what about the other thing ? [doctor] the hepatomegaly means the liver is enlarged . [patient] but you said mom was slightly enlarged . [doctor] correct . [patient] so what does that mean ? [doctor] well , let's talk about what we found and then some possible next steps if you're in agreement . [patient] okay . [doctor] so as i said , the hepatomegaly means your liver is enlarged . [patient] could that be why my stomach is hurting and i'm having issues with the constipation and diarrhea ? [doctor] no , i think you're constipated and have occasional bouts of diarrhea because of certain foods you eat and we can get you started right away on a fiber supplement that should help with that . [patient] so what about my liver , why is it enlarged ? [doctor] well , there are many reasons why people can have an elevated liver enzymes and also an enlarged liver . some possible causes are certain medications that can be toxic to the liver . alcohol abuse , fatty liver disease , hepatitis , cirrhosis , and other liver diseases like wilson's disease . [patient] so what do i need to do ? [doctor] well , i think since it's been about 4 months since your blood work was done , we should check your liver enzymes in addition to a few other labs . [patient] okay and then what ? [doctor] we will get those drawn today and then depending upon the results , you may need an ultrasound of your liver . i think we need to talk about your medications too . [patient] which medications ? [doctor] crestor , how long have you been taking that ? [patient] about 18 months . [doctor] okay , well crestor is one of the medications that can cause liver toxicity , so it may be a good idea to discuss other alternatives . [patient] should i talk to my primary care or can you change it ? [doctor] i would recommend calling your primary care and discuss that with him since he follows you for your blood pressure and cholesterol . [patient] okay . i'll call him this afternoon . [doctor] great . i also think we should go ahead and get you scheduled for a liver ultrasound . if your blood work looks good , then we can always cancel that . [patient] okay . when do you think i'll be able to get the ultrasound done ? [doctor] hopefully within the next 2 weeks , you will receive a call from the radiology scheduling this afternoon to get it set up . [patient] okay and then what happens ? [doctor] when i get the results from the tests , i'll contact you and depending upon what we find , we'll come up with our next steps . [patient] and when should i see you again ? [doctor] let's schedule an appointment when you check out to return in 4 weeks . we'll discuss how you're doing with the fiber supplement and your constipation and review test results to determine if we need to do further testing on your liver . [patient] okay . is there anything else i can do to help with these issues ? [doctor] definitely refrain from drinking any alcohol , increase your water intake to at least 48 ounces a day , in addition to taking the fiber supplement to help with your constipation and be mindful of eating foods that you are sensitive to so you can avoid the bouts of diarrhea . [patient] okay and i will talk to my primary care about my crestor . [doctor] excellent and do you have any other questions for me ? [patient] i do n't think so . [doctor] great . so remember when you check out at the front desk , schedule a follow-up appointment with me for 4 weeks and then go to the lab to get your blood work drawn . [patient] okay , sounds good . [doctor] and expect a call from radiology scheduling about setting up your ultrasound . [patient] alright . thanks dr. edwards . [doctor] thank you mr. allen .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Chronic abdominal pain and diarrhea
* History of present illness: Mid-abdominal pain below the belly button, on and off for about 2 years; recent constipation and explosive diarrhea episodes mostly triggered by certain foods (e.g., creamy pasta); constipation predominates with bowel movements about 3-4 times per week, hard stool, pain improves after bowel movement; diarrhea usually occurs once after eating sensitive foods and resolves quickly; no nausea, vomiting, heartburn, or indigestion; no blood in stool; weight stable but patient desires to lose 25 pounds
* Past medical history: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), anxiety, depression
* Medications: Crestor (approx. 18 months), olmesartan daily, occasional Tylenol (about once a month)
* Social history: Consumes a couple of beers on Saturdays after yard work; no history of heavy alcohol or drug use
* Family history: Sister with irritable bowel syndrome; no family history of gastrointestinal cancer or liver disease
* Surgical history: No abdominal surgeries

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Bowel sounds auscultated in all four abdominal quadrants; tenderness on left side near belly button upon palpation; palpable stool in lower colon consistent with constipation; slight hepatomegaly (enlarged liver) noted; no jaundice observed on skin or eyes; lungs clear bilaterally; normal heart sounds without murmurs, gallops, or rubs; otherwise normal physical exam
* Test results: Abdominal CT scan dated 1/23/2020 reported as normal; recent blood work (approx. 4 months ago) showed slightly elevated ALT and AST liver enzymes; no other lab values provided

A (Assessment):

* Elevated liver enzymes and hepatomegaly, suspected
* Constipation with occasional diarrhea, symptoms consistent with suspected irritable bowel syndrome (per family history and symptom pattern)

P (Plan):

* Order liver function tests and additional labs today to evaluate liver enzymes
* Schedule liver ultrasound within 2 weeks pending lab results; cancel if labs normal
* Start fiber supplement to address constipation
* Advise increase in water intake to at least 48 ounces daily
* Recommend avoidance of alcohol intake
* Educate patient to avoid foods that trigger diarrhea
* Discuss Crestor medication risks with primary care physician for possible alternative lipid-lowering therapy
* Schedule follow-up appointment in 4 weeks to review symptoms, response to fiber supplement, lab and imaging results, and determine further management steps

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Fatigue, decreased cycling endurance
- History of present illness: Patient reports increased fatigue and inability to ride bikes as fast or as far as before (currently 20-30 miles vs. previously up to 40 miles). Needs to rest after rides.
- Past medical history: Aortic valve replacement and ascending aortic aneurysm repair on 1/22/2013
- Social history: No current tobacco or alcohol use mentioned; exercises by cycling and swimming twice weekly
- Family history: No information provided
- Other complaints: Noticed pursed-lip breathing when walking, no associated wheezing; small right testicular nodule noted by patient on epididymis area, no vasectomy history; no depression symptoms; sleeps 6-7 hours per night; occasional snoring without witnessed apnea
- COVID-19 vaccination: Completed two doses (1/15/2021 and 2/5/2021)

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Respiratory—pursed lip breathing, low exhalation phase, clear to auscultation, no wheezing; Genitalia—right testicle with 2 to 3 mm palpable nodule, left testicle normal, no hernia palpable; All other exam portions normal
- Test results: Alkaline phosphatase elevated at 156; lipid panel—total cholesterol 247, HDL 66, LDL 166, triglycerides 74; TSH normal at 2.68; CBC unremarkable; Vitamin D level high-normal at 94; Recent stress test on 9/9/2019; Echocardiogram pending

A (Assessment):

- History of aortic valve replacement and ascending aortic aneurysm repair, currently asymptomatic
- Elevated alkaline phosphatase, possibly related to bone health or liver function
- Right testicular nodule, requires urological evaluation
- Fatigue with decreased exercise tolerance
- Pursed-lip breathing with low exhalation phase, requires pulmonary function testing

P (Plan):

- Order echocardiogram and stress test for cardiac evaluation
- Order alkaline phosphatase and gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) labs today
- Order pulmonary function tests to evaluate pursed-lip breathing and low exhalation phase
- Refer to urology for evaluation of right testicular nodule, including possible ultrasound
- Administer MMR vaccine today, schedule shingles vaccine next month
- Recommend cardiology follow-up with Dr. Vincent Sanchez
- Patient to follow up for wellness visit in one year, sooner if needed after test results reviewed
- Patient to call clinic with any questions or concerns

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Anxiety, breast lumps
- History of present illness: Anxiety was severe in November and December with episodes starting usually during the day at work; anxiety improved with Buspar; anxiety appeared to spike the week before menstruation during that period; possible relation to hormonal changes uncertain; breast lumps remain present though smaller and sometimes painful, similar to past breastfeeding-related soreness; patient reports weight loss over past 6 months; no other issues reported
- Past medical history: Use of progesterone to regulate periods, prior abnormal Pap smear around 2009 requiring 6-month follow-up before normalization
- Social history: No detailed social history provided; reports family vaccination hesitancy (husband and daughter)
- Family history: Mother diagnosed with breast cancer at about age 45

O (Objective):

- Physical exam: Palpation of neck reveals small bumps smaller than before; left breast denser with palpable lumps tender in left lower region; knees relaxed and opened without discomfort; itching managed with cream used once weekly, requiring refill
- Test results: Last Pap smear in 2019 was negative; no new labs or imaging performed during visit

A (Assessment):

- Anxiety, currently improved with Buspar
- Breast lumps, benign etiology suspected (cysts, fibroadenomas)
- History of abnormal Pap smear with current negative status
- Concern for breast cancer due to family history and age, under surveillance

P (Plan):

- Continue Buspar for anxiety management
- Monitor breast lumps with ongoing surveillance; refer to breast specialist for further evaluation including possible ultrasound and timely biopsy if needed
- Repeat Pap smear for safety given history and recent stress/immunocompromise concerns
- Continue use of topical cream for itching and refill prescription
- Patient education provided regarding benign nature of breast lumps and importance of surveillance
- Follow-up arranged as needed, patient advised to contact clinic if new symptoms arise or concerns persist

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Establishing care for history of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)
* History of present illness: Right breast lumpectomy on January 20, 2020, following diagnosis of grade 2, ER positive, PR positive DCIS; no current breast problems or masses felt; performs regular self-breast exams; last mammogram January 2021 normal
* Past medical history: High cholesterol (recent diagnosis), managed with lifestyle changes; history of DCIS with stage 0 ER/PR positive invasive ductal carcinoma of right breast; tubal ligation after last pregnancy
* Social history: Former smoker (quit about 30 years ago), social alcohol use, no illicit drug use
* Family history: Mother with non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma; father with prostate cancer and heart disease; no family history of breast cancer; no siblings; children healthy
* Review of systems: Reports back pain and joint pain attributed to age; denies recent weight loss or gain, headaches, bone pain, urinary symptoms, or blood in stools
* Menstrual history: Postmenopausal for approximately 30 years
* Obstetric history: Gravida 5, para 5, no miscarriages or terminations
* Medications: CoQ10, vitamin D, vitamin C, fish oil, elderberry fruit supplements
* Allergies: Penicillin

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: No palpable breast masses; skin thickening noted at medial inferior aspect of right breast, consistent with radiation-induced skin changes
* ECOG performance status: 0 (fully active)
* Test results: Ultrasound 11/3/2019 showed 0.4 x 2 x 3 cm mass at 2 o’clock retroareolar right breast; core needle biopsy 12/5/2019 confirmed grade 2, ER positive, PR positive DCIS; pathology after lumpectomy 1/20/2020 showed 8 mm tumor with negative margins and five lymph nodes negative for malignancy; last mammogram January 2021 normal; colonoscopy 2018 found benign tubular adenoma polyp in sigmoid colon

A (Assessment):

* Stage 0 ER/PR positive invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast, status post right breast lumpectomy and radiation therapy
* High cholesterol
* Age-related back and joint pain

P (Plan):

* Continue clinical observation with annual follow-up visit
* Schedule screening mammogram in April 2022 prior to next visit
* No endocrine therapy initiated as patient declined
* Manage high cholesterol with lifestyle modifications (exercise and diet); monitored by primary care provider
* No additional imaging or interventions at this time
* Patient education and reassurance provided; no new concerns to address at this visit

transcription: [doctor] next patient is sophia jackson , mrnr 472348 . she is a 57-year-old female who is here for a surgical consult . [patient] her dermatologist referred her . she biopsied a 0.7 mm lesion which was located on the right inferior back . pathology came back as melanoma . [doctor] mrs. jackson , it's good to meet you . [patient] likewise , wish you were under better circumstances . [doctor] yeah , i heard your dermatologist sent you to because she found the melanoma . [patient] yes , that's what the biopsy said . [doctor] okay and when did you first notice the spot ? [patient] my mom noticed it when i was visiting her last month . [doctor] i see and so you went to the dermatologist on april 10 to get it checked out , right ? [patient] yes , i wanted to be extra cautious because skin cancer does run in my family . [doctor] well i'm really glad you took a serious and got it checked . who in your family has had skin cancer and do you know if it was melanoma or was it basal cell or squamous cell ? [patient] my mom and her sister i think they both had melanoma . [doctor] okay . do you have any other types of cancer in the family like breast or ovarian ? [patient] my grandfather had pancreatic cancer . [doctor] okay and what about your mom or dad's father ? [patient] mother's . [doctor] okay and have you personally had any skin spots in the past that you got checked out and they were cancerous or precancerous ? [patient] no , this was the first time i've been to a dermatologist but my primary care doctor looks over all of my moles every year . my physical and has n't said he is concerned about any of them before . [doctor] good , good . let's go over your medical history here in your chart . i have that you are not taking any medications and do n't have any health problems listed , but that you are allergic to augmentin , is that right ? [patient] yes , that's correct . [doctor] okay and for social history , can you tell me what you do for work ? [patient] i own an auto repair shop . okay and have you ever been a smoker ? yeah , i still smoke from time to time . i started that awful habit in my teens and it's hard to break , but i'm trying . [doctor] i'm glad you're trying to quit . what about your surgical history ? have you had any surgeries ? [patient] i had gallbladder and appendix . [doctor] okay , great . we can get your chart up to date now , thank you . and other than the melanoma , how has your health been ? any unintentional weight changes , headaches , fatigue , nausea , vomiting , vision changes ? [patient] no , i've been feeling great . [doctor] good . well , let me take a look at your back here where they did the biopsy if you do n't mind . [patient] sure . [doctor] okay . i'm gon na describe it in medical jargon , what i'm seeing here so that the recording can capture it , but you and i are gon na go over it together in just a moment , okay ? [patient] okay , that's fine . [doctor] alright , so on the right inferior back , there is a 1 cm shave biopsy site including all of the dermis with no residual pigmentation there is no intrinsic or satellite lesions . no other suspicious moles . no axillary , cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy . there is a soft lymph node in the right groin but it's nontender . otherwise normal exam . [patient] okay , you can sit up . so what i was saying there is that i see your biopsy site , but i do n't see any other skin lumps or bumps that look suspicious . [doctor] i also felt your lymph nodes to see if any of them felt abnormal . there is one in the right groin that felt slightly abnormal . it's very likely nothing , but i do want you to have an ultrasound of that area to confirm it's nothing . and you know make sure it's something we need to worry about the reason we are being extra cautious is that melanoma can very rarely metastasize to the lymph nodes . the ultrasound can tell us if we need to look into this further . [patient] okay . i should have worried too much then . [doctor] no , i have a low suspicion that it will show anything . [patient] okay , good . [doctor] so assuming that the ultrasound is normal . the treatment for your melanoma is to cut out the area where the lesion was . with lesions that are 0.7 mm or less and that's what we recommend and yours was exactly 0.7 mm . if it were any bigger , we would have had to do a more complex surgery , but what i recommend for you is what we call a wide local incision , excuse me , excision meaning that i will make a long incision and then cut out an area a bit wider than your current biopsy site . the incision is long because that's what allows me to close the skin nicely . you'll have a fairly long scar from the incision . [patient] okay , that is fine with me . i ca n't see back there anyways . [doctor] yeah , your wife can tell you what it looks like and she may need to help care for the incision at it as it heals . but since we're we are n't doing the more complex surgery , i actually do n't need to see you back unless you wan na check in with me or have any problems , however , it is very important that you continue to follow up with your dermatologist regularly , so she can monitor you . your dermatologist will check if this one does n't come back , but she will also check for other lesions that look suspicious . unfortunately since you had one melanoma , you are at a higher risk of developing another one somewhere else . [patient] yeah , she did say she wants to see me back . [doctor] good and i'm sure she has already told you , but it's very important that you apply sunscreen anytime and anywhere that your skin is exposed to sunlight . [patient] yeah , she definitely went over that several times with me . [doctor] good . other than that , i think that's all for me . we'll get you set up for the ultrasound and the procedure . do you have any questions for me ? [patient] no , i ca n't think of any at this time . [doctor] okay . my nurse will be in to get you scheduled . so sit tight . it was very good to meet you . [patient] thank you . nice to meet you as well . [doctor] please add the following pathology to results a pathology , shave of right inferior back , malignant melanoma , invasive superficial spreading , histology , superficial spreading . clark level iv , breslow thickness 0.7 mm , radial growth phase present , vertical growth phase not identified , mitotic features less than 1 mm² , ulceration not identified , regression not identified , [patient] lymphatic invasion not identified . perineural invasion not identified , microscopic satellitosis not identified , infiltrating lymphocytes , breast , [doctor] melanocytic nevus not identified , predominant cytology , epithelioid , peripheral margin positive , deep margin negative , stage i . also note that i reviewed the dermatologist photo of the lesion , which showed an asymmetric black and brown nevus with central asmelanotic component and a regular border . for assessment and plan , the patient presents today with newly diagnosed melanoma . biopsy revealed an intermediate thickness melanoma . on examination today , there is right inguinal lymph node with slightly atypical consistency . [patient] i recommended an ultrasound to rule out metastatic disease . if the ultrasound is normal , the patient is a candidate for wide local excision with a 1 to 2 cm margin . primary closure should be possible , but skin graft closure may be needed . the relationship between tumor histology and prognosis and treatment was carefully reviewed . the need for follow-up according to the national comprehensive cancer network guidelines was reviewed . we also reviewed the principles of sun avoidance , skin self-examination and the abcde's of mole surveillance . after discussing the procedure , risk and expected outcomes and possible complications , questions were answered and the patient expressed understanding and did choose to proceed .
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Consult for surgical management of melanoma
* History of present illness: Noticed a lesion on right inferior back identified by patient's mother last month; biopsy on April 10 revealed melanoma with 0.7 mm Breslow thickness; first time seeing a dermatologist; no previous skin cancer; annual mole checks by primary care physician without concerns
* Past medical history: No health problems listed; allergic to Augmentin
* Surgical history: Gallbladder and appendix removal surgeries
* Family history: Mother and maternal aunt had melanoma; maternal grandfather had pancreatic cancer
* Social history: Owns an auto repair shop; occasional smoker since teens, trying to quit
* Other symptoms: No unintentional weight changes, headaches, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, or vision changes

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Right inferior back shows 1 cm shave biopsy site with no residual pigmentation, no intrinsic or satellite lesions, no other suspicious moles; no axillary, cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy; soft, nontender lymph node in right groin with slightly atypical consistency; otherwise normal exam
* Test results: Pathology of shave biopsy:
  - Malignant melanoma, invasive superficial spreading type
  - Clark level IV
  - Breslow thickness 0.7 mm
  - Radial growth phase present, vertical growth phase not identified
  - Mitotic rate less than 1/mm²
  - No ulceration, regression, lymphatic invasion, perineural invasion, microscopic satellitosis, or melanocytic nevus identified
  - Predominant cytology epithelioid
  - Peripheral margin positive, deep margin negative
  - Stage I melanoma
* Additional data: Review of dermatologist's photo showed asymmetric black and brown nevus with central amelanotic component and regular border

A (Assessment):

* Newly diagnosed melanoma, intermediate thickness (0.7 mm Breslow)
* Stage I melanoma
* Right inguinal lymph node with slightly atypical consistency, ultrasound recommended to rule out metastatic disease

P (Plan):

* Order ultrasound of right inguinal lymph node to exclude metastasis
* If ultrasound normal, proceed with wide local excision of biopsy site with 1 to 2 cm margin
* Primary closure anticipated, skin graft closure possible if needed
* Emphasize regular dermatology follow-up for surveillance of melanoma recurrence or new lesions per national comprehensive cancer network guidelines
* Educate patient on sun avoidance, skin self-examination, and ABCDEs of mole surveillance
* Address procedure risks, expected outcomes, and possible complications; patient expressed understanding and chose to proceed
* Scheduling of ultrasound and surgical procedure to be arranged by nursing staff

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Pain and stiffness in the right index finger after hyperextension injury during a motor vehicle accident in March 2021
* History of present illness: Right index finger injured about 3 months ago after rear-end collision; persistent pain, swelling, inability to make a full fist, numbness at fingertip, sometimes unbearable pain including with driving; finger rests in about 10 degrees of PIP flexion; prior MRI showed partial thickness tear of flexor digitorum superficialis tendon with tenosynovitis, intact collateral ligaments and extensor tendons; prior occupational therapy and physical therapy with limited improvement; patient reluctant to receive steroid injections previously due to reaction to dexamethasone causing heart racing and itching with methylprednisolone
* Past medical history: Hypertension treated with one blood pressure medication; no diabetes or rheumatoid arthritis
* Social history: Works as an x-ray technician; drives himself
* Allergies/adverse reactions: Reaction to dexamethasone causing heart racing; itching with methylprednisolone

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No specific vital signs provided
* Physical exam: Pleasant, cooperative male in no distress; heart rate regular; 2+ radial pulse; no swelling or bruising on palm volar surface of right index finger; slightly diminished skin creases over tip of right index finger compared to middle finger; right index finger rests in 10-degree PIP flexed position; pain elicited on pushing and bending finger; limited active flexion and extension of tip and middle joints of right index finger; collateral ligaments and extensor tendons intact; no bony abnormalities or arthritis on four-view right hand x-rays; MRI (4/24/2021) showed focal soft tissue swelling over right index MCP joint, partial thickness tear of right FDS tendon, fluid consistent with tenosynovitis around FDP and FDS tendons, intact radial and ulnar collateral ligaments, intact MCP joint capsule and extensor tendons
* Procedure: Attempted right index finger trigger finger injection with 1 cc Celestone (betamethasone) and 0.5 cc lidocaine twice; initial injection aborted due to violent painful reaction and hand withdrawal; second attempt successful with minor bleeding from small palmar vein controlled with bandage; patient reassured; post-procedure recommendations: icing and ibuprofen

A (Assessment):

* Posttraumatic rather severe stenosing tenosynovitis of right index finger
* Partial thickness tear of right flexor digitorum superficialis tendon (least important of flexors), intact flexor digitorum profundus tendon
* Prior intolerance to dexamethasone and methylprednisolone steroid preparations

P (Plan):

* Administered trigger finger steroid injection with 1 cc betamethasone (Celestone) mixed with 0.5 cc lidocaine in right index finger flexor tendon sheath
* Recommend icing and ibuprofen for post-procedure pain and swelling
* Outpatient occupational/physical therapy scheduled once weekly for 6 weeks focusing on active and passive range of motion exercises targeting right index finger with goal of no restrictions
* Patient education: Importance of finger movement post-injection to reduce stiffness and pain; reassurance regarding safety of driving
* Monitor response to steroid injection; consider repeat injection if necessary
* Follow-up evaluation to assess progress with therapy and symptom improvement

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right hip pain in the groin area  
- History of present illness: Right groin pain starting February 2020, initially triggered by stepping backward while walking in the infusion room, now occurs with any movement, especially pivoting; pain severity ranges from 2 to 7 out of 10; occasional episodes cause almost falling; pain sometimes occurs multiple times in a row; no fever, chills, tingling, numbness, bowel or bladder problems; pain improves with stillness but patient does not want to remain still  
- Past medical history: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), infertility, gallbladder removed  
- Family history: High blood pressure, diabetes, thyroid disease, heart disease, kidney disease, gastric ulcers  
- Social history: Works at an infusion center, lives with a roommate, no tobacco use, alcohol less than five drinks per month  
- Allergies: Percocet, Vicodin, Reglan  
- Weight loss: Lost 110 pounds through Weight Watchers since 2018, current weight stable for over a year  

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 115/75 mmHg, pulse 67/min  
- Physical exam: Pleasant 56-year-old woman, height 5’6”, weight 169 pounds; ankles normal, no edema, no calf tenderness; able to walk on toes and heels; full cervical spine range of motion without pain or tenderness, negative Spurling’s test; no lumbar spine pain or midline tenderness, decreased range of motion with exertion, several bulging discs noted but no current low back pain; sacroiliac signs negative  
- Hip exam: Trochanteric area non-tender; minimal discomfort lifting right knee; decreased range of motion in right hip with pain in groin on internal and external rotation; resisted right hip flexion causes pain in right groin; no tenderness on palpation; normal lower extremity motor control; deep tendon reflexes 1+ throughout; no focal motor weakness or sensory deficit noted  
- Imaging: MR arthrogram of right hip (June 3, 2021) shows high grade chondromalacia involving anterosuperior right acetabulum with subchondral marrow edema and cyst formation  

A (Assessment):

- Right hip degenerative joint disease  

P (Plan):

- Initiate low-impact exercise program with provided handout  
- Use NSAIDs as needed for pain relief  
- Use cane to offload right side to reduce pain, patient reluctant but agreed to try  
- Proceed with cortisone injection into right hip joint today after informed consent  
- Schedule follow-up in 3 months for reassessment and possible repeat injection  
- Educate patient on risks associated with injection, including needle risks, sterile technique, and COVID-19 considerations

S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up for hypogonadism, concern about gynecomastia
* History of present illness: On testosterone replacement therapy 1 ml every 10 days, baseline testosterone levels less than 300 ng/dL, currently reports feeling good, more vigorous, sleeping well, some positive effects noticed in blood work, stable weight and muscle mass; taking finasteride half a 5 mg pill daily; taking Cialis daily (5 mg on workout days, 2.5 mg on other days, currently out of Cialis); interested in possibly increasing testosterone dose to 175 mg from 140 mg but advised against it; patient uses a medication calendar for adherence
* Past medical history: HIV positive
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Heart and lung auscultation normal, no concerns noted
* Test results: Last PSA 0.66 ng/mL (stable, previous 0.5 ng/mL), last testosterone level greater than 1500 ng/dL at peak, current approximate level around 700 ng/dL on day 8 of cycle; triglycerides improved from 265 mg/dL pre-testosterone to 145 mg/dL after 5 months of therapy; red blood cell count increased but stable; estradiol tested previously and not elevated

A (Assessment):

* Hypogonadism
* Gynecomastia, discussed but no explicit diagnosis confirmed
* HIV positive status

P (Plan):

* Continue testosterone replacement therapy at current dosing (1 ml every 10 days), no dose increase recommended due to high peak testosterone levels and risk of blood thickening
* Continue finasteride half tablet daily and Cialis as needed; patient to receive paper prescriptions for these medications
* Monitor PSA yearly
* Consider repeating estradiol testing in the fall if desired
* Patient education about risks of high-dose testosterone use and benefits observed in triglycerides and overall well-being
* Follow-up as needed with laboratory monitoring and clinical assessment

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Shortness of breath, coughing up blood
- History of present illness: Shortness of breath for about two weeks, worsening upon waking and with exertion; coughing up blood for about three weeks, approximately three to four cups per day; no vomiting blood or bleeding from other sites; no fevers; no leg swelling or calf tenderness; knee pain without swelling ongoing for some time
- Past medical history: Diabetes, high blood pressure, asthma
- Medications: Metformin, Norvasc (currently held due to low blood pressure episodes)
- Diabetes control: Blood sugar fluctuating with post-meal spikes over 200 mg/dL, morning glucose around 150 mg/dL; last hemoglobin A1c approximately 7.7%
- Blood pressure control: Occasional low readings in the lower 90s; recent readings around 120/70 mmHg; Norvasc taken irregularly due to low blood pressure
- Social history: No recent travel or flights reported
- Other: No history of bruising or bleeding gums

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Pulse oximetry 94% on room air; blood pressure approximately 120/70 mmHg during visit
- Physical exam: No jugular venous distention, no carotid bruits; lung exam reveals rales and rhonchi predominantly on right side with diminished breath sounds; no wheezing; heart exam shows 2/6 systolic ejection murmur unchanged from prior, regular rate and rhythm; abdomen soft without tenderness; extremities with 1+ nonpitting edema bilaterally at ankles, no calf tenderness, negative Homan sign

A (Assessment):

- Differential diagnosis: Possible pneumonia or pulmonary pathology causing cough and hemoptysis
- Concern for pulmonary embolism or other significant chest pathology needing evaluation
- Diabetes mellitus with suboptimal glycemic control
- Hypertension currently withheld from medication due to low blood pressure and acute illness

P (Plan):

- Immediate referral to emergency department for chest x-ray, chest CT scan, and blood testing to evaluate cause of shortness of breath and hemoptysis
- Hold Norvasc until further assessment and stabilization
- Order hemoglobin A1c during acute evaluation; consider increasing metformin dose from 500 mg twice daily to 750 mg twice daily after acute illness resolves
- Schedule follow-up in approximately three weeks to reassess diabetes management and blood pressure after acute episode resolves
- Patient education on urgent symptoms and instructions for emergency evaluation completed; transportation to emergency department arranged; patient confirmed ability to travel independently

diagnosis is gon na be coronary artery disease right you already have a history of that but you know we're gon na do some things to make we're gon na continue to evaluate that over time i want you to continue your aspirin eighty one milligrams daily and your brilinta ninety milligrams twice daily i wan na continue you on a high dose statin called lipitor and you're gon na be taking that eighty SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Follow-up after inferior STEMI and stent placement
* History of present illness: Experienced severe chest pain similar to previous heart attack leading to emergency room visit and additional stent placement; currently no chest pain or shortness of breath; able to walk dog daily for 1.5 to 2 miles
* Past medical history: Coronary artery disease with RCA stent placed in 2018, hypertension, diabetes
* Symptoms: Noticed mild leg swelling since hospital discharge, occasional need to sit up at night using pillows but no major orthopnea
* Medication adherence: Able to afford and is taking prescribed medications as directed
* Diet: Has not been strict with salt intake recently, prefers high-salt foods such as pepperoni pizza and fries, willing to improve diet
* Diabetes management: Monitoring blood sugars, taking metformin, trying to remain active to avoid insulin therapy
* Social history: No specific information on tobacco or alcohol use provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No abnormalities reported
* Physical exam: No jugular venous distention, no carotid bruits; 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base; clear lung sounds; mild pitting edema (1+) of lower limbs; right radial artery catheter site clean, dry, intact without hematoma; right radial pulses palpable
* Test results: EKG shows normal sinus rhythm, good R wave progression, expected post-STEMI changes; echocardiogram reveals reduced left ventricular ejection fraction of 35%, moderate mitral regurgitation

A (Assessment):

* Coronary artery disease
* Newly reduced left ventricular function
* Moderate mitral regurgitation
* Acute heart failure, suspected
* Hypertension

P (Plan):

* Continue aspirin 81 mg daily and Brilinta (ticagrelor) 90 mg twice daily
* Continue atorvastatin (Lipitor) 80 mg daily
* Continue metoprolol succinate (Toprol) 50 mg daily
* Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily
* Initiate furosemide (Lasix) 40 mg once daily
* Add spironolactone (Aldactone) 12.5 mg daily
* Refer to cardiac rehabilitation program for education and exercise support
* Nutrition counseling to address salt intake and diet modifications including reduction of preserved meats such as pepperoni
* Repeat echocardiogram in approximately two months
* Obtain laboratory studies (specific labs not specified)

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Right knee injury after feeling a pop while playing pickup soccer three days ago
- History of present illness: Swelling noted initially which has decreased somewhat, pain rated between 6 and 7 out of 10, reduced to 4 or 5 with ibuprofen; limited knee motion with pain at end range of bending and difficulty fully straightening knee; sensation of knee instability and looseness; able to bear weight but with a marked limp; discomfort sitting for extended periods at work
- Past medical history: No information provided
- Social history: Regular jogging prior to injury, currently advised to slow down and avoid jogging
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No information provided
- Physical exam: Marked limp on right leg ambulation, significant right knee effusion, slight ecchymosis, tenderness on medial joint line palpation, limited passive range of motion with approximately 115 degrees of terminal extension and 20–30 degrees terminal flexion loss due to pain, positive Lachman exam indicating anterior cruciate ligament instability, neurovascularly intact bilateral lower extremities, muscle strength 5/5 in lower extremities
- Test results: No imaging performed yet; MRI ordered for further evaluation

A (Assessment):

- Right knee injury suggestive of anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear

P (Plan):

- Order MRI of right knee to evaluate ACL integrity
- Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily for pain and swelling control
- Recommend icing right knee as needed for swelling and pain
- Advise activity moderation including wearing a knee immobilizer and using crutches to reduce stress on the knee
- Limit work activities with encouragement to perform slight movements to prevent stiffness, avoid prolonged sitting
- Advise no jogging until MRI results and further evaluation
- Schedule follow-up after MRI results are available

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Concern about multiple medications, dizziness when standing up quickly, feeling down since heart attack, occasional leg puffiness
- History of present illness: History of heart attack six months ago with stent placement in left anterior descending artery, currently on aspirin, Brilinta, Crestor, metoprolol, and fish oil; dizziness on standing attributed to metoprolol; diabetes with poor glycemic control (HbA1c approximately 16), occasional craving for sweets; stage 3 chronic kidney disease diagnosed; no suicidal or homicidal ideation, feels lonely living only with dog
- Past medical history: Heart attack, diabetes, stage 3 chronic kidney disease
- Social history: Lives alone with dog, describes feeling lonely
- Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 127/80 mmHg
- Physical exam: No jugular venous distention or carotid bruits; grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base; mild 1+ nonpitting lower extremity edema
- Test results: Kidney function stable (creatinine normal post-contrast dye); last HbA1c approximately 16 (very high)

A (Assessment):

- Coronary artery disease with history of stent placement
- Stage 3 chronic kidney disease
- Diabetes mellitus with poor glycemic control
- Possible mild depression or difficulty adjusting post-heart attack, suspected

P (Plan):

- Refill metoprolol 50 mg once daily, Crestor 40 mg once daily, aspirin, Brilinta continuation for six months, continue fish oil
- Refer to cardiac rehabilitation for activity and exercise confidence
- Refer to nephrologist (Dr. Miller) for kidney disease follow-up
- Order repeat hemoglobin A1c test
- Refer to dietitian for diabetes dietary education and counseling
- Coordinate with primary care physician regarding insulin regimen
- Refer to psychiatry for evaluation and management of mood symptoms related to post-heart attack adjustment
- Advise avoidance of NSAIDs; recommend acetaminophen (Tylenol) for headache or pain
- Monitor for any symptoms of chest pain or shortness of breath; no stress test currently indicated
- Medication refills to be sent electronically to patient’s pharmacy

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Numbness and tingling in the right hand
* History of present illness: On and off numbness and tingling in right hand for approximately six months, more persistent over the last month; some pain mostly while typing on the keyboard and using the mouse; numbness and tingling present all the time; pain improves with rest and ibuprofen; no night pain or sleep disturbance
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Uses a keyboard extensively for work (data entry)
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Pain on wrist flexion and extension; reduced grip strength in the right hand compared to the left; positive Tinel's sign on tapping inside of right wrist causing shooting pain

A (Assessment):

* Carpal tunnel syndrome

P (Plan):

* Prescribe wrist splint to be worn at night
* Continue ibuprofen up to 600 mg four times daily
* Order outpatient EMG nerve conduction study of the wrist
* Conservative treatment initially; possible physical therapy or surgery to release nerve impingement depending on EMG results
* Patient education provided regarding condition and treatment options; follow-up planned after EMG results are available

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Numbness and tingling in left fingers and pain in left wrist for several months
* History of present illness: Symptoms started gradually without known cause, mostly noticed at night with hand numbness causing awakening and the need to shake out the hand; numbness affects all fingers but more prominent in thumb and pointer finger; occasional numbness in the little finger; no symptoms in right hand
* Social history: Works as a landscaper performing heavy labor with repetitive movements such as raking and digging; consumes alcohol socially, about one to two beers on Fridays and Saturdays
* Past medical history: No history or diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis in hands or wrists noted

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Slightly decreased grip strength and weakness in left hand compared to right; decreased sensation reported on left thumb and pointer finger sides; bilateral positive Tinel’s sign on wrist tapping causing tingling sensation in fingertips; heart and lung auscultation normal
* Test results: No information provided yet; planned electromyography (EMG) study ordered

A (Assessment):

* Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome, suspected due to history of repetitive heavy labor and clinical exam findings

P (Plan):

* Order EMG study to measure nerve conduction in fingers
* Recommend activity modification with reduction of repetitive motions and delegation of heavy work duties
* Prescribe wrist splint for support
* Prescribe ibuprofen 600 mg orally every 6 hours for pain management
* Follow-up appointment scheduled in 2 weeks to reassess and consider further diagnostic testing or possible surgical intervention if needed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Sudden onset of right back pain about one week ago
- History of present illness: Pain started while working in the barn, moving hay; initially thought to be musculoskeletal; pain radiated almost to the right groin; associated with sweating and nausea; pain episodes have decreased in frequency and intensity since initial onset; currently no pain or only localized right back discomfort; straining urine with no visible stones or blood; no change in urine color
- Past medical history: No previous kidney stones
- Family history: Father has a history of kidney stones
- Social history: No information provided

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Normal blood pressure, heart rate, no fever
- Physical exam: Abdomen non-tender on palpation, no rebound or guarding; costovertebral angle (CVA) tenderness on the right side
- Test results: CT scan shows 0.5 cm stone in proximal right ureter; no hydronephrosis observed; pending basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture

A (Assessment):

- Kidney stone in proximal right ureter

P (Plan):

- Advise increased fluid intake to facilitate stone passage
- Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours for pain control
- Recommend acetaminophen as needed for breakthrough pain
- Continue using urine strainer to catch stone fragments
- Order basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture to assess for infection or other abnormalities
- Monitor urinalysis results to determine need for antibiotics
- Schedule follow-up appointment in 1 to 2 weeks to assess stone passage
- Discuss lithotripsy as a non-invasive treatment option if stone does not pass by follow-up

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Inside pain of the right knee after injury playing basketball
* History of present illness: Injured right knee 7 days ago when another player ran into her causing her to fall to the ground landing on her side; unable to continue playing; pain localized to the inside of the knee; swelling present since injury; no popping sound or sensation at time of injury; currently using ice, an ace wrap, exercises, and Motrin for pain
* Past medical history: Diabetes mellitus managed with metformin 500 mg twice daily
* Social history: Plays basketball recreationally at the Y; family owns a sports equipment store
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: Swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on the medial (inside) aspect of the right knee; small knee effusion observed; full range of motion decreased with pain on extension and flexion especially with forced movement; negative varus and valgus stress tests; no lateral knee pain on palpation; no deformities observed
* Test results: Right knee x-ray shows normal bony alignment without fractures, small effusion noted

A (Assessment):

* Medial collateral ligament strain of the right knee, suspected

P (Plan):

* Continue using ace wrap and begin wearing right knee brace for support
* Discontinue nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (Motrin/Advil) and start meloxicam 15 mg daily for pain and swelling
* Initiate physical therapy for strengthening muscles around the knee
* Encourage light walking as tolerated
* Monitor diabetes closely with daily blood sugar checks; follow up with primary care provider if blood sugar control worsens due to decreased activity
* Return appointment in 7 days to reassess knee swelling and function; consider further imaging such as MRI or CT scan if symptoms persist or worsen
* Patient education provided on activity modification and injury care; advised to avoid basketball until follow-up evaluation

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Severe left back pain for 3 days, constant in nature, radiating downward, not passed kidney stone yet
* History of present illness: Pain started 3 days ago on left back, traveling lower, constant pain, associated with blood in urine this morning, nausea without fever, chills present, unable to eat due to pain
* Past medical history: Hypertension, diabetes, previous kidney stones (3 episodes including current)
* Medications: Norvasc 2.5 mg for hypertension, Metformin 500 mg for diabetes, taking Tylenol and ibuprofen for pain without adequate relief
* Social history: No information provided
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Blood pressure elevated (patient reports home readings systolic 130-150s, diastolic 70-80)
* Physical exam: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur on heart auscultation, clear lungs bilaterally without crackles or wheezes, abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding, costovertebral angle (CVA) tenderness on right flank, painful abdominal and back palpation
* Test results: Last HbA1c 7.3, recent blood glucose readings in low 100s, prior glucose test around 300 mg/dL

A (Assessment):

* Kidney stone with associated inflammation and pain
* Hypertension, stable on current medication
* Diabetes mellitus, controlled on Metformin

P (Plan):

* Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain
* Continue Tylenol for breakthrough pain
* Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate passage of kidney stone
* Provide urine strainer to capture passed stones
* Refer to urology for evaluation of recurrent kidney stones regardless of stone passage
* Continue Norvasc 2.5 mg for hypertension, no change
* Continue Metformin 500 mg for diabetes, no change
* Refer to dietitian for nutritional counseling to assist with dietary control, especially salt intake and overall diabetes management
* Encourage regular blood pressure monitoring with home cuff and adherence to dietary modifications

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Bilateral elbow pain, worse in the right elbow
* History of present illness: Elbow pain started approximately 1.5 years ago, located on the inside (medial) of both elbows, worsens with use of hands or arms, no relief from icing, pain with flexion, extension, and supination but not pronation; denies previous similar pain during youth sports (basketball, baseball, football)
* Past medical history: No information provided
* Social history: Weightlifting heavily to stay in shape, no recent golfing or pitching activity
* Family history: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Medial elbow pain with palpation, limited extension range of motion bilaterally, pain with flexion, extension, and supination on both elbows (right more than left), no pain on lateral elbow palpation, normal finger sensation, equal pulses in all extremities
* Test results: X-rays show no fractures or bony misalignment

A (Assessment):

* Medial epicondylitis (golfer’s elbow), suspected

P (Plan):

* Order MRI of right elbow to further evaluate condition
* Plan for whole blood injection therapy (autologous blood transfusion into tendon) to promote healing
* Schedule procedure within next few weeks for expected recovery in approximately two weeks
* Monitor healing especially considering upcoming newborn arrival

and sensation that it's intact to light touch now i would like to do a review of the diagnostic imaging that you had before you came in so i do notice a subtle dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal with a three millimeter separation of the first and second metatarsal bases and the presence of a bony fragment in the lisfranc joint space so lem me talk to you a little bit about my assessment and plan now for for the first concern of right foot pain your right foot pain is due to a lisfranc fracture which is a fracture to one of your second metatarsal bones at the top of your foot where the metatarsals meet your cuboids now there are ligaments at the top of your foot so i'm gon na be ordering an mri to assess for injury to any of these ligaments now based on your exam and from what i'm seeing on your x-ray you're most likely going to need surgery of that foot now the surgery will place the bones back in their proper position and using plates and screws will hold them there while they heal and this is gon na allow those bones and ligaments to heal properly it is a day surgery and you will be able to go home the same day and then i'm going to have you follow up with me here in the clinic you'll be in a cast and you will need to use crutches and you will not be able to use that left foot for about six to eight weeks now after that six to eight weeks you will gradually start walking on your foot based on how you tolerate it and we'll see how you do at that point so i do believe you're gon na need surgery i i'm recommending this because there are significant complications to your foot if we do not do this poor bone and ligament healing can lead to losing the arch of your foot and you're becoming flat-footed you also have a high likelihood of developing arthritis in that foot so what i'm gon na do unfortunately you'll be out the rest of the season but we are gon na get you fixed up and ready for next season if you're okay with all of this i'm gon na have the nurse come in and get you started on your paperwork and then i will see you on monday morning and we will get your foot taken care of
[patient] alright thank you
[doctor] you're welcome
SOAP:
S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Left foot pain after injury during a soccer game
- History of present illness: Injured left foot yesterday when another player fell onto it; experienced twisting of body and immediate pain; unable to continue playing and was helped off the field; pain level 3/10 with ibuprofen, 7-8/10 without; started icing, elevation, compression, and taking ibuprofen since injury
- Past medical history: No prior left foot injuries; multiple soccer-related injuries otherwise
- Social history: Long-term soccer player since age 4-5, played in local and school teams
- Neurologic symptoms: No numbness, tingling, or strange sensations reported

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: Blood pressure 118/72 mmHg, heart rate 58 bpm, respiratory rate 14/min, afebrile, O2 saturation 99% on room air
- Physical exam: Bruising on dorsal and plantar surfaces of left foot; swelling; tenderness to palpation of midfoot; positive piano key test; brisk capillary refill <3 seconds; intact and strong dorsalis pedis pulse; intact motor and sensory function to light touch
- Cardiopulmonary exam: Regular rate and rhythm; no murmurs, clicks, rubs, or ectopic beats; lungs clear and equal bilaterally
- Imaging: X-ray shows subtle dorsal displacement of base of second metatarsal, 3 mm separation between first and second metatarsal bases, and a bony fragment in the Lisfranc joint space

A (Assessment):

- Lisfranc fracture of the left foot involving the base of the second metatarsal with associated joint displacement

P (Plan):

- Order MRI to assess ligamentous injury in Lisfranc joint
- Recommend surgical intervention to realign bones and stabilize with plates and screws as day surgery
- Postoperative management: immobilization in a cast, non-weight bearing with crutches for 6 to 8 weeks
- Gradual weight-bearing after immobilization based on tolerance
- Schedule follow-up clinic visit on Monday morning to initiate surgery planning and paperwork completion
- Patient education provided regarding risks of nonoperative management including arch collapse and arthritis development
- Advise patient that recovery will prevent complications but preclude participation for the rest of the current soccer season

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days, loose and watery stools about six to seven times a day, lower abdominal pain on one side, headache rated 8/10, crampy and comes and goes, weakness and shakiness, loss of appetite, vomiting only at the start of symptoms but now stopped, no fever currently but had a temperature around symptom onset, no blood in stools or vomit, blurred vision reported, no neck pain or stiffness, no rashes
* History of present illness: Diarrhea impacting day-to-day activities and work, headache started three days ago with increasing severity, no relief from ibuprofen taken (three tablets per day), headache described as similar to migraine
* Past medical history: Asthma, uses inhaler (under control), no other medications
* Family history: Mother and sister have migraines, both well controlled
* Social history: Accountant, working currently though symptoms are affecting work, no regular smoking or alcohol use, some social alcohol consumption
* Allergies: No information provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No information provided
* Physical exam: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Headache very similar to migraine based on history and family history
* No explicit diagnosis for diarrhea provided

P (Plan):

* Advise stronger analgesia for headache: correct ibuprofen dose up to two tablets three times a day or prescribe Naproxen (another anti-inflammatory)
* Consider adding Paracetamol or Codeine as additional painkillers
* Recommend keeping a headache diary to identify possible triggers
* Follow-up appointment in one to two weeks to assess headache frequency and consider prophylactic treatment if headaches become frequent
* Advise patient to seek earlier medical attention if headaches worsen, vision problems, limb weakness, or general deterioration occurs

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days, frequent loose and watery stools, abdominal pain described as cramp on the left lower side, weakness and shakiness
* History of present illness: Diarrhea occurring six to seven times a day, watery stools without blood, some abdominal cramping, loss of appetite, able to hold down fluids, initial vomiting that has now stopped, no current fever but felt hot around symptom onset 3–4 days ago, mild cough about six to seven times a day without sputum or blood, intermittent runny nose, no sore throat or ear pain, slight shortness of breath controlled with inhaler for asthma, no chest pain, muscle and joint stiffness reported all over, no smoking or alcohol use, no similar symptoms in close family except one child with vomiting but no diarrhea
* Past medical history: Asthma, hypertension, diabetes (type not specified)
* Medications: Uses inhaler for asthma, on Lisinopril
* Allergies: Medication allergies (details not specified)
* Social history: Lives with wife and two children, works as an accountant, does not smoke or drink alcohol

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No specific measurements provided
* Physical exam: Patient has sniffles and runny nose, mild abdominal tenderness described indirectly, no chest pain or respiratory distress observed
* Test results: No tests performed or reported

A (Assessment):

* Viral illness, suspected (possible early signs of flu)
* No diagnosis of chest infection made, antibiotics to be considered if symptoms worsen
* Asthma, stable on inhaler
* Hypertension and diabetes, no further details provided

P (Plan):

* Supportive care with rest and plenty of fluids
* Use regular Paracetamol if feeling hot, cold, or sweaty
* Prescribe Amoxicillin 1 tablet three times a day to be started within 24 to 48 hours if symptoms such as breathlessness and feeling run-down do not improve
* Advise patient to return for review if symptoms persist beyond one week
* Reinforce asthma inhaler use as needed
* No further investigations planned at this time

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
* History of present illness: Loose, watery stool about six or seven times a day, associated with lower left abdominal cramping pain described as muscular cramps, feeling weak and shaky, intermittent ear ringing, vomiting at onset which has now stopped, no blood in stool or vomit, no numbness present currently, loss of appetite with reduced food intake mainly soups, smoothies, and liquids, no fever currently but had a temperature around symptom onset, no difficulty swallowing or speaking, no visual problems, no ear discharge but mild ear pain and itchiness reported
* Past medical history: Asthma controlled with inhaler
* Medications: Nasal spray for nose (name unknown), asthma inhaler, no other regular medications
* Allergies: Latex allergy
* Social history: Non-smoker, does not drink alcohol, works as an accountant, lives alone, no pets, no recent unusual food other than takeaway at a Chinese restaurant four days ago
* Family history: No one else with same symptoms; family history notable only for asthma

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No current fever recorded, patient reports prior temperature elevation
* Physical exam: No physical exam findings documented due to video consultation
* Test results: No investigations performed or reported

A (Assessment):

* Possible Bell’s Palsy, suspected
* Need for neurological examination to confirm diagnosis and exclude other causes

P (Plan):

* Arrange face-to-face clinic appointment today for full physical and neurological examination including ear inspection
* Provide patient with support team contact number to book suitable appointment time
* Reassure patient preliminarily that condition is unlikely to be life-threatening
* Advise patient to attend the clinic appointment promptly for definitive assessment and diagnosis confirmation

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days, loose and watery stool about six to seven times a day, lower abdominal pain on one side, weakness and shakiness, intermittent cramps in left elbow, loss of appetite, vomiting at onset but now stopped, feeling hot initially but no current fever, dry skin on the tip of the left elbow, asthma controlled with inhaler
* History of present illness: Diarrhea affecting day-to-day activities, need to stay close to the toilet, no blood in stool, no current vomiting, difficulty going to work due to symptoms
* Past medical history: Asthma controlled with inhaler, suspected osteoarthritis in the left elbow confirmed previously by a GP, no other medications regularly taken
* Social history: Accountant, does not smoke or drink alcohol, recently ate takeaway and had a meal at a Chinese restaurant with friends
* Family history: No rheumatology diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis or lupus, no one in household with diarrhea, one child had vomiting without diarrhea

O (Objective):

* Physical exam: Left elbow slightly warmer than surrounding skin, dry skin on tip of left elbow, no tenderness on nerve compression, joint swelling suspected as bursitis, no signs of septic arthritis (no redness or spreading inflammation observed)
* Vital signs: No fever at time of examination
* Test results: No current laboratory data; blood test forms arranged to check inflammatory markers, infection, rheumatological antibodies, and gout markers

A (Assessment):

* Bursitis of the left elbow

P (Plan):

* Prescribe Ibuprofen 400 mg orally twice daily after food; advise to stop if heartburn occurs
* Arrange blood tests for inflammatory markers, infection screening, rheumatological antibodies, and gout evaluation with forms sent to patient’s home
* Follow-up appointment to review blood test results and clinical status; appointment can be face-to-face, phone, or video as per patient preference
* Advise patient to seek urgent medical attention if left elbow becomes very red, painful, or if redness spreads, to rule out septic arthritis
* Patient education provided regarding symptom monitoring and expected time frame of test results (approximately 5-6 days after blood draw)

- Past medical history: Heart failure, asthma controlled with an inhaler, history of a small heart attack (no angina)

- Heart failure flare-up, suspected

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for 3 days, loose and watery stools, frequent need to stay close to toilet, lower left abdominal pain
* History of present illness: Symptoms started about 3-4 days ago with diarrhea, occasional vomiting at onset (no blood), sore throat occurring intermittently, runny nose with clear discharge, dry cough, muscle cramps in throat, weakness, shakiness, loss of appetite, mild headache with photophobia, no fever currently but had initial fever, no chest pain or breathing difficulty at rest, shortness of breath on exertion attributed to asthma
* Past medical history: Asthma controlled with inhaler
