SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
* History of present illness: Loose, watery stool occurring about six to seven times per day, lower left abdominal cramping pain below the belly button, intermittent, associated with weakness, shakiness, nausea, initial vomiting now resolved, loss of appetite, no blood in stool or urine, felt mildly febrile at symptom onset, needs to stay close to the toilet due to frequent bowel movements, no burning or stinging on urination
* Past medical history: Asthma controlled with inhaler, otherwise fit and well
* Social history: Accountant, working despite symptoms, non-smoker, does not drink alcohol
* Family history: No relevant family history reported; no household members with diarrhea though one child was vomiting
* Sexual history: Sexually active, uses contraception, last period two weeks ago, pregnancy possible but not confirmed
* Dietary history: Ate takeaway from a Chinese restaurant about four days ago, currently eating light foods and fluids

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No specific vital signs provided
* Physical exam: No specific physical examination findings provided
* Test results: No laboratory or imaging results provided

A (Assessment):

* Urinary tract infection, possible
* Differential diagnosis includes gastrointestinal infection, pregnancy-related causes

P (Plan):

* Empiric antibiotic therapy with Trimethoprim, one tablet twice daily for three days
* Recommend pregnancy test to exclude pregnancy-related causes
* Symptomatic treatment with Paracetamol for pain
* Advise oral hydration including cranberry juice for urinary symptoms
* Patient to monitor symptoms and return if worsening abdominal pain, persistent fever, vomiting, or no improvement after a few days
* Arrange initial diagnostic tests to clarify cause of symptoms (specific tests not detailed)

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
* History of present illness: Loose, watery stools about six to seven times daily, left lower abdominal cramp-like pain that comes and goes, weakness and shakiness without current fever but had a feverish feeling at symptom onset, initial vomiting without blood which has since stopped, loss of appetite but able to hold down fluids, symptoms affecting day-to-day activities and work, no blood in stools, no other family members with similar diarrhea symptoms though one child had vomiting
* Past medical history: Asthma, well controlled with inhaler
* Medications: Uses asthma inhaler; no other medications
* Social history: Does not smoke or drink alcohol, works as an accountant, lives with wife and two children

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No objective temperature measurement provided
* Physical exam: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Gastroenteritis, suspected (likely viral, possibly bacterial)

P (Plan):

* Conservative management with emphasis on adequate hydration, including oral rehydration solutions such as Dioralyte
* Use paracetamol (up to two tablets four times daily) for fever and weakness as needed
* Recommend rest and taking 2 to 3 days off work
* Advise follow-up if symptoms persist beyond 3 to 4 days for possible stool testing and further evaluation
* Patient education on symptom monitoring and when to seek further care

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the past three days with watery, loose stools occurring about six to seven times daily
* History of present illness: Diarrhea causing frequent need to stay close to the toilet, lower left abdominal cramp-like pain, weakness, shakiness, loss of appetite, mild fever at onset about three to four days ago, one episode of vomiting at symptom start (no blood), no current fever, occasional palpitations (heart beating faster than normal), recent cough with blood-streaked sputum
* Past medical history: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), asthma controlled with inhaler, on Methotrexate (last dose this morning)
* Social history: Works as an accountant, lives alone in a flat, has a cat, does not smoke or drink alcohol
* Family history: No history of blood clots or lung disease reported
* Other: Recently ate takeaway from a Chinese restaurant about four days ago; no other family members with similar diarrhea or vomiting symptoms though one child vomited

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: Heart rate approximately 66–74 beats per minute (measured by patient pulse count), no measured temperature provided
* Physical exam: Digital assessment by video for capillary refill and neck gland palpation attempted but limited by remote consultation; no overt signs of acute instability observed during online examination
* Test results: No laboratory or imaging results available

A (Assessment):

* Chest infection, suspected
* Consideration for pneumonia or other chest infection due to cough with blood and pleuritic chest pain
* Rule out lung cancer, possible pending further investigations

P (Plan):

* Arrange urgent face-to-face clinic assessment today for chest auscultation, blood pressure, pulse, and temperature measurements
* Possible initiation of antibiotic treatment after clinical assessment
* Support team to contact patient to book in-person appointment
* Consider chest X-ray if symptoms do not improve or clinical suspicion remains
* No medication prescribed at this time until further examination completed

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
* History of present illness: Loose, watery stool with frequent toilet use, lower left abdominal cramp-like pain, dry cough occurring about six to seven times a day, runny nose, weakness, shakiness, no current fever but had elevated temperature when symptoms started, vomiting at onset but now resolved, loss of appetite, able to tolerate fluids, no blood in stool or vomit, disturbed sleep due to symptoms, no chest pain, no shortness of breath while walking or daily activities
* Past medical history: Asthma managed with inhaler, diabetes mellitus (under hospital care), hypertension treated with Zinopril
* Social history: Accountant, currently working, smokes, drinks wine approximately within recommended limits but advised to cut down, no alcohol abuse reported, no illicit drug use mentioned
* Family history: No relevant family history reported
* Additional information: Lives with wife and two children, no other household members with similar diarrhea symptoms, no known medication allergies

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No current fever noted, history of elevated temperature at symptom onset
* Physical exam: No specific findings documented
* Test results: No laboratory or imaging results provided
* Additional observations: Patient reports no ear pain or discharge, passing urine normally, no rash or musculoskeletal complaints reported

A (Assessment):

* Viral illness (as stated by physician)
* No other explicit diagnosis provided

P (Plan):

* Supportive care with rest and adequate hydration
* Paracetamol for symptom relief as needed
* Advice to reduce alcohol intake gradually (to two glasses per week initially, then one, with potential future cessation)
* Encourage taking one to two days off work for rest
* Monitor symptoms; if no improvement in 2-3 days or worsening fever, persistent cough, or breathing difficulty, patient advised to return for re-evaluation and possible antibiotic therapy
* No other medications prescribed or tests ordered at this time

* Advise patient to keep a diary of potential triggers including clothing, shower gels, and soaps

S (Subjective):

- Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days with frequent loose, watery stools occurring about six to seven times per day
- History of present illness: Diarrhea accompanied by lower abdominal cramp-like pain primarily on the left side, no blood in stool, associated with weakness, shakiness, loss of appetite, and an episode of vomiting at the onset which has since resolved, initial febrile feeling about three to four days ago but no current fever, cough and cold symptoms started prior to diarrhea, dry cough without sputum or phlegm, no chest wheeze or rattling noises, no shortness of breath at present, symptoms affecting day-to-day activities and work as an accountant
- Past medical history: Diabetes mellitus diagnosed 5-6 years ago, hypertension treated with Lisinopril, asthma controlled with inhaler
- Social history: Does not smoke or consume alcohol
- Family history: No similar symptoms reported in family members except one child had vomiting without diarrhea

O (Objective):

- Vital signs: No fever currently; blood pressure measured this morning within normal limits, no specific values provided
- Physical exam: Mild redness at the back of the throat without tonsillar enlargement, no cervical lymphadenopathy
- Test results: No laboratory or imaging results provided

A (Assessment):

- Viral upper respiratory tract infection with associated diarrheal illness, suspected

P (Plan):

- Recommend symptomatic treatment with over-the-counter preparations such as Night Nurse and Day Nurse, compatible with current medications
- Advise monitoring for symptom progression including development of shortness of breath, wheezing, chest symptoms, or persistence of symptoms beyond three weeks
- Instruct to seek medical attention promptly if symptoms worsen or new concerning signs develop
- No additional medications or investigations required at this time
- Patient education and reassurance provided

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days with loose, watery stools occurring about six to seven times daily, lower abdominal pain described as cramp-like on the left side, weakness and shakiness
* History of present illness: Diarrhea started approximately three days ago, associated initially with vomiting which has since stopped, no blood in stool or vomit, history of mild fever at symptom onset, loss of appetite but able to hold down fluids, no breathing difficulty currently, localized rash and puncture mark on left arm from presumed bee sting, no swelling of lips currently but reported sensation of lip cramp, anxiety present but no history of anaphylaxis or use of EpiPen
* Past medical history: Asthma treated with inhaler, no other illnesses reported
* Family history: No relevant acute allergic reactions, one child with vomiting but no diarrhea
* Social history: Accountant, currently working though symptoms make it difficult, no smoking, no alcohol intake, no pets at home
* Allergies: No known food or pet allergies

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No fever or abnormal breathing observed at time of consultation
* Physical exam: Localized rash and puncture mark on left arm without redness or swelling, no lip or oral mucosa swelling observed, breathing normal, no stridor present, soft tissues of airway normal on inspection
* Test results: No diagnostic tests performed during this consultation

A (Assessment):

* Localized allergic reaction to insect bite, suspected
* Acute diarrheal illness, presenting with vomiting initially and ongoing loose stools

P (Plan):

* Advise patient to take over-the-counter antihistamines such as Piriton (Chlorphenamine) 4 mg tablet up to six times daily or once daily as preferred for allergic symptoms
* Educate patient about signs of systemic allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) including lip swelling, difficulty breathing, stridor, and advise urgent hospital attendance if symptoms develop or worsen
* Monitor for local infection signs such as spreading redness, warmth, or increased swelling; if present, consider antibiotic treatment
* Provide educational material about anaphylaxis for patient awareness
* Recommend follow-up if symptoms deteriorate or new symptoms arise, or if allergic reactions recur regularly requiring further investigation including possible blood testing
* Encourage patient to maintain hydration and continue bland/liquid diet as tolerated
* No allergy testing indicated at this time

- History of present illness: Loose, watery stools occurring about six to seven times daily, associated with lower abdominal cramping on the left side, weakness, shakiness, loss of appetite, prior vomiting at symptom onset but no current vomiting, no blood in stool or vomit, no current fever but had a temperature at symptom onset

* Past medical history: Asthma controlled with inhaler; no other medical conditions or medications except hormonal contraception started 3 months ago

* Advise keeping a headache diary to identify triggers

* Provide patient education and reassurance regarding current condition and red flags to observe

- Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days, loose and watery stools occurring about six to seven times per day
- History of present illness: Diarrhea started approximately six days ago, accompanying left-sided lower abdominal cramping pain described as muscular cramp, intermittent pain, associated weakness and shakiness; initial vomiting resolved; loss of appetite but able to hold down fluids; felt feverish at symptom onset three to four days ago but no current fever; no blood in stool or vomitus; no lower back pain or urinary symptoms reported; trouble with frequent toilet trips affecting daily activities
- Past medical history: Asthma controlled with inhaler, previous urinary infections
- Medications: No regular medications except asthma inhaler; allergic to Clindamycin
- Social history: Non-smoker, no alcohol consumption, works as an accountant
- Family history: No one else with similar symptoms; family includes wife and two children, one child had vomiting but no diarrhea

- Vital signs: No temperature recorded at consultation; patient advised to monitor temperature at home
- Physical exam: No information provided
- Test results: No urine or stool tests conducted; no imaging performed

- Urinary tract infection (infection in urine), suspected

- Prescribe a 3-day course of antibiotics for suspected urinary infection  
- Advise patient to stay well hydrated, drinking 2.5 to 3 liters of water daily  
- Recommend drinking cranberry juice and advise use of urinary pH modifying sachets available from chemist  
- Instruct patient to monitor symptoms and temperature at home, seek medical attention if pain worsens, lower back pain develops, high temperature occurs, or difficulty passing urine arises  
- Advise follow-up if symptoms do not resolve with treatment or if recurrent urinary symptoms occur  
- Send prescription electronically to patient's requested pharmacy for prompt collection and initiation of antibiotics

* Provide advice regarding sleep hygiene and coping strategies

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days with frequent loose, watery stools (about six to seven times per day), lower abdominal pain on one side described as cramp-like muscular pain, weakness and shakiness, occasional nosebleeds, cough with phlegm, loss of appetite, initial vomiting which has stopped, occasional temperature/fever at onset, mild chest symptoms (left-sided pain), no shortness of breath but occasional wheezing due to asthma
* History of present illness: Symptoms started approximately three to four days ago after eating takeaway food about four days ago; no other household members have diarrhea, only one child vomiting; difficulty managing day-to-day activities due to symptoms
* Past medical history: Asthma controlled with inhaler, diabetes (no recent blood sugar checks or details on control provided), no other medications except inhaler, no other medical problems mentioned
* Social history: Works as an accountant, does not smoke, does not drink alcohol
* Family history: No similar symptoms in family members, no other details provided
* Allergies: Patient reports having allergies but no details provided

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No current temperature measured; patient reports feeling hot at symptom onset but no thermometer confirmation
* Physical exam: No information provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Suspected viral chest infection
* Diabetes (known, no further details)
* Asthma (known, controlled)

P (Plan):

* Advise patient to monitor temperature regularly with a thermometer and seek re-evaluation if temperature remains above 37.5–38°C, if cough worsens, produces large amounts of phlegm, or if coughing up blood or if nosebleeds persist
* Continue current symptomatic treatment including use of lemsip (contains paracetamol); caution to avoid other paracetamol-containing products simultaneously
* Cough syrup recommended only at night if cough prevents sleep; daytime coughing is beneficial
* Emphasize maintaining hydration and light diet (soups, smoothies, liquids)
* Ensure regular diabetes and blood pressure follow-ups as scheduled by GP
* No antibiotics or other medications prescribed at this time
* Patient education given regarding symptoms that warrant urgent consultation (persistent fever, worsening cough, chest pain, shortness of breath, nosebleeds)

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days with loose, watery stool approximately six to seven times daily, lower abdominal cramping pain on the left side, weakness and shakiness, loss of appetite, vomiting at symptom onset which has since stopped
* History of present illness: Symptoms started about three to four days ago, initially associated with feeling hot (feverish) intermittently but no measured temperature, no blood in stool or vomit, able to hold down fluids but reduced oral intake, no other family members affected similarly except one child vomited without diarrhea, recent consumption of takeaway food and eating at a Chinese restaurant with friends about four days ago, no recent travel or unusual exposures reported
* Past medical history: Asthma controlled with inhaler, no other medical problems mentioned

* Social history: Accountant by profession, no smoking, no alcohol consumption
* Family history: No information provided

* Test results: No test results available, stool sample recommended for bacterial infection screening

A (Assessment):

* Infectious gastroenteritis, likely viral but possible bacterial etiology suspected

* Maintain light diet with simple foods such as toast or biscuits; avoid fruit, vegetables, milk

* If symptoms worsen or patient becomes unable to keep fluids down, advise urgent evaluation in Accident & Emergency
* Patient education provided on symptom monitoring and when to seek urgent care

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days with loose, watery stool occurring about six to seven times daily, accompanied by lower left abdominal cramp-like pain, weakness, shakiness, headache with intermittent visual disturbances, loss of appetite, and initial vomiting which has now resolved
* History of present illness: Symptoms started approximately three to four days ago with some raised temperature noted at onset but no current fever, no blood in stool or vomitus, headache ongoing for three days with occasional altered light vision, pain rated moderately severe, headache does not wake patient at night, tolerated fluids but reduced solid food intake mainly consuming soups and smoothies
* Past medical history: Asthma controlled with inhaler, no other medical problems mentioned
* Social history: Accountant by profession, no smoking, no alcohol use, no recent travel abroad, lives with wife and two children
* Family history: No relevant medical problems reported in family
* Other: No nasal, throat, ear symptoms, no respiratory symptoms, no neurological symptoms such as tingling, numbness, or weakness

* Book an appointment for a neurological examination including eye fundoscopy and blood pressure measurement to assess headache etiology and review current contraceptive pill appropriateness
* Advise urgent emergency department attendance if headache worsens, becomes unbearable, or changes significantly before scheduled appointment
* Continue current asthma inhaler therapy unchanged
* Provide patient education regarding symptom monitoring and follow-up plan

* Vital signs: No current fever observed, patient appears not dehydrated
* Physical exam: No specific physical exam findings documented
* Test results: No laboratory or imaging results provided

A (Assessment):

* No diagnosis explicitly stated or suspected by the physician during consultation

P (Plan):

* Diet advice: Soft diet avoiding dairy, fish, meat, eggs during diarrhea; start with crackers, toast, jam, then boiled vegetables and mashed foods; after 48 hours diarrhea-free, gradually reintroduce meat, eggs, fish
* Recommendation to maintain adequate fluid intake
* Suggestion to use probiotics such as yogurt to help restore gut flora
* Advice to avoid milk during diarrhea episode
* Instructions to monitor symptoms and seek further evaluation if diarrhea persists beyond one week or if blood appears in stool (stool sample may be needed)
* Warning to contact healthcare provider if bowel movements increase to 6–8 times per day due to dehydration risk, possibly requiring hospital admission
* Recommendation to consider over-the-counter oral rehydration solution (Dioralyte) to replenish lost salts
* Information documented in patient app for review and guidance
* Follow-up or further contact if symptoms worsen or persist

* Patient education provided regarding inhaler use and monitoring symptoms

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days, loose and watery stools about six to seven times daily, lower left abdominal pain described as cramping, weakness and shakiness, loss of appetite, initial vomiting stopped now

* Past medical history: Eczema, asthma controlled with blue inhaler used intermittently
* Social history: Accountant, non-smoker, no alcohol consumption

* Prescribe oral antihistamine Fexofenadine to manage eczema symptoms

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days, affecting daily activities, with frequent loose and watery stools (6-7 times per day)
* History of present illness: Lower abdominal cramping pain localized to the left side, intermittent, associated with weakness and shakiness, vomiting at symptom onset (ceased now), some burning pain on passing urine, loss of appetite, no blood in stool or vomit, no current fever but had a raised temperature at symptom onset about 3-4 days ago
* Past medical history: Asthma controlled with inhaler
* Medications: Uses an inhaler for asthma, no other regular medications
* Allergies: Severe allergy to Clindamycin
* Social history: Non-smoker, does not drink alcohol, accountant by occupation, sexually active with regular partner using condoms
* Family history: No details specifically provided, patient states no one else with similar symptoms except one child with vomiting but no diarrhea
* Other relevant history: Last period three weeks ago, no suspicion of pregnancy, recent intake included takeaway and Chinese restaurant meal

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No fever at presentation
* Physical exam: No details provided
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Simple urinary tract infection (bladder infection), suspected

P (Plan):

* Prescribe antibiotic therapy: Nitrofurantoin or Trimethoprim, one tablet twice daily for three days
* Advise increased fluid intake to help flush infection
* Suggest cranberry juice may help symptoms
* Counsel to continue barrier contraception but avoid sexual intercourse until symptoms resolve
* Advise patient to seek medical attention if symptoms worsen, including high fever, back pain, or feeling generally unwell, to rule out possible upper urinary tract infection (kidney involvement)
* Arrange follow-up or call if no improvement by end of the week

SOAP:
S (Subjective):

* Chief complaint: Diarrhea for the last three days
* History of present illness: Loose, watery stool about six to seven times a day, occasional lower left abdominal cramping pain described as muscular cramps, weak and shaky feeling, initial vomiting that has stopped, loss of appetite but able to hold down fluids, no blood in stool or vomit, intermittent fever at symptom onset, recent eating of prawn soup around seven o'clock four days ago, lip swelling developed about half an hour after eating the soup and progressively worsening, no symptoms of throat swelling or chest tightness reported initially
* Past medical history: Asthma controlled with Salbutamol inhaler
* Medications: Uses Salbutamol inhaler, takes antihistamines (specific name not provided)
* Social history: Accountant, no smoking, no alcohol use
* Family history: No one else with similar symptoms; mother reported severe allergic reaction requiring hospital, no peanut allergy history disclosed; wife and two kids without diarrhea, one child had vomiting
* Allergies: History of lip swelling after eating sandwich ruled out by patient; possible food-related allergic reactions mentioned by physician but patient denies prior severe reactions

O (Objective):

* Vital signs: No specific vital signs provided
* Physical exam: No explicit findings provided; patient reported lip swelling observed by physician
* Test results: No information provided

A (Assessment):

* Suspected anaphylactic reaction based on history of lip swelling, chest tightness, weakness, and previous allergic reaction history

P (Plan):

* Immediate call for ambulance due to concern for anaphylaxis
* Advise patient to take antihistamines while waiting for emergency services
* Recommend hospital evaluation and possible administration of emergency injection (e.g., epinephrine)
* Plan for follow-up after hospital discharge to arrange further management including possible prescription of emergency injections
* Patient advised to remain with someone until ambulance arrives and to contact medical provider after hospital visit
